urn:contentItem:5WFS-GPF1-JCJY-G4FV-00000-00Fintechs to crack banks' data vaults thanks to Payment Services Directive 2;Big lenders will soon let third parties unlock their customer account information, writes Niall Brady2019-06-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Fintechs to crack banks' data vaults thanks to Payment Services Directive 2Big lenders will soon let third parties unlock their customer account information, writes Niall BradyNiall Brady

When Sean Murphy worked in property management, one of the least popular tasks in the office involved tracing rents received back to the tenants who had paid them.

"We'd get hundreds of transactions into our bank account each month but we didn't know who they belonged to," says Murphy. "We had to copy and paste the information into a spreadsheet, and then try to identify who had paid what. It was perverse: our information was sitting inside the bank's systems but we couldn't get it out in a way that made sense."

The experience helped him realise that, somewhere under the grunt work, a good business idea might be lurking. What was needed was some way of tapping into the customer account information locked away in the banks, leveraging the data in ways that could make everyday life a lot less complicated.

As chief executive of Simpler, an online mortgage broker, Murphy has taken the first steps in this direction. Instead of the mountains of paperwork that are needed to support a typical loan application, first-time buyers can short-circuit the process with Simpler's app, which interfaces with mortgage providers behind the scenes.

Life should get easier for businesses such as Murphy's from September, when the EU's second Payment Services Directive (PSD2) comes into force. It will usher in a new era of open banking, forcing banks to allow third parties - retailers, fintech start-ups and rival lenders - to access the accounts of any customers who authorise it. A public awareness campaign about PSD2, billed by some as the biggest upheaval to hit retail or business banking in the past 50 years, has kicked off in recent days.

"It's your data but it's trapped in the bank," said Murphy. "Open banking will get the data out of the bank so that it can be used for useful applications."

By breaking the banks' stranglehold on customer data, the hope is that their monopoly on financial services might be loosened, if not broken.

For an idea of what to expect, most people are looking to Britain, which implemented PSD2 in January 2018. This has necessitated a £1bn ((EURO)1.1bn) investment by the country's banks and spawned almost 200 third-party businesses eager to harvest data from bank customers for a wide range of services.

Credit Ladder, for example, lets tenants build a credit history based on their rental payments - data that was previously not available to lenders when making credit checks.

Nestlings.io

works like a mobile game that helps users make regular savings. Yet Britons have been predictably reluctant to throw their bank accounts open to third parties.

"When you ask consumers to give away their data, their initial reaction is always no," said Garrett Cassidy, founder of Trezeo, an Irish company that has taken advantage of open banking in the UK. "Their attitude changes, though, if you can demonstrate how sharing data can create value."

Trezeo has raised (EURO)750,000 from backers including Voxpro founders Dan and Linda Kiely. It uses open banking to access the accounts of those with irregular earnings, such as taxi drivers and gig-economy workers, helping to smooth out their cashflow by holding back some income in busy weeks to help tide them over when work is less plentiful.

Initial expectations that the tech giants might use open banking as a weapon to break into financial services have so far proved unfounded. This may be because their ambitions are much greater than anything envisaged by PSD2. With Facebook planning its own currency, for example, it probably believes it has nothing to learn from conventional banks. Big tech may also be wary of PSD2 because the price for accessing banks' customer data is that third parties must agree to strict regulatory supervision.

Stripe, the payments unicorn founded by Irish brothers Patrick and John Collison, has obtained authorisation from the Central Bank of Ireland to provide PSD2-type services. There are no signs yet that other tech groups will follow.

"The open banking products that are out there are mostly good solutions for small problems," said Murphy. "Many of the companies behind them are probably not large enough to attract the funding that's needed to get regulated. You'd need a minimum of (EURO)100,000 to show the regulator you have the resources to stay solvent for the first 18 months."

Yet a number of Irish fintechs have surmounted the challenges of scale by concentrating on the UK. Swoop Funding, with (EURO)1.2m of backing from Enterprise Ireland and other investors, interrogates the bank accounts of UK small businesses to help them link up with about 1,000 providers of debt and equity capital.

"We condense the funding market for small businesses, which are generally knowledge- and time-poor," said founder and chief executive Andrea Reynolds.

Circit, whose backers include former Ulster Bank chief executive Jim Brown, has a tool that allows external auditors to obtain real-time confirmations from their clients' bankers. Luna Connect is a Galway start-up that uses open banking to gather information on businesses and individuals that are looking for credit.

"In some ways there's nothing new about what we do," said Cassidy, whose career before Trezeo included an eight-year stint at Bank of Ireland.

"Without open banking, however, it would be too laborious and expensive to go through people's statements manually to gauge what a reasonable level of income should be for each individual. The process is so much more efficient when we have direct access to people's electronic data."

Irish banks are well placed to roll out open banking, says Cassidy, because AIB, Bank of Ireland and Ulster Bank have been through the process in the UK, including developing the application programming interfaces (APIs) that link customers' accounts with third-party providers. "Using the same APIs as the UK lowers the barriers for UK third parties to come to Ireland," he said.

"I don't think they'd be interested if Ireland used different APIs, because the market is too small."

Swoop is already working with Ulster Bank and other local lenders on introducing its business funding platform to Ireland. "We're seeing a real shift in banks' mindsets," says Reynolds.

"They've moved from viewing open banking as a compliance issue - something they have to do because of PSD2 - to being an opportunity. They're becoming more collaborative, realising that if they cannot meet their customers' needs, there is an opportunity in helping them find funding elsewhere by working with third parties such as Swoop."

Fears that banks might use this collaboration as a Trojan horse to steal the clever ideas of emerging companies are unfounded, according to Fergal Coburn, chief digital and innovation officer at AIB.

"We're a bank," he said. "Our business is not scalable to a level where we could absorb all the fintech ideas out there."

Coburn believes one of the main threat to banks from PSD2 will come from other banks. If customers agree to allow AIB to access their accounts at other banks, for example, it could have a much better view of their overall finances, allowing for speedier lending decisions.

AIB opened an open banking portal in November last year for fintechs gearing up to take advantage of open banking. Despite a lot of interest, only eight third parties are connected to the bank's API so far. They include Fire Financial Services, a payments company founded by the businessman Colm Lyon, who sold his Realex Payments for (EURO)115m in 2015.

"We've made a big investment in this," says Coburn. "Take-up has been disappointing but I expect open banking will be similar to our experience with contactless payment cards. They were a slow burn at first but usage has accelerated dramatically, to the point where half of card transactions are now contactless."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60D6-GSK1-JCMN-Y0X6-00000-00Fiona, Apple, and Amazon: How Big Tech Pays to Win the Battle of Ideas2020-07-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisFiona, Apple, and Amazon: How Big Tech Pays to Win the Battle of IdeasDavid Dayen

Jul 20, 2020( The American Prospect Blogs: http://prospect.org/blogs Delivered by Newstex) A large and persistent network of communicators competes in Washington for the attention of the political class: think tanks, advocacy groups, newspaper op-ed writers, cable-news expert guests, academics, lobbyists. They have varying degrees of legitimacy among the public, but all of them contribute to the stream of information that policymakers and their staffs interact with and consume. It's a constant low hum attempting to influence, shape, and control, and even by osmosis, it tends to work.Large corporations have long figured out that by laundering their self-interested views through these third parties, they can confer feigned legitimacy upon them. In rare moments when the political class actually seems roused enough to do something, corporations who fear legal or regulatory changes start collecting legitimizers more rapidly.

The more independent the communicator appears, the greater the victory for the corporate benefactor. And the biggest win of all is to get someone perceived as a critic into the fold.Which brings us to the case of Fiona Scott Morton, and me. Scott Morton is a Yale economist who served in the antitrust division of the Justice Department and now directs the Thurman Arnold Project[1], a collaborative research institution named after the famed antitrust enforcer. A year ago, I wrote a piece[2] for The New Republic about her, noting that her rhetoric on competition policy had sharpened, pushed forward by the incipient anti-monopoly movement. Given that Scott Morton may very well serve as a top antitrust official in a hypothetical Biden administration, her shift toward more aggression on monopoly seemed important enough to elevate.More from David Dayen[3]So it matters that Scott Morton has been taking money[4] advising Apple and Amazon, at a time when both firms face antitrust investigations in Congress and among state and federal law enforcement. Fiona self-disclosed the relationship[5] in a panel discussion last month. The Apple consulting is longstanding; she took on Amazon as a client within the past year.This is far more the norm than the exception; in fact, there's even a duopoly among consulting firms that outsource experts and academics to monopolies. Compass Lexecon and Charles River Associates, have 10 prior lead economists at the Justice Department's antitrust division[6] on their payroll. (Scott Morton, one such economist, works with Charles River[7].) When Gene Kimmelman worked on a series of reports building an antitrust case against the tech giants, he 'had to hire an outside lawyer,' according to Bloomberg, to detail the potential conflicts among those toiling on the project.The problem goes well beyond one researcher and one set of client relationships. Scott Morton contributed to two of those reports, making cases against Facebook and Google. The CEOs of those companies will appear before the House Antitrust Subcommittee next week, along with the CEOs of Amazon and Apple, Scott Morton's clients.She reconciles this by saying that those papers covered Facebook and Google exclusively, and that 'I work for companies that I'm comfortable are not breaking the law.' Personally, I don't see much daylight between, say, Google steering video search results to its YouTube subsidiary[8] and Amazon steering shopping searches to its house brands[9]. The lawsuit over tech companies using people's faces to test facial recognition software[10] without their permission implicates Google and Amazon. Your donation keeps this site free and open for all to read. Give what you can...SUPPORT THE PROSPECT[11]Similarly, Facebook's strategy of buying potential rivals[12] seems identical to Apple buying a company[13] every two to three weeks. Apple's domination of its App Store[14] seems to go well beyond Google's Android store for phone apps, requiring developers to seek Apple's approval to get access to its iPhone users.Maybe there are nuances here, and there are many ways to resolve these issues short of an antitrust violation. But it's common sense that, if policymakers are scrutinizing four Big Tech companies, and Fiona Scott Morton works for two of them, and she writes papers about how the other two are stone-cold lawbreakers, then she's by definition steering policymakers toward the companies she doesn't work for, to the benefit of those she does.Lack of disclosure on op-ed pages is ubiquitous; small business owners or experts put their names to arguments constructed by tech platforms, hiding behind the writer's presumed independence. In other cases, Scott Morton has written publicly about her clients. In a Washington Post op-ed published last July[15] titled 'Why 'Breaking Up' Big Tech Probably Won't Work,' Scott Morton dismisses breakups as 'sloganeering,' preferring other restraints that promote competition. The op-ed parrots a common theme of the tech platforms that market share could merely be a function of offering popular products. She didn't disclose her tech consulting in that piece.In response to a question from the Prospect, Scott Morton maintained that the op-ed was only about Facebook. 'I don't think a piece on Facebook required a disclosure about work for any other company, pharmaceutical, tech, or otherwise,' she said in an email. She added that she was not working for Amazon at the time, only Apple. But the piece mentions Apple twice and is clearly framed around the tech giants as a whole, not any one company. It even includes a disclaimer about the Post's owner, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, which would be odd on a piece solely about Facebook.Scott Morton has also drawn blood on Amazon in the past. A paper she wrote[16] citing Amazon forcing third-party sellers to not offer a lower price elsewhere on the web led to Amazon ending the practice[17]. Amazon had a strategy to prevent that from happening again; hire the expert who pointed it out. This is a win for Amazon even if they get no useful advice about navigating antitrust law out of the consulting relationship.Zephyr Teachout of Fordham Law, a prominent critic of monopolies, called for Scott Morton to step down[18] from the Thurman Arnold Project after the revelation. 'She cannot continue as the Director without undermining its integrity,' Teachout argued.But the problem goes well beyond one researcher and one set of client relationships. Lack of disclosure on op-ed pages is ubiquitous[19]; small business owners or experts put their names to arguments constructed by tech platforms, hiding behind the writer's presumed independence. Hal Singer detailed at the Prospect last week[20] the hundreds of congressional and regulatory staffers who have found their way to work for Amazon, Facebook, and Google. The open shilling[21] for Big Tech going on throughout academia and BigLaw and think tanks is so commonplace you can write a detailed article outlining who's on what side. Your donation keeps this site free and open for all to read. Give what you can...SUPPORT THE PROSPECT[22]This buzz in the ear of decision-makers all day long creates the monopolists' desired impression. Kamala Harris's frequent team-ups with tech giants[23] during her state attorney general career offers a window into how this works.It's very clear that monopolist purchases of experts who align with their self-serving claims threaten the functioning of democracy in the public interest. In fact, here's an article making exactly that case[24] with specific examples, co-authored by Austin Frerick, who is now the deputy director of the Thurman Arnold Project, working directly for Fiona Scott Morton. urn:contentItem:5WY6-TPD1-JCJY-G4H2-00000-00Fire1 chief Conor Hanley wants to make Ireland the beating heart of medtech2019-08-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Fire1 chief Conor Hanley wants to make Ireland the beating heart of medtechGavin Daly

When he gets the chance, Conor Hanley likes to leave his house at dawn in his dressing gown and go for a dip in the sea across the road. "I hate the cold water but you feel great getting out," says Hanley, chief executive of Fire1, a low-profile but heavily backed Dublin medical technology firm. "You know the day is going to get better after that."

It must be the only time he has to himself. As well as the day job at Fire1, which is developing a remote monitor for heart failure, he is chairman of the Irish Medtech Association (IMA); sits on the board of Enterprise Ireland; and lectures in enterprise at University College Dublin (UCD), his alma mater.

For good measure, Hanley has just started playing five-a-side football and is determined to learn how to surf. Unsurprisingly, the targets on the activity app on his Apple Watch are set to their maximum level. "I try to keep busy," he says.

Fire1 alone is a big undertaking. The venture raised (EURO)40m last year from heavyweight investors, and has 30 staff between offices at Dublin City University's Alpha innovation campus and UCD's Nexus research centre.

The office walls carry quotes from heart failure patients, and Hanley is clearly highly motivated. "We are trying to solve heart failure," he says.

"It helps on a Monday morning commute to have a purpose to your work. Building a business is a long, hard journey, so it's important to keep that focus on why you're doing it."

Fire1 has developed its core technology and is "moving into the clinical roadmap", says Hanley. That will involve a lengthy period of testing and certification before Fire1 products are available.

With his IMA hat on, meanwhile, Hanley represents 450 medtech companies that employ a combined 38,000 people and account for exports worth more than (EURO)12.5bn a year. Not as sexy as big tech or as high-profile as pharma, it is an industry that prioritises "substance over style", he says.

Ahead of the 2020 budget, the IMA is calling on the government to improve tax incentives for entrepreneurs and co-fund a (EURO)42m advanced manufacturing centre in Limerick. Its pre-budget submission warns that, post-Brexit, the UK will surely try to use lower taxes and incentives to lure business from Ireland.

"There is a phenomenal opportunity for Ireland to be one of the dominant centres for healthcare solutions," says Hanley, slipping slightly into jargon about the internet of things. "A lot of the building blocks are here but we need to ensure we don't lose that opportunity."

Hanley's CV makes him a decent poster boy for the sector. He attributes his business inclinations partly to his father, who had his own business as a consultant engineer.

One of four children, Hanley grew up in Foxrock, south Dublin, and went to St Michael's College in Ballsbridge. He moved on to UCD to study chemical engineering, graduating in 1990.

He did well enough to score a scholarship to do a PhD at Pennsylvania University in Philadelphia, which claims the distinction of being the first higher-level institution in America to refer to itself as a university. Hanley specialised in nanotechnology and spent five years at the university.

"I loved the meritocracy and the can-do attitude in America," he says. "A lot of it was hard work but it gave me a foundation for what I do - tech and innovation with a really global focus."

He went to work at Air Products & Chemicals, an industrial chemicals multinational based in Pennsylvania. One of the world's largest producers of industrial gases, it employs about 16,000 people and is valued at $50bn ((EURO)45bn) in New York.

Hanley got wide experience with Air Products in the US and Europe, including working on a project in Belgium to bring nitrogen into beer cans to keep the beer bubbly. In the late 1990s, he was involved in the launch of the first hydrogen fuel cell car in London.

His next step was a scholarship to do an MBA at Insead, the famed graduate business school at Fontainebleau in France. Hanley enjoyed the course and loved France.

"It was quite a transformative experience. At Insead, you meet a huge diversity of people from different backgrounds, all with global ambitions."

By the time he graduated from Insead in the summer of 2001, Hanley had been out of Ireland for 11 years. He does not mind admitting he was motivated to come home in pursuit of his now wife, Grainne, who was in Ireland.

"I believed Ireland had transformed in that time, and I wanted to come back and get involved in something," he says. "I wanted to try to consolidate the various elements of my career up to then."

In Dublin, he joined Ntera, an early-stage nanotechnology company that had been spun out from UCD research. Founded by college professor Donald Fitzmaurice, Ntera raised about (EURO)40m in funding to develop hi-tech displays for electronics products but ultimately went into liquidation in 2011.

Hanley left in 2004 and still speaks highly of the experience. "It was ahead of its time," he says. "Donald is a great visionary. and Ntera's employees have gone on to do many other ventures."

He can count himself among them. With his multinational experience, MBA and start-up stint, Hanley had a desire to do something of his own and narrowed his focus to the healthcare sector.

"I had an itch I still wanted to scratch," he says. "There was a lot of talk at the time about technology transforming healthcare and helping people to live longer. I became obsessed."

With two academics from UCD's school of electronic and electrical engineering, Conor Heneghan and Philip de Chazal, he co-founded the medtech outfit BiancaMed. It developed a wire-free sensor for measuring sleep and breathing, with the potential to detect conditions from sleep apnoea to heart failure.

ResMed, a US specialist in medical products for sleep and respiratory disorders, was a seed investor. BiancaMed raised about (EURO)10m in total, with backers including DFJ ePlanet Ventures, Seventure Partners in France, Enterprise Ireland and Invest Northern Ireland.

The company licensed in some technology and did its own development in Dublin. Its product was manufactured in Shenzhen, China, and launched in Japan, and also sold through Apple stores.

In January 2011, ResMed bought out the other investors and took 100% ownership of BiancaMed for about (EURO)25m. Following the acquisition, Hanley joined ResMed, which invested in expanding the R&D facility in Dublin. Over five years at the US group, he ran its chronic disease management solutions division, its cardiology business, and its ventures and initiatives business units. "I was Dublin-based but spent 70%-80% of my time abroad, from San Diego to Sydney, to Tokyo," he says. "That whole period was very helpful for me in terms of learning from peers in different business units and environments."

In 2016, he was hired to run Fire1, which had been launched two years earlier by the Foundry, a Californian medtech incubator. Fire1 was the 15th company from the Foundry but the first it located outside the US, says Hanley.

"They liked the talent and the medtech base in Ireland," he says. "It was very early-stage when I joined, but with a great investor base and core talent."

In tandem with Hanley's hiring, the company raised $7.5m from healthcare group Covidien and venture capitalists Lightstone Ventures and New Enterprise Associates. In January last year, it raised a further (EURO)40m, with Gilde Healthcare, Gimv and Seventure Partners joining the existing investors.

For many of the financial backers, it was their first deal in Ireland. Hanley knows it was an eye-catching amount for a company that few people knew existed. "It is a big number for Ireland and even in a European context," he says. "I would say the investors and I are equally ambitious about what we can achieve."

The company may raise more funding depending on its needs, he says.

"It's the nature of this sector. We are continuing to grow the team, and thinking of second and third versions of our products."

Hanley still travels widely to keep on top of trends in medicine, technology and regulation. The US sucks up a lot of medtech investment and China is an emerging power, but Ireland holds its own, especially in talent, he says.

"I interact a lot with universities, and with doctors and healthcare professionals. The calibre of our doctors and researchers is world-class. Ireland is a great place to innovate."

Hanley is doing his bit on the education front, as a part-time associate professor of electronic engineering at UCD, where he teaches a module in entrepreneurship in engineering. The class promises to explain what it is like to start a company, including "all its chaos, uncertainty, impossible deadlines [and] conflicting input".

Having been through all that in real life, Hanley has a confession, however.

"I don't think of myself as an entrepreneur," he says. "I'm just driven by whatever project I'm working on, by the team and the innovation we're doing."

With some help from those early-morning swims, of course.

The life of Conor Hanley Vital statistics Age:

50

Home:

Monkstown, Dublin

Family:

Married to Grainne, a doctor, with two children: Louise, 9, and Michael, 7

Education:

Engineering degree from University College Dublin, PhD in chemical engineering from Pennsylvania University, and MBA from Insead, France

Favourite book:

Bruno, Chief of Police series, by Martin Walker

Favourite film:

Jiro Dreams of Sushi, a Netflix documentary about a top sushi chef

Working day

I go for a swim at 6.30am, have breakfast, then get in early to avoid the traffic. We have offices at UCD and at DCU's incubation centre. I finish at 6.30pm-7pm. I travel 30%-40% of the time, to conferences and meetings.

Downtime

I have started playing five-a-side football and I'm one of the oldest [players], so it's like Russian roulette for injuries. I've made it my life's ambition to learn to surf. I play tennis, too. I love having dinners with family and friends.

urn:contentItem:60G1-JBV1-F03R-N4GR-00000-00Fire & Fawning2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisFire & Fawningilene

Jul 29, 2020( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Fire & Fawning[1] Courtesy of Scott Galloway at No Mercy / No Malice[2], @profgalloway[3] (originally publishedJuly 24, 20[4]) The CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google are scheduled to testify in front of the US House Judiciary Antitrust Subcommittee. Some thoughts Bigtech has won before the hearing starts. Agreeing to let all four testify concurrently inhibits the committee's ability to go deep on any one issue, and will leave the American public with a sentiment instead of a viewpoint on big tech, much less any conclusions (such as, that the Obama DOJ was asleep at the switch, and Instagram and Whatsapp should be divested). The Covid-inspired remote format dramatically lessens the likelihood of an unscripted moment that reveals something the American public didn't previously know. Fabric softener for tough questioning is the deep pockets that keep members in power.

When the show starts, Zuck will be the target of the most ire, as he's an oligarch minus the charm. Bezos, on the other hand, will receive the least ire, as his command of soft power is second only to China. Being on these committees must be just awesome, as every member clings to their office as if they were Puerto Rican rescue dogs clinging to lamb lung fillet. (I see this with my dog Gangster. It's a moment that gives you pause to see how much a living thing can love something else.) Bezos has the power to take away the committee's lamb treats (he owns a powerful arbiter in theWaPo) and, maybe more important, they want invites to the best parties in DC (low bar) at the old textile museum— Bezos's man cave in Kalorama. I think Bezos lacks character and code (he gamifies the commonwealth for his own enrichment #HQ2), but I'd love to roll with him, and so would every first ballot hall of lame panelist questioning him at the hearings. Cook and Pichai will likely just try to stay out of the line of fire and fawning for Zuck and Bezos, respectively. Expect Zuck to use two words repeatedly in his defense (tik and tok[5]) as he attempts to wrap himself in the flag and convince the committee that he's our national champion, singularly able to repel the invading Chinese coming for our children. But there is hope. By limiting the hearing to the antitrust subcommittee, the House gives more time to representatives who have domain expertise. The sharpest of these embers, if they take the right approach, may be able to move the needle from apathy towards outrage and build momentum for future change. The key here is to recognize the mediumisthe message. Exploit the one attribute of the format that can be much improved: visuals. These always look awkward and very fifties during live testimony, though Representative Katie Porter does a great job with her mini white boards (note to self: get one). The 'share screen' function should be the weapon of choice here. Words will communicate themes (you're too big and abuse your monopoly power, which suppresses innovation, job growth, and the economy). Little is new here, but points can be communicated more effectively than before. The best opportunity to yield insight into why big tech should be broken up is to highlight the scale of the firms, and the problem. The winning cocktail is visuals and proportion. The effective panelists at these hearings use the witness as a prop to stamp their passport on the way to the destination (you're a monopoly). The strategy is simple: ask a question, share screen/visual, unshare so public can see an awkward reaction by witness, allow 5 seconds max for answer, interrupt, and wash/rinse/repeat. So, as I'm hoping to be unanimously approved as US Ambassador to Australia in the Biden Administration (#itcouldhappen), here are my suggestions for visuals and questions: All Four Q: Messrs. Bezos, Cook, Pichai, Zuckerberg, your firms have added greater market capitalization in the last five years than the largest retailers and CPG firms have in total. This is a large portion of the entire consumer economy. If you were public servants, would you be concerned that too many of the spoils are being registered by increasingly fewer firms and people? Q: Your market capitalization per employee is thousands of times higher than that of other companies in your sectors. Do you think your companies contribute to income inequality? Q: Since the onset of the pandemic, nearly every sector, other than big tech and companies deemed too big to fail, has shed substantial value. Instead, since the beginning of the year, your firms and Microsoft have increased in value by an average of 35%, while the remaining 495 firms in the S&P 500 are down 5%. Every firm, sector, and economy appears to have incurred a transfer in value and power to your firms. Should we be concerned that your considerable advantage pre-Covid is now unassailable? Q: Small business formation is at a multi-decadelow[6]. The fastest-growing sectors receive scant funding from investors. Why should someone invest in a search engine right now, or a music streaming business, or a social media platform, or an e-commerce firm, given the sizes of your companies? Apple Q: Mr. Cook,monopoly rentis when a monopoly producer lacks competition and thus can sell its goods and services at a price far above what the otherwise competitive market price would be, at the expense of consumers. Our information age is often called 'the app economy,' denoting how important apps have become to commerce and consumption. Your firm and Google dominate the app ecosystem, with62% and 38%[7]shares, respectively. This chart shows the rents you are able to extract from every streaming video app. Every media company that wants to reach a consumer online must pay you a toll or rent. Do you think any of these firms believe that paying you this rent is a choice? Q: Apple TV+ is offering consumers $1 billion in original content for every .80c a month the consumer spends on your Apple TV+ streaming video service. Isn't it your opportunity to differentiate your $1,300 phones and fund Apple TV+ from the revenues of an unrelated product that allows you to offer a media product at well below cost? In sum, isn't Apple guilty of 'dumping,' that is, buying market share with unfeasibly low prices? Q: Spotify is consistently rated as a superior music service to your Apple Music, yet Apple Music is growingfaster[8]than Spotify in the US. Isn't this a function of you owning the rails, and being able to levy a30%[9]tax on a competitor while illegallyreducing[10]their discoverability in the app store? Amazon Q: Mr. Bezos, you are the wealthiest person in the world. Your wealth exceeds the GDP of Kuwait and Luxembourg, combined. It exceeds the defense budgets of Israel, France, Germany, and the United Kingdom, combined. A common feature among the other wealthiest Americans of the 20th century (Rockefeller, Morgan, Mellon, Carnegie, Gates) is that most/all of these men presided over firms that were eventually tried for monopoly abuse and deemed monopolies. Why should we believe your wealth accumulation is any different? Q: Last year, Amazon paid $162 million in federal tax while your largest competitor, Walmart, paid almost $3 billion. Do you think this level of participation in our country's infrastructure and services is appropriate for a company worth $1.5 trillion? Q: Due to Covid-19, US consumers are expected to spend an additional $41 billion on retail ecommerce in 2020. Since you control38%[11]of US e-commerce revenue, doesn't this mean that you've added at least $16 billion in topline revenue due to Covid while thousands of small businesses havefolded[12]? Q: In a five-week period during the pandemic, your firm added the value of the world's largest firm by revenue —Walmart[13]. If your firm can accrete the value of the largest firm in the world in five weeks, and money is power, then isn't your firm the most powerful private entity in history? Hasn't your firm reached a level of soft and economic power well beyond the point when the DOJ has historically taken antitrust action? Q: Our understanding is your firm has more full-time lobbyists in Washington than there are sitting US senators. Are you aware of any retailer or tech firm, other than Google, that has this manylobbyists[14]attempting to suppress regulation or antitrust action? Q: Mr. Bezos,82%[15]of American homes have Amazon Prime, more than voted in the 2016 election, have a pet, attend church, or decorate a Christmas tree. Can you name any other firm that has a recurring revenue relationship with 8 out of 10 households? Q: Your video content, as registered by IMDB and the National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences, is far inferior to the content offered by AT&T's division (HBO), yet you refuse to distribute HBO Max as a stand-alone offering on your service. Doesn't this mean you are leveraging your distribution power to weaken the competition (HBO Max[16]) and reduce consumer access to better content? Q: Mr. Bezos, the recently released TOS for your audio and podcast platformsay[17]that participants on the service cannot say anything bad about Amazon. Are we to assume that all assets you control, includingThe Washington Post, are restricted to only positive comments regarding you and your firm? Google Q: Mr. Pichai, your search engine is the default on Android devices, and you have amultibillion[18]dollar contract with Apple to be the default search engine on the iPhone. You've alsobought[19]digital advertising networks[20]to build your part of the digital advertising duopoly. What company —whether a search business or an advertising firm —can begin to compete with a behemoth with such a massive advantage and such deep pockets? Q: Google owns the dominant digital ad server, DoubleClick Ad Exchange, or AdX. Over90%[21]of large publishers sell their ad inventory on AdX. And Google owns the dominant tool, Google Ads, through which advertisers purchase inventory on AdX. Don't you think controlling both the auction house for ad space and the main auction participant for buying those ad spaces allows Google to engage in anticompetitive pricing? Q: You've been finedthree[22]times by the EU for acting in ways that harm competition. Google searchesfavor[23]YouTube ahead of other video rivals. Searches often display results just under the question as the user types, making it unnecessary to click any links. This deprives other firms of revenue. You present search resultsas you see fit[24], independent of the cost to other businesses. Don't you think having 71% share in the search business and increasingly locking other companies out of profits through search is unfair use of monopoly power? Q: YouTube has come under criticism many times in the past for radicalizing our children through an algorithm that suggests increasingly violent and extreme content. A user can start out with 'downtown NYC' and within three videos they are being offeredconspiracy[25]theories about how 9/11 was an inside job. One of your former engineers accused YouTube ofperverting civic discussion[26]through radicalizing algorithms. Don't you think that if YouTube were its own company and had more competitors of similar size, that it would be forced to work harder to correct these algorithms that are so toxic to the public good? If the best corrective mechanism of a free market is competition, where is the competition to force you to do better? Q: Mr. Pichai, can you name any other firm, anywhere in the world, that has this level of market share of a sector greater than $100 billion in size? Facebook Q: Mr. Zuckerberg, a Princeton Universitystudy[27]of Americans' internet habits leading up to the 2016 presidential election found that Facebook led users to untrustworthy news sites 15% of the time, and to trustworthy news sites only 6% of the time. Studies have also found that the underlying Facebook algorithm, which promotes emotion and outrage, benefitted Trump more than Clinton. Do you feel partially responsible for the erosion in the sanctity of our elections? Q: This summer, a number of Facebook's biggest advertisers announced a boycott of the platform in response to your inadequate handling of hate speech. In response, Nick Clegg, your Vice President for Public Affairs, said, 'We've made huge strides But, you know, on an average day, there are 115 billion messages sent on our services around the world, and the vast, vast, vast majority of that is positive.' Clegg's defense is alsoan admission[28]that Facebook is too large to safely manage. Are you too big to protect your platform from hate speech and socially divisive messaging? Q: As we saw in the 2016 elections, Facebook's powercan be exploited[29]to disrupt elections, broadcast viral propaganda, and inspire deadly hate campaigns around the globe. Facebook is an algorithmic rage machine that perpetuates conspiracy theories (including that vitamins will protect you from Covid) at a far greater rate than truth. Enragement is engagement. Nearly half of all top-performing posts that mention voting by mail arefalse or misleading[30]. What good are you offering your users that outweighs the cyberwar Russia fought on your platform, and that it is prepared to fight again, the systematic surveillance of users, and the torrent of misinformation on your platform? Q: Teen suicide has skyrocketed — up 77% for older teen girls and up 151% for younger teens. Hospital admissions due to self-harm are up 50% for 15-19-year-old girls and up 200% for 10-14-year-old girls. Gen Z is on the brink of theworst[31]mental health crisis in decades. Do you think platforms like Instagram, where girls perpetually feel their appearance doesn't match up to filtered images, has something to do with this mental health crisis? Q: Mr. Zuckerberg, you are in sole control of a platform whose algorithms select and deliver content (news and entertainment) to2.6 billion[32]people. Your algorithms are opaque to government agencies. You are the principal source of information for a cohort larger than any country orreligion[33]— a population greater than that of China and the US, combined. You cannot be removed from office, and will likely control these algorithms for the next 5-7 decades. So, we'd like to get to know you better. You know, get a feel for the real Mark Zuckerberg. A couple of questions: Are you a pathologicalliar[34]? Do you display alack[35]of remorse or guilt? And again Are you a pathologicalliar[36]? Life is so rich, P.S . More about my take on the hearings (or at least, more entertaining) on this week'sProf G Show[37]. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G7-H9H1-F03R-N405-00000-00'Fire & Fawning' - Scott Galloway: Here's What Politicians Should Ask The Big-Tech CEOs Today2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexis'Fire & Fawning' - Scott Galloway: Here's What Politicians Should Ask The Big-Tech CEOs TodayZero Hedge

Jul 29, 2020( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1] View original post here[2]. Authored by Professor Scott Galloway via ProfGalloway.com,[3] The CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google are scheduled to testify in front of the US House Judiciary Antitrust Subcommittee later today. Some thoughts Big tech has won before the hearing starts. Agreeing to let all four testify concurrently inhibits the committee's ability to go deep on any one issue, and will leave the American public with a sentiment instead of a viewpoint on big tech, much less any conclusions (such as, that the Obama DOJ was asleep at the switch, and Instagram and Whatsapp should be divested). The Covid-inspired remote format dramatically lessens the likelihood of an unscripted moment that reveals something the American public didn't previously know. Fabric softener for tough questioning is the deep pockets that keep members in power.

When the show starts, Zuck will be the target of the most ire, as he's an oligarch minus the charm. Bezos, on the other hand, will receive the least ire, as his command of soft power is second only to China. Being on these committees must be just awesome, as every member clings to their office as if they were Puerto Rican rescue dogs clinging to lamb lung fillet. (I see this with my dog Gangster. It's a moment that gives you pause to see how much a living thing can love something else.) Bezos has the power to take away the committee's lamb treats (he owns a powerful arbiter in theWaPo) and, maybe more important, they want invites to the best parties in DC (low bar) at the old textile museum— Bezos's man cave in Kalorama. I think Bezos lacks character and code (he gamifies the commonwealth for his own enrichment #HQ2), but I'd love to roll with him, and so would every first ballot hall of lame panelist questioning him at the hearings. Cook and Pichai will likely just try to stay out of the line of fire and fawning for Zuck and Bezos, respectively. Expect Zuck to use two words repeatedly in his defense (tik and tok[4]) as he attempts to wrap himself in the flag and convince the committee that he's our national champion, singularly able to repel the invading Chinese coming for our children. But there is hope. By limiting the hearing to the antitrust subcommittee, the House gives more time to representatives who have domain expertise. The sharpest of these embers, if they take the right approach, may be able to move the needle from apathy towards outrage and build momentum for future change. The key here is to recognize the mediumisthe message. Exploit the one attribute of the format that can be much improved: visuals. These always look awkward and very fifties during live testimony, though Representative Katie Porter does a great job with her mini white boards (note to self: get one). The 'share screen' function should be the weapon of choice here. Words will communicate themes (you're too big and abuse your monopoly power, which suppresses innovation, job growth, and the economy). Little is new here, but points can be communicated more effectively than before. The best opportunity to yield insight into why big tech should be broken up is to highlight the scale of the firms, and the problem. The winning cocktail is visuals and proportion. The effective panelists at these hearings use the witness as a prop to stamp their passport on the way to the destination (you're a monopoly). The strategy is simple: ask a question, share screen/visual, unshare so public can see an awkward reaction by witness, allow 5 seconds max for answer, interrupt, and wash/rinse/repeat. So, as I'm hoping to be unanimously approved as US Ambassador to Australia in the Biden Administration (#itcouldhappen), here are my suggestions for visuals and questions: All Four Q: Messrs. Bezos, Cook, Pichai, Zuckerberg, your firms have added greater market capitalization in the last five years than the largest retailers and CPG firms have in total. This is a large portion of the entire consumer economy. If you were public servants, would you be concerned that too many of the spoils are being registered by increasingly fewer firms and people? Q: Your market capitalization per employee is thousands of times higher than that of other companies in your sectors. Do you think your companies contribute to income inequality? Q: Since the onset of the pandemic, nearly every sector, other than big tech and companies deemed too big to fail, has shed substantial value. Instead, since the beginning of the year, your firms and Microsoft have increased in value by an average of 35%, while the remaining 495 firms in the S&P 500 are down 5%. Every firm, sector, and economy appears to have incurred a transfer in value and power to your firms. Should we be concerned that your considerable advantage pre-Covid is now unassailable? Q: Small business formation is at a multi-decadelow[5]. The fastest-growing sectors receive scant funding from investors. Why should someone invest in a search engine right now, or a music streaming business, or a social media platform, or an e-commerce firm, given the sizes of your companies? Apple Q: Mr. Cook,monopoly rentis when a monopoly producer lacks competition and thus can sell its goods and services at a price far above what the otherwise competitive market price would be, at the expense of consumers. Our information age is often called 'the app economy,' denoting how important apps have become to commerce and consumption. Your firm and Google dominate the app ecosystem, with62% and 38%[6]shares, respectively. This chart shows the rents you are able to extract from every streaming video app. Every media company that wants to reach a consumer online must pay you a toll or rent. Do you think any of these firms believe that paying you this rent is a choice? Q: Apple TV+ is offering consumers $1 billion in original content for every .80c a month the consumer spends on your Apple TV+ streaming video service. Isn't it your opportunity to differentiate your $1,300 phones and fund Apple TV+ from the revenues of an unrelated product that allows you to offer a media product at well below cost? In sum, isn't Apple guilty of 'dumping,' that is, buying market share with unfeasibly low prices? Q: Spotify is consistently rated as a superior music service to your Apple Music, yet Apple Music is growingfaster[7]than Spotify in the US. Isn't this a function of you owning the rails, and being able to levy a30%[8]tax on a competitor while illegallyreducing[9]their discoverability in the app store? Amazon Q: Mr. Bezos, you are the wealthiest person in the world. Your wealth exceeds the GDP of Kuwait and Luxembourg, combined. It exceeds the defense budgets of Israel, France, Germany, and the United Kingdom, combined. A common feature among the other wealthiest Americans of the 20th century (Rockefeller, Morgan, Mellon, Carnegie, Gates) is that most/all of these men presided over firms that were eventually tried for monopoly abuse and deemed monopolies. Why should we believe your wealth accumulation is any different? Q: Last year, Amazon paid $162 million in federal tax while your largest competitor, Walmart, paid almost $3 billion. Do you think this level of participation in our country's infrastructure and services is appropriate for a company worth $1.5 trillion? Q: Due to Covid-19, US consumers are expected to spend an additional $41 billion on retail ecommerce in 2020. Since you control38%[10]of US e-commerce revenue, doesn't this mean that you've added at least $16 billion in topline revenue due to Covid while thousands of small businesses havefolded[11]? Q: In a five-week period during the pandemic, your firm added the value of the world's largest firm by revenue —Walmart[12]. If your firm can accrete the value of the largest firm in the world in five weeks, and money is power, then isn't your firm the most powerful private entity in history? Hasn't your firm reached a level of soft and economic power well beyond the point when the DOJ has historically taken antitrust action? Q: Our understanding is your firm has more full-time lobbyists in Washington than there are sitting US senators. Are you aware of any retailer or tech firm, other than Google, that has this manylobbyists[13]attempting to suppress regulation or antitrust action? Q: Mr. Bezos,82%[14]of American homes have Amazon Prime, more than voted in the 2016 election, have a pet, attend church, or decorate a Christmas tree. Can you name any other firm that has a recurring revenue relationship with 8 out of 10 households? Q: Your video content, as registered by IMDB and the National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences, is far inferior to the content offered by AT&T's division (HBO), yet you refuse to distribute HBO Max as a stand-alone offering on your service. Doesn't this mean you are leveraging your distribution power to weaken the competition (HBO Max[15]) and reduce consumer access to better content? Q: Mr. Bezos, the recently released TOS for your audio and podcast platformsay[16]that participants on the service cannot say anything bad about Amazon. Are we to assume that all assets you control, includingThe Washington Post, are restricted to only positive comments regarding you and your firm? Google Q: Google owns the dominant digital ad server, DoubleClick Ad Exchange, or AdX. Over90%[17]of large publishers sell their ad inventory on AdX. And Google owns the dominant tool, Google Ads, through which advertisers purchase inventory on AdX. Don't you think controlling both the auction house for ad space and the main auction participant for buying those ad spaces allows Google to engage in anticompetitive pricing? Q: You've been finedthree[18]times by the EU for acting in ways that harm competition. Google searchesfavor[19]YouTube ahead of other video rivals. Searches often display results just under the question as the user types, making it unnecessary to click any links. This deprives other firms of revenue. You present search resultsas you see fit[20], independent of the cost to other businesses. Don't you think having 71% share in the search business and increasingly locking other companies out of profits through search is unfair use of monopoly power? Q: YouTube has come under criticism many times in the past for radicalizing our children through an algorithm that suggests increasingly violent and extreme content. A user can start out with 'downtown NYC' and within three videos they are being offeredconspiracy[21]theories about how 9/11 was an inside job. One of your former engineers accused YouTube ofperverting civic discussion[22]through radicalizing algorithms. Don't you think that if YouTube were its own company and had more competitors of similar size, that it would be forced to work harder to correct these algorithms that are so toxic to the public good? If the best corrective mechanism of a free market is competition, where is the competition to force you to do better? Q: Mr. Pichai, can you name any other firm, anywhere in the world, that has this level of market share of a sector greater than $100 billion in size? Facebook Q: Mr. Zuckerberg, a Princeton Universitystudy[23]of Americans' internet habits leading up to the 2016 presidential election found that Facebook led users to untrustworthy news sites 15% of the time, and to trustworthy news sites only 6% of the time. Studies have also found that the underlying Facebook algorithm, which promotes emotion and outrage, benefitted Trump more than Clinton. Do you feel partially responsible for the erosion in the sanctity of our elections? Q: This summer, a number of Facebook's biggest advertisers announced a boycott of the platform in response to your inadequate handling of hate speech. In response, Nick Clegg, your Vice President for Public Affairs, said, 'We've made huge strides But, you know, on an average day, there are 115 billion messages sent on our services around the world, and the vast, vast, vast majority of that is positive.' Clegg's defense is alsoan admission[24]that Facebook is too large to safely manage. Are you too big to protect your platform from hate speech and socially divisive messaging? Q: As we saw in the 2016 elections, Facebook's powercan be exploited[25]to disrupt elections, broadcast viral propaganda, and inspire deadly hate campaigns around the globe. Facebook is an algorithmic rage machine that perpetuates conspiracy theories (including that vitamins will protect you from Covid) at a far greater rate than truth. Enragement is engagement. Nearly half of all top-performing posts that mention voting by mail arefalse or misleading[26]. What good are you offering your users that outweighs the cyberwar Russia fought on your platform, and that it is prepared to fight again, the systematic surveillance of users, and the torrent of misinformation on your platform? Q: Teen suicide has skyrocketed — up 77% for older teen girls and up 151% for younger teens. Hospital admissions due to self-harm are up 50% for 15-19-year-old girls and up 200% for 10-14-year-old girls. Gen Z is on the brink of theworst[27]mental health crisis in decades. Do you think platforms like Instagram, where girls perpetually feel their appearance doesn't match up to filtered images, has something to do with this mental health crisis? Q: Mr. Zuckerberg, you are in sole control of a platform whose algorithms select and deliver content (news and entertainment) to2.6 billion[28]people. Your algorithms are opaque to government agencies. You are the principal source of information for a cohort larger than any country orreligion[29]— a population greater than that of China and the US, combined. You cannot be removed from office, and will likely control these algorithms for the next 5-7 decades. So, we'd like to get to know you better. You know, get a feel for the real Mark Zuckerberg. A couple of questions: Are you a pathologicalliar[30]? Do you display alack[31]of remorse or guilt? And again Are you a pathologicalliar[32]? urn:contentItem:608Y-MCD1-JCBW-N3RY-00000-00Fireworks on US markets may last way beyond July 42020-07-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 45Fireworks on US markets may last way beyond July 4Harvey Jones

YESTERDAY'S US Independence Day celebrations were muted as firework displays were cancelled, but the country's stock market continues to put on a dazzling show.

After the shock of the financial crisis,Wall Street went on to enjoy its longest bull run in history, powered by the runaway success of its world-beating "mega-cap" technology giants.

Investors have made fortunes from holding shares in social media site Facebook, smartphone maker Apple, retail giant Amazon, streaming service Netflix and Google-owner Alphabet.

Apple, Amazon, Alphabet and Microsoft are the only US companies in history to be valued above $1 trillion. Incredibly, just when analysts thought that the tech giants could not get any bigger, Covid-19 has given them another boost.

As the planet went into lockdown, people kept up with friends on Facebook, logged on to their iPhones and MacBooks, splurged on Amazon, binge-watched Netflix and Googled just about everything.

If you hold US funds inside your pension or Stocks and Shares Isa, you will have reaped the benefit. But can the US continue to outperform as political tensions grow ahead of the presidential election on November 3? TECH SURGE The Nasdaq index of US technology stocks has returned an astonishing 500 per cent in the last 10 years, thrashing almost every rival. If you had invested £10,000 a decade ago, you would have £60,000 today.

'Stocks Big tech's success powered the US S&P 500 index of top stocks, which grew around 300 per cent. Over the same period, our FTSE All-Share Index grew just 87 per cent.Your money has gone much further in the US.

both and and second FundCalibre managing director Darius McDermott said US markets have even shrugged off the pandemic: "While the UK is still down 17.6 per cent so far this year, the S&P 500 has held steady and the Nasdaq is up 19.8 per cent."

US stocks face economic and political uncertainty, and fears of a second coronavirus wave, but investors should retain exposure. "The US is still the world's largest economy, and too important to ignore," he added.

If you want to invest in the US, McDermott suggests funds Axa Framlington American Growth, JPM US Equity Income, Schroder US Mid Cap and LF Miton US Opportunities.

TERRY SMITH The popular Fundsmith Equity, managed by Terry Smith, is heavily invested in the US, and grew 146 per cent in the last five years. It is now one of the UK's largest funds, worth more than £20billion.

Scottish Mortgage has done even better, returning an incredible 222 per cent over the past five years. It is a global fund, but its US holdings include big positions in Amazon andAlphabet.With both funds, remember that past performance is never a guarantee of future success.

Ryan Hughes, head of active portfolios at investment platform AJ Bell, said Baillie Gifford American is now one of the most popular funds among its investors. "It has returned 54 per cent during the past six months, helped by its concentrated positions INAMAZON,Tesla and Netflix," he said.

By comparison, the domestic stock market has flopped again.The four worst performing sectors in 2020 are all from the UK - with the Equity Income sector falling 20 per cent, and the All-Companies, Smaller Companies and Equity & Bond Income sectors faring almost as badly.

Adrian Lowcock, head of personal investing at advisory firmWillis Owen, said UK performance has been hit by the weak pound and the large number of companies cutting dividends during the pandemic.

It could bounce back, especially if we get Brexit clarity. "The worst is probably over now," Lowcock said.

face economic political Willis Owen figures show that Morgan Stanley US Growth is a top performing fund this year, growing 64 per cent, closely followed by Matthews China Small Companies. "Chinese shares have performed well as the country was the first to go into lockdown, and the first to come out." LF Ruffer Gold is up 56 per cent this year, as investors poured into the precious metal as a safe haven.

of a wave of TRUMP TROUBLE Politics will dominate as President Trump seeks re-election and could cast a cloud over the stock market.

Fidelity International's portfolio manager Aditya Khowala said Trump faces a tough task as the US grapples with recession and Covid-19.

He expects Trump to "throw the kitchen sink at the economy", on top of trillions of dollars of stimulus from the US Federal Reserve: "GDP could increase more than 20 per cent in the third quarter as a result."

That would boost US share prices as well as Trump's election hopes. Khowala said the US market may look expensive after recent success, but has momentum on its side.

The US tech giants face regulatory challenges and cannot maintain today's growth rates forever, but most investors should have some exposure.

Remember to diversify by investing in regions such as China and Europe. Who knows, even the UK market might put on a show one day.

'Stocks face both economic and political uncertainty, and fears of a second wave of coronavirus'

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SBD-JRB1-JCJY-G1KM-00000-00Firing Line: Richard Clode2018-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisINVESTMENTSVersion:1Firing Line: Richard ClodeMelanie Tringham

Many longstanding financial advisers may be wary of investing in tech funds, given the stocks' notorious volatility 17 years after the dotcom crash.

For Richard Clode, portfolio manager on the global technology team at Janus Henderson Investors where he helps run two retail funds with two other managers, in total managing £4.5bn, there are certain factors to look out for.

Having been hired straight from university to work in the tech sector at Herald Investment Management (and only a couple of years after the original dotcom bubble burst), he works with those more experienced hands looking for stocks where the market might have missed something, or where there is still strong growth but the stock is not hugely overvalued.

Tech stocks, in general, trade at a 14 per cent premium to global equities. Mr Clode said: "Quality consumer companies trade on the same multiples as a lot of these tech stocks. We look at a company where we have an upside to earnings expectations, and you're not having to pay for it, and it happens to be a tech company."

Fangs

Much of the attention is inevitably focused on Fangs - Facebook, Apple, Netflix and Google (although that acronym is changing to include Microsoft and Alphabet). Rather than going on "hype and expectation", Mr Clode said that his team goes where they think "growth potential is underestimated, and we think in five years' time they will still have growth".

"We're not going to build it up and then pull out. Who knows if you're going to get [that type of investment] right. We're trying to reduce the volatility of clients investing in tech; clients who have wanted to invest in tech but don't want to have the very volatile up and down years."

The funds he helps to run invest in Facebook, because despite the recent setbacks and the potential for regulation, it still has plenty of long term potential. Even though the stock fell 10 per cent following the Cambridge Analytica revelations, and potential regulatory implications, it rose 55 per cent last year.

He said: "WhatsApp [which is owned by Facebook] is the biggest messaging site in India. We still think they have a good position of user growth. And they still haven't monetised heavily in Europe - we still think they've got some levers to pull. In the US they've gone a bit overboard, but they still have some levers.

"Netflix has been a relatively cleaner story. It hasn't been targeted by [US president] Donald Trump in a tweet - we think it's a fantastic company." However, the company has high valuations so Mr Clode does not think it is worth buying into that stock.

The funds have about a 20 to 25 per cent turnover, with the entire fund turning over every four to five years. Mr Clode tends not to be very reactive to a stock if it is poorly performing: "If you don't think the investment case is broken then you wouldn't sell it.

"If you were in a Russian stock and they invaded Crimea and you think this is good long-term, but they face sanctions then you're forced to sell it."

Both funds have 50 stocks. "Running a tech fund, we understand the obsession with Fang. We don't invest in all of them, only because we thought all of these other stocks were underappreciated. We thought it's paying too much for Netflix but we hold the others because we thought there was a good investment case. There are a lot of exciting tech stocks that have created a great return for us."

A lot of the big tech stocks are about to benefit from a beneficial tax regime, which means many of them will be bringing a large amount of cash onshore, putting it on their balance sheet, and some may be distributing it to shareholders. Apple's intended dividend means its share price has held up well despite the recent trouble with the iPhone X, which had production issues relating to the Face ID.

In addition, Mr Clode is interested in the less flashy tech stocks, such as Microsoft and Intel, as tax breaks are also encouraging firms to invest in IT infrastructure that they may have been putting off for a few years.

Mr Clode said: "These are the stocks that are beating earnings and they're not expected to beat earnings. If they can beat earnings they should go up." The trick is finding stocks where the market has not already priced in a rise, if the manager expects good news: "That's what keeps us in a job".

Outlook

Looking to the future, Mr Clode said, was a near impossible task. "Technology moves exponentially, it doesn't go one step at a time. It's very hard for us to [imagine] where it's going to go. There's no pathway to machine intelligence and super intelligent robots. Maybe there will be a breakthrough that creates the algorithm and learns like a baby."

It is impossible to say where processing power will be in the future, he said, so who knows where computing will take us.

Melanie Tringham is features editor at Financial Adviser

Richard Clode's Career Highlights

2014 - present: Portfolio manager, technology equities, Janus Henderson Investors

2012: Emerging markets research portfolio manager/technology analyst, Pioneer Investments

2010: Asian equity long/short technology analyst, Moore Capital

2007: Emerging markets technology analyst, Gartmore Asset Management

2003: Asian technology portfolio manager, Herald Investment Management

urn:contentItem:5JTD-J9G1-JD3N-54XX-00000-00Firms confident despite $A rise: CBA2016-05-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 22Firms confident despite $A rise: CBAMICHAEL RODDAN

Commonwealth Bank business banking boss Adam Bennett says the Australian dollar's unexpected rally between February and May this year did not deter firms from seeking new lending, thanks to low rates.

During a workshop at the bank's newly launched pop-up innovation lab, Mr Bennett said there was no direct correlation between the movements in the Australian dollar and business lending, and despite pockets of weakness in the business loan book in Queensland and Western Australia, the overall quality of the book was "very, very sound".

Mr Bennett welcomed the measures in the federal budget aimed at companies, but said the current focus on tech start-ups as the backbone of innovation in Australia needed to the broadened to drive improvement across all businesses.

"We were pleased to see in the budget a focus on the business sector and on stimulatory measures that would really promote favourable conditions across small and medium-sized businesses," Mr Bennett told The Australian. "The tax cuts, the asset write-off criteria extension have all been very favourably received around Australia." "To create sustainable growth in the economy, I think it's important both to balance short-term measures, which are still very positive, with the broader-view outlook for the economy and the measures that can be taken that drive confidence in businesses across the country." Mr Bennett said the start-up sector was a very important part of the country's innovation agenda. "But it's by no means the entire story," he said. "It's absolutely critical that all businesses of all sizes across all industries and sectors see innovation as something that is within their reach and important to their success." The comments came as global ratings agency Moody's warned the banking sector that although it had an incumbent advantage against fintech competitors, a major competitive reversal could still be on the cards.

"Greater movement toward open data, for instance, could unglue one of banks' strongest defences by making it easier to switch financial services providers," Moody's senior vice-president Robard Williams said.

CBA's innovation lab, a smaller version of the flagship lab in Sydney, allows the bank's clients to workshop ideas in a space rich with data.

About 40 per cent of transactions in Australia are controlled by CBA, data which the lab then packages and presents to its clients in an interactive format.

Clients can, for instance, track how much a consumer from a particular postcode spends on groceries or restaurants, and see when they make their purchases.

"The innovation approaches that have served businesses well in the past will be insufficient to meet the realities of the future," Mr Bennett said.

Australia ranks 21st out of 32 developed countries for the proportion of large businesses deemed to be innovating.

"Critical to our ongoing strategy is investing in innovation, particularly in the business banking sector.

"We've got considerable investments that are going into our products and solutions that are designed to create real value for our clients," Mr Bennett said.

While fintechs have had some successes in individual business lines, Moody's said the sector had yet to prove its resilience to a range of economic and financial market conditions. Moody's estimates there are about 4000 fintech start-ups globally and investment in the sector has exploded from $2.4 billion to $19bn over the past four years.

A more defined regulatory stance would crystallise, and perhaps change, the rules of engagement between fintechs and traditional banks, Mr Williams said."And a killer app or the entrance of one or more Big Tech players, with large customer bases and deep pockets, could quickly shift the financial services landscape."
