The new package — worth an...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60FM-R1F1-JB77-K3TP-00000-00FirstFT: Today’s top stories2020-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisFirstFT: Today’s top storiesGordon Smith and Eli Meixler

Florida has overtaken New York as the state with the second-highest number of confirmed coronavirus infections as Republicans prepare to unv... Florida has overtaken New York as the state with the second-highest number of confirmed coronavirus infections as Republicans prepare to unveil a new stimulus package for the faltering US economy. The new package — worth an...

Florida has overtaken New York as the state with the second-highest number of confirmed coronavirus infections as Republicans prepare to unv...

Florida has overtakenNew York as the state with the second-highest number of confirmed coronavirus infections as Republicans prepare to unveil a new stimulus package for the faltering US economy.

The new package — worth an estimated $1tn — will include a direct cash payment of $1,200 for each person, an extended moratorium on evictions and reduced federal unemployment benefits, according to Trump administration officials who previewed the proposal on Sunday.

But Steven Mnuchin, the US treasury secretary, said the new legislation may have to be introduced on a piece-by-piece basis because of disagreements between Republican and Democratic lawmakers. Time is running out. The previous measures, which have propped up the US economy during the coronavirus pandemic, are due to expire at the end of the month.

Meanwhile, Florida has become the state with the second-highest number of confirmed infections, behind only California, after reporting nearly 12,000 new cases on Saturday and 9,338 on Sunday, for a total of nearly 424,000 cases. Saturday marked the first time since May 23 that the death toll has risen by more than 1,000 for five consecutive days across the US.

Coronavirus digest

Gold soared to a record high on Monday as the sharp rise in US coronavirus cases and flare-ups around the world weighed on investor confidence.

Travel shares tumbled across Europe as new curbs coincided with the start of the summer tourist season. The UK has reimposed quarantine for travellers from Spain. (FT)

Jair Bolsonaro made headlines in Brazil and around the world for his admonitions that Covid-19 is a mere “sniffle”, while near-neighbours Chile and Peru introduced European-style lockdowns. Latin America editor Michael Stott looks at pandemic politics across the continent.

A draconian lockdown in India — imposed with no warning, no planning and no transparency into the policy deliberations or scientific advice behind it — has failed to flatten the curve.

North Korea has declared a state of emergency in a southern border city, the first admission that the pandemic may have breached its frontier. (FT)

The FT has launched a global economic recovery tracker to provide a first snapshot of activity across key sectors. Follow our live coverage here.

In the news

Europe’s big banks brace for Covid-19 linked losses The largest UK, Swiss and eurozone lenders are expected to provision at least €23bn for the second quarter as they report earnings in coming days, according to analysts at Citigroup. (FT)

US oil production wells up US oil companies have increased production by 1.2m barrels a day over the past six weeks, as they restart wells shut when prices sank. Output bottomed out at 9.7m b/d in June but has since risen to 10.9m b/d. (FT)

Bridgewater sued by former co-chief executive Eileen Murray, the former co-chief executive of Bridgewater Associates, is suing the hedge fund over its alleged refusal to pay deferred compensation of up to $100m after she disclosed a gender discrimination dispute with the company. (FT) 

US universities under pressure to cut feesGeorgetown has become the latest US university to cut course fees after 2,000 students signed a petition accusing the elite institution of “highway robbery” for maintaining its tuition fees at nearly $58,000 a year, despite moving most of its courses online. But most top US universities are refusing to cut fees. (FT)

Intel sends shockwaves through chip industry A rare slip by Intel has left the chip making industry contemplating a decisive shift in leadership in the world’s most advanced manufacturing technology. Intel’s shares ended down 16 per cent on Friday, while rival TSMC’s market value leapt by 10 per cent after the US chipmaker said it would delay the introduction of its next generation of microchips. (FT)

HSBC denies Huawei ‘trap’ HSBC denied “ setting traps to ensnare” Huawei in breaking US sanctions, its first public comments on the controversy. The US, which is looking to exploit cracks in the Russia-China relationship, also suspended its Fulbright programme in Hong Kong and China. (FT, SCMP)

SAP announces Qualtrics IPO The German software giant intends to float US subsidiary Qualtrics, which it bought for $8bn two years ago. Chinese IPOs on Wall Street have more than doubled since the start of this year, raising $2.9bn despite US-China tensions. (FT)

Macron’s dilemma France’s president has postponed his flagship pension reforms to next year while his government steers the economy out of a Covid-19 recession. But with a presidential election looming in 2022, many wonder if Emmanuel Macron can risk angering trade unions again. (FT)

VW’s EV rush Volkswagen’s first purpose-built electric car, the ID. 3, has attracted tens of thousands of pre-orders from new, younger customers as its ambition to overtake market pioneer Tesla picks up pace. (FT)

Olivia de Havilland, 1916-2020 Olivia de Havilland, who has died at the age of 104, is remembered by film goers for her role in Gone with the Wind and by the industry for a 1940s lawsuit that established actors’ independence from studios. (FT)

The day ahead

Chinese researcher in US court Juan Tang, who US authorities allege was a member of the Chinese military hiding in the San Francisco consulate, is to appear in court. In Chengdu, US diplomats left the consulate after a Monday deadline. (FT, BBC)

Space talks Russian and American officials will meet in Vienna to discuss whether and how to regulate the militarisation of space, days after US Space Command said Russia had recently tested a space-based anti-satellite weapon. (FT, Guardian)

Brexit sticking points EU-UK future-relationship talks remain deadlocked on fishing rights and state subsidies as Michel Barnier and David Frost open a third round of “intensified” talks on Monday. (FT)

Boris Johnson has been shadowboxing around a deal, Peter Foster writes in our latest Brexit Briefing newsletter. Sign up here.

What else we’re reading

Lunch with the FT Jim Chanos has been cast as the “Darth Vader of Wall Street” and the “Catastrophe Capitalist”. The 62-year-old short-seller, who predicted the downfall of US energy giant Enron almost two decades ago, prefers to describe himself as a “forensic financial statement junkie”. (FT)

Big Tech is back in the congressional hot seat On Wednesday, the chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google will be questioned in a House judiciary antitrust subcommittee hearing. This is perhaps the most important and high-profile conversation about monopolies since the Microsoft case of the 1990s, writes Rana Foroohar. (FT)

Asset managers, eco-warriors Despite fears of a swift retreat from climate pledges, coronavirus has actually spurred commitments to sustainable investing as many warily foresee the economic damage of climate catastrophe. US investors are demanding data on corporate efforts to fight racial discrimination. (FT)

The ghost City Coronavirus could permanently transform London’s financial centre, which traces its roots back to 1376, as the success of homeworking keeps staff home. Hiring in a pandemic is less easy than it looks, Pilita Clark writes — but Andrew Hill says lay-offs are the worst of the bad options facing recession-hit companies. (FT)

Johnson fuels Scottish separatism Boris Johnson’s first trip to Scotland since last December’s general election highlighted his status as the recruiting sergeant for Scottish independence, as calls grow for a second referendum. The FT View is that the government needs a positive strategy to preserve the three-century-old union. (FT)

Sweden’s companies reap Covid-19 benefit From telecoms equipment maker Ericsson to consumer appliances manufacturer Electrolux, Swedish companies have beaten expectations, raising questions about whether the Nordic country’s light-touch coronavirus strategy was the correct course after all. (FT)

What are the wealthy buying? Diamonds and Dutch masters — jewellers, auction houses and property agents are reporting brisk business at the very top of the income scale, where coronavirus has proven more inconvenience than existential threat. Plus, how an influx of leisure customers is helping the private jet market survive the pandemic. (FT)

Video of the day

How to spot a Covid-19 outbreak from data Data journalist John Burn-Murdoch examines how the outbreak in England and Wales has unfolded and how data distinguish isolated clusters from community spread. (FT)

Jay Powell has warned that a full economic recovery may take until the end of next year and require a Covid-19 vaccine.“For the economy to f... Jay Powell has warned that a full economic recovery may take until the end of next year and require a Covid-19 vaccine. “For the economy to fully recover, people will have...

Jay Powell has warned that a full economic recovery may take until the end of next year and require a Covid-19 vaccine.“For the economy to f... Jay Powell has warned that a full economic recovery may take until the end of next year and require a Covid-19 vaccine. “For the economy to fully recover, people will have...

Jay Powell has warned that a full economic recovery may take until the end of next year and require a Covid-19 vaccine.“For the economy to f...

Jay Powell has warned that a full economic recovery may take until the end of next year and require a Covid-19 vaccine.

“For the economy to fully recover, people will have to be fully confident,” and that “may take a while”, the Federal Reserve chairman told CBS News on Sunday.

Donald Trump said last week that he hoped to have a vaccine ready by the end of 2020, but public health experts have warned that it is likely to take longer.

Mr Powell said that while lawmakers had “done a great deal and done it very quickly”, Congress and the Fed may need to do more “to avoid longer run damage to the economy”. On Friday, the US House passed a Democratic plan for $3tn more in stimulus over Republicans’ objections.

Barack Obama offered a rare public rebuke of the Trump administration on over the weekend, telling a virtual college commencement that leaders in Washington “aren’t even pretending to be in charge”. In case you missed it, here’s Edward Luce’s excellent look inside   Trump’s coronavirus meltdown. (FT, CBS)

Coronavirus digest

Japan has fallen into its first technical recession since 2015, its economy contracting 3.4 per cent in the first quarter even before a nationwide lockdown.

India extended its lockdown by another two weeks and   suspended new bankruptcy cases.

Italy and Portugal will ease restrictions on shops, restaurants and travel from Monday, and Spain’s prime minister sought a final, month-long extension of emergency powers.   Beaches reopened across Europe

Germany cracked down on anti-lockdown protesters, fearing infiltration by far-right extremists. Returning citizens helped New Zealand’s   population pass 5m.

Covid-19 patients are suffering symptoms for six weeks or longer. (FT, BBC)

Follow our  tracker of national lockdowns and our    live coverage here.

In the news

Buffett dumps Goldman shares Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway has dumped the bulk of the stake in Goldman Sachs that it acquired in the depths of the financial crisis. Berkshire revealed in filing late on Friday that it sold more than 10m Goldman shares in the first quarter, a holding that was worth $2.3bn at the end of last year and represented 2.9 per cent of the investment bank. (FT)

European IPOJAB Holdings will this week unveil its intention to float the world’s largest pure-play coffee company, including the Jacobs Douwe Egberts Group roasting business and Peet’s chain of coffee shops. JAB, which manages the wealth of Germany’s billionaire Reimann family, plans to raise as much as €2bn from the Amsterdam listing of its JDE Peet’s coffee business. (FT)

Dividends face $500bn cut Close to $500bn could be wiped from dividends this year as companies scramble to protect balance sheets, according to a worst-case scenario estimate. British banks are investigating whether they   pressured corporate clients into extra business in return for loans following a warning from the financial watchdog. (FT)

Contenders eye WTO helm The unexpected early departure of World Trade Organization director-general Roberto Azevêdo has caused a frantic search for his replacement amid deep concern for the institution, former trade officials said. The WTO is needed today as much as ever, writes the   FT’s editorial board. (FT)

American Airlines faces turbulence Investors are betting that American Airlines, which has $34bn of debt compared with $23bn at Delta and United, will file for bankruptcy for the second time in a decade in what lawyers grimly call “Chapter 22”. (FT)

Taiwan’s travel trial The Taiwanese government and Stanford University are preparing a quarantine and testing regime for foreign travellers that could provide a new protocol for international travel. Taiwan has fared better than most in containing Covid-19, suffering just seven deaths. (FT)

Oil volatility sparks debate The US commodities-market regulator is poised to loosen curbs on commodities speculators, just weeks after sales by the largest oil-linked exchange traded fund helped drive crude prices off a cliff. But analysts foresee   stronger oil prices as lockdowns ease. For the first time in two months,   US oil prices are above $30 a barrel today. (FT)

Israel’s new government After nearly 18 months of political deadlock, a unity government between Benjamin Netanyahu and Benny Gantz was sworn in on Sunday. In Afghanistan, president Ashraf Ghani reached a   power sharing deal with his political rival Abdullah Abdullah, paving the way for the government to present a united front in negotiations with the resurgent Taliban. (FT)

The day ahead

WHO meeting Health ministers from the WHO’s 194 member states meet virtually on Monday and Tuesday. Taiwan retracted its bid for participation just hours before the conference was due to begin. (FT)

US automakers reopen Ford, General Motors, and FiatChrysler plan to   restart production on Monday, but a smooth return may be   hindered by Mexico, which has delayed reopening “essential” manufacturing operations until June 1. (NYT, CNBC)

Hit the pitch England’s Premier League is set to allow clubs to begin training, after Germany’s   Bundesliga reopened — in empty stadiums — at the weekend. Here’s why stadiums are   perfect disease incubators. (AFP, FT, WSJ)

Has coronavirus advanced or set back women at work? Join Emma Jacobs and Laura Noonan for a live Q&A at 12pm and 5pm UK time

What else we’re reading

Why the US jobless surge is worse than in Europe For decades, European economists have studied the American labour market with admiration, recognising its superior flexibility and lower average unemployment rates over successive economic cycles. That flexibility, which has long been its greatest asset relative to Europe, may have become its greatest handicap during this crisis, writes Gavyn Davies. (FT)

Tesla’s mad genius defies US lockdown Elon Musk has been railing against the pandemic response for months but his recent stand-off with California bureaucrats won him new fans in America’s heartland and the White House. It was nothing more than a brilliant marketing ploy, writes our San Francisco correspondent   Patrick McGee. (FT)

Banks should raise capital to survive With coronavirus set to be an order of magnitude worse than the 2008 crash, it is striking that few are asking whether banks will need new capital, Patrick Jenkins writes. Worried about money?   You are not alone, writes Claer Barrett. (FT)

Big Tech’s viral boom could be its undoing Surveillance capitalism was a dirty phrase before coronavirus. Now, it is business as usual. But the first post Covid-19 regulatory push is already happening around privacy, Rana Foroohar writes. (FT)

The end of the office? It is now hard to imagine a time when the office wasn’t central to our cities and our lives. Is this the end of the office century, Henry Mance asks.   Lucy Kellaway hopes not, offering an impassioned defence of the office as escape from our hearths, or better still, from our usual selves. (FT)

Letter from China: Sichuan goes with the flow As China unlocks internal travel, Yuan Yang’s journey from Beijing to a village in Sichuan to visit her grandparents offers a hint about how we will live with Covid-19. Barcelona’s W Hotel has   a single guest, charged with checking all 1,400 taps. (FT, NYT)

Crisis in Europe Ursula von der Leyen is planning an audacious bid for new powers, seeking to put the European Commission at the centre of efforts to revive the EU economy. But the former German defence minister’s young presidency faces a crucial test: bridging bitter divides within the bloc over recovery funds. (FT)

Responsible business in times of crisis Gillian Tett kicks-off a new series on responsible business by assessing whether businesses can keep the promises made on ESG (ethical, social and governance) during this crisis, while   Patrick Temple-West shines a spotlight on executive pay.

Seeing the good amid the bad In countries around the world, the pandemic has inspired fresh public displays of gratitude. None make up for the devastation, but we should be grateful for consolations too, writes Pilita Clark. Beware bad habits and mad ideas rushed through under pressure,   Andrew Hill warns. (FT)

Find more top reads in our Long Story Short newsletter, written this week Lilah Raptopoulos, US head of audience engagement and co-host of Culture Call. Sign up   here to get LSS in your inbox every Friday.

Video of the day

The rise and fall of global trade In the first in a new video series, senior trade writer Alan Beattie explores the forces behind the surge and collapse of globalisation from the Roman and Mongol empires to Donald Trump and Covid-19. (FT)

Donald Trump became the third president in US history to be impeached on Wednesday night when the House of Representatives charged...

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.Donald Trump became the third president in US history to be impeached on...

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

Donald Trump became the third president in US history to be impeached on Wednesday night when the House of Representatives charged him with abuse of power and obstruction in a partisan vote that paves the way for a Senate trial next month.

“The president’s reckless actions make impeachment necessary,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi said, dressed in funereal black. “He gave us no choice.”

Following a day of ferocious debate, the House voted almost entirely along party lines, finding Mr Trump abused his power by pressing his Ukrainian counterpart to launch investigations into political rival Joe Biden and into debunked theories that Kyiv, rather than Russia, intervened in the 2016 US election. Lawmakers also passed a second article of impeachment accusing Mr Trump of obstructing Congress’s inquiry. Here’s a record of the votes — not a single Republican voted in favour.

It is highly unlikely that Mr Trump will be convicted and removed from office by the Republican-controlled Senate, where majority leader Mitch McConnell has already expressed his preference for a short hearing that will acquit the president and protect the party’s majority.

Here are the highlights of a historic day on Capitol Hill as well as our guide to Ukrainegate and a review of the most important witness testimonies. Finally, meet the impeachment tourists visiting Washington to witness the historic event. (FT, NYT, Politico)

In the news

Airbnb wins big legal victory in Europe
Europe’s top court has ruled that the home rental site Airbnb does not need to comply with the onerous regulations applied to property agents in the EU. In a rare sign of co-operation among Big Tech groups, Apple, Amazon and Google have formed an alliance to improve smart home devices in an effort to avoid a turf war. Meanwhile, the UK government will create a new technology regulator next year to police companies such as Facebook and Google after Brexit, according to several people involved in the process. (FT)

Queen’s Speech
Britain’s new legislative programme will be unveiled by the Queen on Thursday, in a ceremony stripped of some of its pomp. It will include bills to take Britain out of the EU by January 31 and improve public funding for the National Health Service. Here are the key Brexit dates ahead. Meanwhile, Emily Thornberry, shadow foreign secretary, became the first candidate to formally enter the Labour leadership race. (FT)

WorldCom chief released
The former chief executive of WorldCom was granted early release from prison on Wednesday, 13 years into a 25-year sentence in consideration of his declining health. Bernard Ebbers came to symbolise an era of corporate corruption for orchestrating an $11bn accounting fraud that was then the largest in US history. (FT)

Warren Buffett’s power company under fire for coal plant closures
PacifiCorp, an electric utility owned by Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, is facing criticism for accelerating plans to install wind turbines, solar panels and battery storage, while retiring coal-fired generators in the US west. Wyoming, which mines 40 per cent of US coal, has launched an investigation into the company’s plan. (FT)

White House agrees to cheaper drug imports from Canada
The Trump administration has laid out a plan that would allow certain drugs to be imported from Canada, where they can cost a third to a tenth of US list prices. Announcing the plan alongside the governor of Florida, a swing state where healthcare costs are particularly important because of its large population of retirees, the health and human services secretary Alex Azar said it was a “really historic day for healthcare”. (FT)

BoE pressers hacked
The Bank of England has acknowledged that high-speed traders were able to listen in on market-sensitive press conferences before they were officially broadcast after one of its suppliers hacked into its systems. The UK’s financial watchdog has launched an investigation into the claims. (FT)

India deal drawn into Wirecard scandal
The FT has published its latest investigation into Wirecard, the German technology company. It examines allegations of “round tripping”, where sales and profits are faked by sending money to a third party, who then uses it to buy services from the sender, and poses a simple question: why did the German company agree to pay around €300m for an Indian business only weeks after it changed hands for €37m? Read more on the investigation here. (FT)

India bans New Delhi demonstrations
India has banned demonstrations in New Delhi and shut down mobile networks across the country as authorities struggle to contain protests against a new citizenship bill. Police have made hundreds of arrests since protests erupted last week after Narendra Modi’s government passed a new citizenship law that critics say marginalises Muslims and violates the constitution of the world’s largest democracy. This is a profile of Amit Shah, Mr Modi’s right-hand man. (FT)

Bolivia issues arrest warrant for Evo Morales
Prosecutors in Bolivia have issued an arrest warrant for former president Evo Morales, accusing him of “sedition, terrorism and the financing of terrorism” in the turbulent weeks following his resignation in October and his escape to Mexico. (FT)

Moral Money

Ultra-wealthy families are turning up the heat on Wall Street banks that finance fossil fuels, while Aon, Mercer and Willis Towers Watson are stepping up their fight against greenwashing. The failed climate talks at COP25, meanwhile, are creating confusion for aviation carbon pricing schemes. Read the latest edition of Moral Money and sign-up here.

The day ahead

Democrats debate
Seven US Democrats vying for the party’s presidential nomination will battle it out on Thursday in a sixth televised debate. Edward Luce writes that none of the candidates shows much promise for uniting a disparate base. Ed and Rana Foroohar discuss money and power in Trump’s America in our Swamp Notes newsletter.   Sign up here. (Vox, FT)

Putin’s annual presser
Vladimir Putin holds his annual marathon news conference on Thursday, a largely stage-managed affair that could offer clues on Ukraine policy following a ceasefire and prisoner exchange. Mr Putin will probably face questions on   sluggish economic growth and Russia’s four-year ban from international sporting events. (RFE/RL, FT, Bloomberg)

FT Seasonal Appeal

The FT travelled to Mongolia, the centre for trafficking of rare wildlife that is threatening the survival of native species such as the marmot, snow leopard and Gobi bear as well as the balance of the wider ecosystem.

This year, the FT’s Seasonal Appeal partner is the Zoological Society of London, an international conservation charity that helps combat animal poaching in more than 50 countries. FT editor Lionel Barber explains why we chose to work with ZSL to help fight the $23bn-a-year illegal trade in wildlife.

Learn more here, and donate to the campaign   here.

What else we’re reading

FT Person of the Year
Satya Nadella, chief executive officer of Microsoft, has earned a unique place among the tech barons who preside over today’s digital landscape. The growing wealth and power of Big Tech has been a defining feature of modern capitalism. Yet even judged by those standards, Mr Nadella, the third chief executive in Microsoft’s history, stands out. (FT)

Realpolitik for post-Brexit Britain
Britain has spent much of the past 75 years struggling to avoid adjusting its international ambitions to diminished economic circumstance. The shock of Brexit may provide just the impetus needed, Philip Stephens writes. As the BBC braces for a funding battle with Boris Johnson’s government, here are some of Downing Street’s guerrilla tactics. The FT View is that a funding review of Britain’s public broadcaster should not be a tool of intimidation. (FT)

The changing face of economics
A chance meeting between the Nobel winning economist Robert Solow and photographer Mariana Cook led to collaboration that resulted in this portrait collection of leading economists. Tim Harford, who started writing his economics column for the FT in 2005, reviews the book and assesses how the discipline is meeting the sizeable challenges of the 21st century. (FT)

The art market is bananas
The sale of a piece of fruit for $120,000 is a symptom of a world untethered from reality, writes Rachel Spence, after collectors bought an artwork of an overripe banana duct-taped to a wall entitled “Comedian” by Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan. (FT)

An ode to the Post-it
Which wholly analogue office product is universal in technology companies the world over? While staplers and carbon paper may be unknown to those under 35, the Post-it Note seems to be sole survivor of 1980s offices still going strong. (FT)

India & Globalisation
Narendra Modi’s election in 2014 was supposed to usher in the most economically liberalising government since the 1990s. But it has not turned out that way, Alan Beattie writes. The country is missing an opportunity to boost its tourism sector by neglecting historic sites, argues Amy Kazmin. Read more in our Special Report: India & Globalisation. (FT)

Dutch dilemma
The Netherlands has centuries of experience managing water. But the unprecedented rise in sea levels is forcing the government to figure out how to keep one of the world’s richest countries from disappearing into the North Sea. Not every low-lying region will make it. (Politico)

China’s vast surveillance network This report looks inside China’s vast spying network, which includes phone scanning and facial recognition. It is one of the world’s biggest surveillance networks and is aimed at regular people, giving the police huge powers. (NYT)

Video of the day

Mexico’s migrant crackdown
FT Central America correspondent Jude Webber travels to the Mexico-Guatemala border to meet migrants desperate to make it to the US and the smugglers profiting from their pain. Has President Andrés Manuel López Obrador turned his country into a “border wall”? (FT)

China has formally approved a plan to impose a draconian new national security law on Hong Kong, a day after the US declared such a move wou... China has formally approved a plan to impose a draconian new national security law on Hong Kong, a day after the US declared such a move would signal that the...

China has formally approved a plan to impose a draconian new national security law on Hong Kong, a day after the US declared such a move wou... China has formally approved a plan to impose a draconian new national security law on Hong Kong, a day after the US declared such a move would signal that the...

China has formally approved a plan to impose a draconian new national security law on Hong Kong, a day after the US declared such a move wou...

China has formally approved a plan to impose a draconian new national security law on Hong Kong, a day after the US declared such a move would signal that the city was no longer autonomous from Beijing.

Mike Pompeo, the US secretary of state, said on Wednesday: “No reasonable person can assert today that Hong Kong maintains a high degree of autonomy from China, given facts on the ground.”

The comments from Mr Pompeo are the most serious response yet from Washington to Beijing’s decision last week to impose the new law on the territory.

The law, which was passed by the 2,885 lawmakers on Thursday, with just one dissenter and six abstentions, has raised concerns about the    territory’s future as a financial centre and highlighted how the city has found itself on the frontline of escalating tensions between Washington and Beijing.

It has also reignited protests in the city after a hiatus during the coronavirus epidemic. Hundreds were arrested on Wednesday in Hong Kong’s central business and main shopping districts.

But businesses are resigned to the new law. The Financial Times’ reporters spoke to several executives working in professional services in Hong Kong, including law firms and banks, both global and Chinese-owned.

“Do people here like the national security law?” said one senior lawyer at a global law firm in Hong Kong. “It’s like asking, ‘Do people like bitter medicine with terrible side-effects?’ The medicine will hurt for sure but we have no choice but to take it now.”

Jamil Anderlini, our Asia editor, writes that China’s leaders have decided that stamping out dissent in the territory is more important than preserving its status as Asia’s premier financial centre. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

The US coronavirus death toll topped 100,000, according to Johns Hopkins University. These are   some of the victims.

The UK has suffered the highest rate of deaths from coronavirus among countries with comparable data, according to a Financial Times analysis of excess mortality.

GlaxoSmithKline is to produce 1bn doses of a vaccine adjuvant to help in the fight against Covid-19. Merck is testing an   “error catastrophe” treatment that forces the virus to self-destruct.

Young people are bearing the brunt of the hit to employment: more than one in six who were previously working have stopped, new research showed. (FT, NYT)

Live Q&A: Go behind the scenes of the US coronavirus response with the FT’s Demetri Sevastopulo, Andrew Edgecliffe-Johnson and Laura Noonan on Thursday, March 28.

In the news

Exclusive:Fed holds firepower Only a fraction of the Federal Reserve’s multitrillion-dollar emergency lending facilities have been deployed. The promise to buy risky assets ranging from junk bonds to local government debt was a key plank of the Fed’s effort to stabilise markets and boost the US economy. In its Beige Book, an anecdotal assessment of economic conditions from the regional US reserve banks published on Wednesday, the Fed said US economic activity fell   “sharply” heading into May. (FT)

US relaxes rules for opioid substitutes Before coronavirus hit, addiction to opioids was seen by many as the biggest public health crisis in the US. But while lockdowns have made life harder for addicts in many ways, those working in addiction therapy say new rules governing addiction treatments such as methadone could encourage more people to seek treatment. (FT)

Boeing to axe 12,000 US jobs The voluntary and involuntary lay-offs will start this week and are part of efforts to reduce the aircraft manufacturer’s 160,000-strong workforce by 10 per cent. EasyJet, a UK-based low cost airline, announced on Thursday it would   cut 4,500 jobs or 30 per cent of its workforce. (FT)

Ackman dumps Berkshire Hathaway stake Bill Ackman said his hedge fund could seize opportunities faster than his mentor Warren Buffett’s sprawling conglomerate, explaining the decision to shed a stake worth 10 per cent of Pershing Square’s assets under management. (FT)

Big Tech’s M&A spree Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft have announced 19 deals this year, the fastest pace of acquisitions since 2015 despite heightened regulatory scrutiny. Rival factions on   WeWork’s board are heading for a showdown over a vote on Friday. (FT)

Huawei CFO loses bidto dismiss extradition request A Canadian court has denied an attempt by Meng Wanzhou, Huawei chief financial officer, to dismiss an extradition request from the US, where she faces allegations of fraud. (FT)

Departure delayed SpaceX’s attempt to become the first private company to lift humans into orbit was delayed by weather with less than 17 minutes to go on Wednesday; the mission was postponed to Saturday. Separately,   a Japanese billionaire set to be the company’s first space tourist may have been grounded by a terrestrial foe: the taxman. (FT)

March ructions deter bullion banks Big bullion banks have pulled back from gold futures after being stung by coronavirus-fuelled market disruption, which cost HSBC a $200m paper loss in a single day. Goldman Sachs delayed its   digital wealth management platform to 2021, citing the need to act “prudently”. (FT)

Asia’s huge semiconductor industry is being remoulded as the US crackdown on Huawei causes a cascade of consequences. Read more in   Tech Scroll Asia — sign up   here.

The day ahead

US unemployment New jobless claims for the week ending May 18 are forecast to total about 2.1m, bringing the total since the pandemic hit to more than 40m. Also on Thursday, the revision of first-quarter GDP is released along with durable goods orders as well as pending home sales. (FT)

Trump threatens Twitter over fact-check Donald Trump plans to sign an executive order on social media companies a day after threatening to shut down Twitter. The row between the president and Twitter was triggered by the social media platform’s decision   to place a fact-check warning on some of his tweets earlier this week. Twitter must tread a delicate path in dealing with the president, writes   the FT editorial board. (FT, Reuters)

The Financial Times is launching a new newsletter,  Scoreboard, to follow the money and deals behind the business of sport.    Sign up here.

What else we’re reading

Trump is courting a landslide defeat Most of the polling, including the Trump campaign’s own numbers, show him heading for defeat in November. Common sense points the same way. But two things could prevent that outcome, writes Edward Luce. (FT)

Insuring for a second wave Insurers say coronavirus will be one of the most expensive events in their history, potentially costing more than $200bn. But thousands of businesses still face ruin. Amid outcry from customers and politicians, the industry is turning attention to the next crisis — which may be only months away. (FT)

Lessons from a pandemic The Covid-19 pandemic represents a tragedy for its victims and their families and economic hardship for many. Yet it might usher in an age of global co-operation, the Pulitzer Prize-winning geographer Jared Diamond writes — depending on how we react. (FT)

How is Ethiopia beating Covid-19? With no lockdown and few ventilators, Ethiopia has harnessed community healthcare to great effect. To stem the pandemic, we must find today’s   superspreading “Typhoid Marys”, Anjana Ahuja says. Despite Taiwan’s virus success, the country remains   plagued by political isolation. (FT)

WFH poses challenges As the NYSE trading floor reopens, the benefits of remote working are once again being weighed — but there is another, more subtle problem, Gillian Tett writes. The challenges aren’t just technological,   they’re managerial. (FT, New Yorker)

Keeping the doors open As China’s Hubei province locked down in January, frantic efforts were made to keep Reckitt Benckiser’s second-largest Dettol plant running. With disinfectant sales soaring, the group ramped up daily production tenfold. (FT)

Brexiters still do not understand Europe After jilting its long-term partners, Boris Johnson’s government still struggles to grasp why it cannot retain matrimonial privileges. The underlying assumption remains that the UK is “owed” privileged access, Philip Stephens writes. (FT)

Lockdown in luxury For some, the experience of the pandemic has been rather different: superyacht brokers are reporting a surge in charter inquiries, as the wealthy look to travel while minimising human contact. (FT)

Podcast of the day

Behind the Money When Carlyle Group executives signed an agreement with American Express Global Business Travel in December they imagined it would be one of the private equity firm’s most enduring deals. Now, Carlyle is trying to walk away from that deal before any money changes hands. Our US private capital correspondent, Mark Vandevelde, reports on the ensuing legal row, and what it could mean for dealmaking during the pandemic.

Mark tells the Behind the Money podcast: “If in this crisis we get a lot of behaviour that is rational but people think of as having quite a narrow investment horizon, then it may be a very long time before people believe again these Wall Street players’ promises of long-term partnerships.” (FT)

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

The economic costs of China’s coronavirus outbreak mounted on Wednesday as multinational companies were forced to halt operations in the worst affected areas.

British Airways and Starbucks became the latest businesses to respond to the deepening health crisis, which has now claimed 132 lives and infected nearly 6,000.

The company warnings came as the first evacuations of foreign nationals from Wuhan, the city of 11m at the centre of the outbreak, began. A chartered ANA flight carried 206 Japanese citizens out of the city, while a US flight departed earlier on Wednesday carrying government staff and civilians. Other countries, including Britain, Germany and Italy, have said they plan evacuations. Australia announced plans to quarantine its evacuated citizens on Christmas Island.

Thousands of foreigners remain trapped in the stricken city. Divyank Parekh, a 20-year-old from India studying at the Wuhan University School of Medicine, told one of our reporters: “We’re very worried because we see people getting ill around us.”

Meanwhile, British Airways suspended all flights to and from mainland China on Wednesday and more than a billion dollars was wiped off the value of Hong Kong airline Cathay Pacific, as its shares traded for the first time following the lunar new year break.

US coffee chain Starbucks closed more than 2,000 outlets in China and warned its annual financial results had been threatened by the virus. KFC, Pizza Hut and McDonald’s have also closed outlets in China. The impact is also being felt in the technology sector. Apple, which released record earnings on Tuesday (more on this below), warned of the virus’s “potential impact” on this quarter’s results. Separately, US officials scotched the idea of US commerce secretary Wilbur Ross visiting China.

How dangerous is the virus? Science editor Clive Cookson answers this and other questions, including whether face masks are effective. (FT, ABC)

In the news

Republicans push to block impeachment witnesses
Senate Republican leaders piled pressure on their colleagues on Tuesday night to block witnesses appearing in Donald Trump’s impeachment trial amid indications that a small group of moderates wanted to hear from former national security adviser John Bolton. Donald Trump’s lawyers wrapped up the impeachment trial’s opening arguments with an impassioned defence of the US president. Today begins a new phase in the trial, which will see senators asking questions about the case. Here’s an inside look at the opposing legal teams. Do you think John Bolton should be subpoenaed to testify in the trial? Have your say in our latest   poll. (FT, NYT)

Apple books record profit
The iPhone maker reported one of the biggest quarterly profits in the fourth quarter for any company, with revenues rising 9 per cent to $91.8bn, buoying a stock price that has more than doubled in the past year. Shares in eBay fell more than 5 per cent on a disappointing earnings outlook that blamed US state internet sales taxes. (FT)

Trump’s Middle East plan
Donald Trump said his Arab-Israeli peace plan laid the foundations for “a realistic two-state solution”, but the scheme would require Palestinians to relinquish critical negotiating positions. Israel will vote on Sunday on annexing settlements considered illegal under international law. Benjamin Netanyahu was indicted on corruption charges, meaning the Israeli PM could face trial before standing for re-election on March 2. (FT, WaPo)

EU 5G plan allows member states to decide
The 27 countries in the EU will ultimately hold responsibility for deciding whether to allow Huawei access to critical parts of their 5G communications networks under a new plan. The EU proposal largely mimics the UK strategy to exclude equipment from high-risk vendors from the sensitive “core” of a network. The Trump administration considers the UK decision a craven surrender of national sovereignty that could strain the US-UK “special relationship”.

Nissan’s ‘invisible’ chief
Just two months into his tenure, Nissan’s chief executive Makoto Uchida is facing doubts from insiders who say the carmaker needs decisive leadership to heal the wounds with French alliance partner Renault, which  named Luca de Meo as its chief executive. Nissan is also planning aggressive cost cuts to deal with an unexpected sales fall. (FT, Reuters)

Bolivia’s interim leader shows interest in top job
After becoming Bolivia’s caretaker president Jeanine Áñez said it would be “dishonest” to run for the office. Now she has changed her mind. In an interview with the Financial Times she said: “I am here to continue the process and to ensure that this vote is not dispersed and to take care of democracy, take care of everything that the Bolivian people fought for.” (FT)

Harvard chemist’s China links
Prosecutors have charged the chair of Harvard University’s chemistry department with failing to disclose alleged income from the Chinese government. British trader Navinder Singh Sarao, who was implicated in the 2010 stock market “flash crash”, avoided further jail time as his sentencing on Tuesday closed a years-long legal drama. (FT)

The day ahead

Goldman Sachs’ investor day
The Wall Street stalwart holds its first-ever investor day on Wednesday. Goldman’s growing consumer business, shareholder returns and investment in technology will be in the spotlight after more than a decade of lagging behind rivals such as JPMorgan Chase. Don’t miss this deep-dive on chief executive David Solomon’s radical overhaul. (Barron’s, FT)

Federal Reserve meets
The Federal Reserve is unlikely to change its federal-funds rate at the end of its first meeting of the year on Wednesday. But investors will seek clarity from chairman Jay Powell about the size of the Fed's balance sheet. Market Questions has more on this week’s central bank meetings. Does the Fed have a communication problem? Our News in Focus podcast attempts to answer that question. (FT)

Boeing earnings
The 737 Max grounding forced Boeing to take a more than $5bn charge last year to pay compensation to airlines. Analysts expect that figure to increase on Wednesday when Boeing reports fourth-quarter and full-year earnings. Peggy Hollinger writes that Boeing’s travails run deeper than a few bad apples. Facebook, Tesla and Microsoft also report on Wednesday. (FT, Yahoo)

Sign-up to Trade Secrets

Trade Secrets is turning its attention to a historic impasse that last year spiralled quickly out of control, threatening not only global tech supply chains but also the region’s security alliances: the dispute between South Korea and Japan. Sign up to receive   Trade Secrets, our must-read daily briefing on the changing face of international trade and globalisation.

What else we’re reading

Punishment to fit white collar crime
The US has experimented with astronomical corporate fines, which regulators say will hit executives, whose bonuses are often tied to earnings and share price, and encourage boards to be more vigilant. But critics argue that such fines hurt investors twice. (FT)

Britain after Brexit will be lonelier
Britain is going its own way in a world ruled by superpowers. Never in my lifetime has a British government been so determined to inflict economic damage on its own people, Martin Wolf writes. Northern Ireland dominated the first phase of Brexit talks, but new tensions are looming over Irish Sea trade checks. (FT)

EU citizens are showing post-Brexit fears. Sign up here to our Brexit Briefing newsletter for the latest.

Stagflation looms over India and China
The two nations have been hit by a surge in consumer prices that, together with a slowdown in growth, has sparked fears of “stagflation” in the world’s most populous countries. If the Asian powerhouses were to be overtaken by rising prices in a stagnant economy, it would pose a grave threat to global growth. (FT)

Saracens’ guide to winning
Executives love to look to the sports world for leadership gurus. Saracens, the London rugby union club, tapped into the demand with an executive management course, “The Saracens Way”. But the team’s success was built less on values such as “honesty”, “discipline” and “humility” than on acquiring the best players — and to do so, multimillionaire owner Nigel Wray broke the rules. (FT)

Trapped in Tehran
In July 2019, Middle East correspondent Nicolas Pelham received a rare journalist’s visa to Iran. But on the day he was due to fly home, he was detained, interrogated for three days and prevented from leaving the country for seven weeks. (Economist)

German fears of Big Tech
When Steve Jobs returned to Apple in 1997, it was valued at $3bn, less than one-tenth of Siemens, Europe’s largest industrial group then and now. Today, Apple is worth more than Germany’s 30 leading companies — a striking example of how Europe’s largest economy risks being left behind by the tech boom. (FT)

Special Report: Future of the Connected City
Now that our online data has been comprehensively mined, Big Tech is coming for our faces. Whereas there has long been some compunction on UK and US police forces to destroy DNA and fingerprint samples from those not charged with any crimes, no such rules apply to our faces. But artists, designers and activists have been developing tools to stymie facial recognition software. Read more in the Future of the Connected City special report. (FT)

How to stop time
As the world seemed to be getting busier and faster, writer Mark O’Connell wanted a timeout. So he walked into the woods and did absolutely nothing for 24 hours. He found the encounter with the passage of the time unexpectedly cathartic. (Guardian)

Tech Scroll Asia

China’s tech supply chain is already facing disruptions from the coronavirus outbreak, with Apple’s ambitious iPhone production targets at risk. The US thinks the UK’s limited acceptance of Huawei is a “craven surrender”, while Foxconn founder Terry Gou is back at the helm. Read more in this week’s Tech Scroll Asia, your guide to the billions made and lost in Asia tech.

We’re offering a free 30-day trial to Tech Scroll Asia, which includes complimentary access to the Financial Times. Sign up here.

Podcast of the day

The Rachman Review
“Let’s just get out of there” is not a strategy: General John Allen, head of the Brookings Institution and former Nato forces commander, talks to Gideon Rachman about the importance of clear objectives in the Middle East and Afghanistan. (FT)

\tSaudi Arabia and Russia ended their oil price war on Sunday, finalising a deal to make the biggest oil production cuts in history followin... \tSaudi Arabia and Russia ended their oil price war on Sunday, finalising a deal to make the biggest oil production cuts in history following pressure from Donald Trump to support the ravaged energy...

\tSaudi Arabia and Russia ended their oil price war on Sunday, finalising a deal to make the biggest oil production cuts in history followin... \tSaudi Arabia and Russia ended their oil price war on Sunday, finalising a deal to make the biggest oil production cuts in history following pressure from Donald Trump to support the ravaged energy...

\tSaudi Arabia and Russia ended their oil price war on Sunday, finalising a deal to make the biggest oil production cuts in history followin...

\tSaudi Arabia and Russia ended their oil price war on Sunday, finalising a deal to make the biggest oil production cuts in history following pressure from Donald Trump to support the ravaged energy sector.

Opec said it would cut 9.7m barrels a day in May and June, equivalent to almost 10 per cent of global supply, with smaller reductions until April 2022. The cuts would be more than twice those made by the cartel during the global financial crisis.

Mr Trump welcomed the announcement, saying it would protect US jobs.  Crude prices rose in reaction, but remained at historically depressed levels.

But Mexico has resisted pressure to cut output alongside larger producers, as President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has made state oil company Pemex a political priority. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

The US death toll overtook Italy's on Sunday, becoming the first country to record more than  20,000 deaths, nearly 19 per cent of the global total. White House divisions, lack of planning and   Donald Trump’s faith in his own instincts slowed the US response.

Coronavirus latest: Asian equities and US futures slip ahead of earnings season.

Germany’s oversupply of hospital beds, bemoaned for years by politicians and health economists, has proven a boon.

Boris Johnson was discharged from hospital on Sunday as the UK’s death toll exceeded 10,000. Thousands of patients will be   “scored” to ration treatment during the outbreak’s impending peak. 

More than 750 Qantas employees have been ordered to self-isolate owing to a large coronavirus cluster at Australia’s Adelaide airport. (FT, Times UK, NYT)

The FT View tackles the dos and don’ts of wearing a face mask. Follow our   coronavirus tracker and our   live coverage here. 

We’ve launched a  Telegram channel to help you find the important and free-to-read stories from our global network of reporters.    Sign up here.

In the news

US bank earnings America’s biggest lenders report first-quarter earnings this week, with analysts having already cut profit forecasts for   asset managers after the March sell-off. (FT)

G20 debt deal The G20 group is planning to offer lower income countries a moratorium on bilateral loan repayments as part of an “action plan” to stave off an emerging markets debt crisis. A Brookings-FT tracking index shows the global economy was   facing the worst collapse since the second world war in March, well before the height of the coronavirus crisis. (FT)

New York struggles to bury its coronavirus dead
Just as coronavirus has threatened to overwhelm New York’s healthcare system with a surge of patients, it is also taxing its “deathcare” system, clogging the morgues, cemeteries and funeral homes. (FT)

MBA students’ refund demand
MBA students at some of the world’s leading business schools are demanding a refund on their tuition fees as compensation for campus closures and the switch to what they view as inferior online learning. (FT)

Margrethe Vestager urges stakebuilding European countries should buy stakes in companies to stave off Chinese takeovers, the EU competition chief told the Financial Times, as Brussels steps up protection for businesses during the pandemic. (FT)

Israel’s uncertainty Israel’s president on Sunday denied a request from Benjamin Netanyahu’s rival Benny Gantz for more time to form a government, raising the prospect of a fourth national election.   Mossad, Israel’s intelligence agency, has played an outsize role in acquiring medical gear to fight coronavirus. (Reuters, NYT)

Boeing under ecclesiastical pressure  US friars and nuns are pushing Boeing to disclose more about its lobbying practices, accusing the aerospace manufacturer of being “disingenuous” in a filing with US regulators.\t   Aeroplane emissions fell by almost a third last month, according to an FT analysis. (FT)

Argentina’s impending debt default Argentina is heading for its ninth sovereign debt default, analysts have warned, with increasingly frustrated investors set to reject the government’s debt restructuring offer. (FT)

Assange fathered children in embassy The WikiLeaks founder fathered two children with a lawyer who was representing him while he was holed up in Ecuador’s embassy in London, the lawyer said. (Reuters)

An Easter like no other St Peter’s Square, normally thronged with visitors on Easter Sunday, was instead ringed by police barricades, as the Pope’s address was delivered inside the basilica. (FT)

The days ahead

Wisconsin election results The results of Wisconsin’s April 7 ballot, which included the Democratic presidential primary, will be announced on Monday. (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel)

European lockdown reviewsAfter a month of tightening lockdowns across Europe to combat coronavirus, Austria, the Czech Republic and Denmark will in the coming weeks become the first European countries to loosen restrictions on daily life and business. Britain’s three-week lockdown is expected to be   extended. (FT)

What else we’re reading

Simon Schama: what history tells us of plague While epidemics differ in their origins, virulence and duration, and while our understanding of how they arise and are carried has changed dramatically over the centuries, to a remarkable degree the social danse macabre has stayed much the same. (FT)

Crisis revives Franco-German relations The EU’s engine has sprung back to life as  Paris and Berlin, working in tandem, saved a €500bn eurozone rescue package. More than any other European leader, France’s   Emmanuel Macron has cast himself as a commander in the fight against the pandemic. (FT, Politico)

Crash course in survival As businesses strain to survive the coronavirus crisis, Mohsin Meghji has a simple message: the first battle is about attitude. “A lot of companies are not used to living poor,” said the founder of M-III partners, a New York-based consultancy focused on financially distressed companies. (FT)

Holiday headache Having drawn up team holiday rotas, Pilita Clark knows it always required the skills both of a Nobel-winning diplomat and a butcher. It is difficult to imagine how much harder that task is now. Andrew Hill recalls    William Wordsworth’s wisdom for the benefit of stressed out home workers. (FT) 

WeWork’s lessons for US real estate The company’s troubles hint of what is to come — a long period of falling property prices in global cities,  writes Rana Foroohar. (FT)

Being happy in lockdown “It’s not pretty out there. But here is the question: from the bubble of my privileged house with its private garden where the tulip bulbs get fatter every day in the spring sunshine, is it acceptable to feel happy?”  asks Lucy Kellaway. (FT)

Investment management - the weak link? A coronavirus recession will probably be very different to the financial crisis a dozen years ago. The banking sector looks healthy, but analysts and investors warn that risks have migrated into the multi-faceted, less-regulated investment industry. Meanwhile, banks should not be shamed into a   do-gooder lending binge. (FT)


Looking for a Job? Big Tech is hiring As millions across the US lose their jobs,  well-capitalised tech companies such as Apple and Google are looking to scoop them up — especially skilled workers who had been gravitating to smaller start-ups, recruiters say. Here’s    who else is hiring (and firing). (Wall Street Journal) 

Fall of the roaming empire Global telecoms groups face losing $25bn in revenue from  data roaming charges as international travel collapses. Coronavirus has exposed   America’s broadband problem: poor access in rural areas. (FT)

50 years of garden writing for the FT A long marriage takes two, says Robin Lane Fox, who has been writing a gardening column since 1970. The FT has given him the cue and the time to see more, try more, hear more and improve. And he has no plans to stop. (FT)

In defence of male vanity Crises expose the way we have been living.  The rise of male vanity has been documented well enough but it has taken the lockdown to show how central it has become to our habits and our egos, writes Janan Ganesh. (FT) 

Video of the day

Lockdown lunches: how to bake the best bread With restaurants closed and millions indoors, we are going to have to get back to home-cooking. Food writer Tim Hayward shows the FT’s Daniel Garrahan how to bake the perfect loaf. (FT)

The Paris-based OECD on Monday became the first international organisation to sound the alarm about coronavirus, saying the outbreak puts the global economy “at...

The Paris-based OECD on Monday became the first international organisation to sound the alarm about coronavirus, saying the outbreak puts the global economy “at...

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.The Paris-based OECD on Monday became the first international organisati...

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

The Paris-based OECD on Monday became the first international organisation to sound the alarm about coronavirus, saying the outbreak puts the global economy “at risk” of falling into recession.

Stock markets in Asia and Europe, however, rallied on Monday, after suffering their worst week since the 2008 financial crisis, on hopes central banks would intervene to stimulate growth.

In an emergency statement as markets opened on Monday morning, the Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda promised to inject liquidity into markets and hinted at raising asset purchases. The statement by Mr Kuroda followed a highly unusual and significant intervention from Jay Powell, chairman of the Federal Reserve. He said on Friday the US central bank would “act as appropriate” to support growth, suggesting it was ready to cut interest rates at its next meeting on March 17-18. The Bank of England said it was working with UK regulators and other central banks “to ensure all necessary steps are taken to protect financial and monetary stability” as calls grow for policymakers to intervene.

Elsewhere, Italy is to inject €3.6bn into its economy to mitigate the impact of the largest outbreak of coronavirus in Europe. Roberto Gualtieri, Italy’s economy minister, said on Sunday the government would introduce tax credits for companies that reported a 25 per cent drop in revenues, as well as tax cuts and extra cash for the health system. Bruno Le Maire, France’s finance minister, warned that the hit to the French economy would be “much more significant” than the 0.1 per cent forecast when the Covid-19 outbreak was restricted to mainland China.

In Asia, China’s factory activity plunged to an all-time low in February, according to data released on Saturday. In other developments over the weekend Mike Pence, the US vice-president, authorised state health officials to close schools if necessary to contain the coronavirus as President Donald Trump announced new travel restrictions as two people died of the virus over the weekend.

Follow our live coverage here and the latest figures on the outbreak, which has now killed more than 3,000. (FT)

In other developments:

The European Commission is holding an emergency news conference in Brussels to update on its coronavirus planning. The bloc’s public health warning has been upgraded from “low to moderate” to “moderate to high”.

Iran’s health ministry said the number of people who had died from the virus rose to 66 on Monday and the number of those infected had breached 1,500.

Indonesia has confirmed its first coronavirus cases, a 64-year-old woman and her 31-year-old daughter. Both patients had been in contact with a Japanese national who tested positive in Malaysia, President Joko Widodo told reporters on Monday.

South Korea is investigating a religious sect at the centre of the country’s outbreak. (FT)

Further reading:

What should macro policymakers do about the coronavirus

Rana Foroohar: Corporate margins are going to be squeezed

China’s coronavirus ‘red guards’ revive painful memories

FT View: Coronavirus unmasks the vulnerability of the bull run

Gideon Rachman: How coronavirus is changing global politics

Coronavirus may create lasting workplace change

Charts that matter: Shipping costs provide clues on damage wrought by coronavirus

Sign up here to   Market Forces, Mike Mackenzie’s daily analysis of what’s moving markets.

In the news

Biden rises, Buttigieg exits
An emphatic win in South Carolina on Saturday has rescued Joe Biden but Super Tuesday looms, with a third of delegates in play. Market Questions asks what Super Tuesday means for investors, while this graphic has the current standing of each candidate ahead of tomorrow’s crucial contests. Rana Foroohar argues that it is still too early to predict who is going to win the nomination, despite Mr Sanders’ convincing poll lead. Who do you think will win the Democratic nomination. Have your say in our latest poll. (FT)

Elliott targets Twitter
Activist hedge fund Elliott Management has privately submitted four nominees for Twitter’s board and is pushing for the removal of Jack Dorsey after taking a more than $1bn stake. The UK’s Competition and Markets Authority is the most aggressive antitrust enforcer worldwide, new figures reveal. (FT)

Turkey declares Syria offensive
Brussels has called an emergency meeting of EU foreign ministers as Turkey’s escalating conflict with the Syrian regime risks creating a new refugee crisis. Recep Tayyip Erdogan over the weekend said he had “opened the gates” to the EU for 4m as hundreds of refugees amassed at Turkey’s border with Greece. (FT)

Deutsche Bank warned
The UK financial regulator has criticised Deutsche Bank for not improving anti-money laundering and compliance controls, demanding monthly rather than quarterly updates and warning failure could jeopardise post-Brexit access. (FT)

Slovakia’s election
The Ordinary People anti-corruption movement, whose slogan is “Let’s beat the mafia together”, won a resounding victory in Saturday’s parliamentary elections. Self-made millionaire Igor Matovic, poised to become prime minister, tapped into public anger with the long-ruling leftwing Smer party. (FT)

UK’s Galileo rival delayed
Britain’s plan for a sovereign satellite navigation system— pushed by the government as a symbol of post-Brexit independence after the UK was shut out of the EU’s £10bn Galileo programme — has been delayed for at least six months amid conflicts over the scope and cost of the multibillion-pound project. (FT)

US hails Afghanistan deal
The Trump administration hailed a peace deal with the Afghan Taliban, which commits allied forces to withdraw all troops within 14 months, as the first significant step towards ending America’s longest running war. But the deal has already hit a roadblock over the release of thousands of Taliban prisoners. (FT, AP)

Google parent invents fish recognition system
The advanced research lab at Google’s parent company Alphabet, best known for its work on self-driving cars, internet balloons and delivery drones, has invented a system that will eventually recognise and monitor every individual fish kept in farms. The three-year-old project, dubbed Tidal, is working with fish farms in Europe and Asia to pair underwater cameras with AI techniques to track species, including salmon. (FT)

The day ahead

UK-EU trade talks
Britain and the EU finally begin mammoth talks in Brussels on Monday covering nearly every aspect of their future relationship. The FT View is that Britain’s bellicose position is not as hardline as it seems, but Wolfgang Münchau writes that the UK’s threat to walk out in June is real. The UK also publishes US trade objectives on Monday. (FT)

Israel’s election
Israel holds a nationwide election on Monday, its third in less than a year, and one few believe will yield a decisive victory for either Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu or rival Benny Gantz. A loss would leave Israel’s four-time premier unprotected when his trial on corruption charges begins on March 17. (FT)

Keep up with the important business, economic and political stories in the coming days with the FT’s Week Ahead. Click to subscribe   here. And don’t miss our FT News Briefing podcast — a short daily rundown of the top global stories.

What else we’re reading

Why Sanders and Warren scare Big Tech but thrill its workers
Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren have received the most donations from employees at California’s largest technology companies ahead of the crucial Super Tuesday primary contest, according to an FT analysis of Federal Election Commission data. Donations to 2020 presidential candidates from employees of the state’s most prominent tech firms totalled $1.1m by the end of January 2020 in the Golden State, the biggest prize of the 14 states which vote on Super Tuesday. (FT)

EU banks’ rise and dramatic fall
When HSBC interim chief Noel Quinn announced a dramatic overhaul last month, he took aim at a familiar target for European banks: the US. Europe’s lenders spent billions to crack into America, but many have beat a humbling retreat following a two-decade acquisition spree. (FT)

VW’s electric ambitions
Volkswagen plans to produce 26m emission-free vehicles in the next nine years, leapfrogging Tesla as the world’s largest electric carmaker. But perhaps the most radical ambition is to generate profits almost from the get-go, defying dire industry-wide projections. Andrew Hill writes that VW is right to hire a young climate activist to challenge senior executives. (FT)

Find an anti-role model
The “inspiration” market is booming, but much of it frames work as a quasi-religious experience. We can learn more from the terrible bosses who show us the path to avoid, Emma Jacobs writes. (FT)

Hilary Mantel’s ‘The Mirror and the Light’
What does it take to restore the dead and their world to the land of the living? In The Mirror and the Light, the majestic and often breathtakingly poetic conclusion to her Cromwell trilogy, the author makes the nature of the past her great theme, Simon Schama writes. (FT)

Online MBA rankings 2020 Warwick Business School is number one in the   2020 Financial Times ranking of online MBAs, its third consecutive year in the top slot. The demand for online MBAs has grown in popularity since Aspen University in Denver introduced the first one in 1987. The coronavirus is creating new demand for online courses as university campuses shut down in response to the health crisis.

We need your help
FT Globetrotter, our new city guides, offer insider tips on London, Tokyo, New York, Frankfurt, Paris and Hong Kong, such as where to book a breakfast meeting, 5k running routes, top spots for after-work cocktails, and more. But we want to know if we’re on the right track. What is most important for you when you travel for work? What would you ideally like to do when an hour or an afternoon opens up? Tell us   here.

Video of the day

Why our oil addiction is not just about cars and planes
Cutting oil consumption is essential to reducing our carbon footprint. But switching to electric transport and cutting air travel won’t end our dependency. The FT’s senior energy correspondent Anjli Raval reveals how oil is also used to make plastic packaging, clothes, cosmetics and even medicines. (FT)
