How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz to find out.

Senate Republicans introduced legislation to inject more than $1tn of fiscal stimulus into the US economy as California ordered its 40m residents to stay at home unless required to make essential trips.

The proposal by Mitch McConnell, the Republican Senate majority leader, includes cheque payments for taxpayers of $1,200 per adult and $500 for every child, excluding the well paid.

The legislation also includes business-friendly labour provisions, capping employer payments at $10,000 for each employee on paid family and medical leave. It also imposes a cap of $5,110 on sick leave for adults, and $2,000 for staff who take leave from work to care for a child or person quarantined because of the virus.

But negotiations with congressional Democrats, who control the House of Representatives, and the White House could be testy. Democrats faulted the Republican plan for providing insufficient aid to workers as the economy rapidly sheds jobs.

As well as the massive stimulus package for US households and business, Donald Trump also said his government was open to taking equity stakes in companies as the economy grinds to a halt because of the pandemic.

The order by Gavin Newsom, governor of California, to all the state’s citizens is similar to lockdowns already introduced in Italy, Spain and France. It follows new advice from the Trump administration that US citizens should avoid all international travel. The US military has reluctantly begun to step in to aid the federal government’s coronavirus response.

Meanwhile, the US and Mexico are drafting plans to partially close their border, mirroring a shutdown of the Canadian border, likely to take effect on Friday.

Crises reveal character, and Mr Trump must learn to lead by example, Edward Luce writes. (FT)

Coronavirus business update  is your level-headed briefing on how the coronavirus epidemic is affecting the markets, global business, our workplaces and daily lives, with expert input from our reporters and specialists across the globe. Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Sign up here.

Coronavirus digest

UK chancellor Rishi Sunak will launch a massive rescue package on Friday after the Bank of England embarked on more monetary easing to prevent the coronavirus crisis spiralling out of control. Boris Johnson said the UK can “turn the tide” on coronavirus within the next three months, setting out new restrictions while holding back on a London lockdown.

Giuseppe Conte, Italy’s prime minister, demanded the EU use “the full firepower” of its €500bn rescue fund in an interview with the Financial Times, calling for emergency credit lines to countries. Divisions have again emerged within the European Central Bank over how far to take its “no limits” policy to protect the eurozone. Writing in the FT, ECB president Christine Lagarde explains the bank’s new pandemic programme.

Taiwan has accused the World Health Organization, from which it is excluded, of failing to communicate an early warning about human-to-human transmission.

Poor countries are still waiting on the World Bank’s specially designed “ pandemic bonds”, as some investors question whether they will pay out at all.

Here’s a look at the Imperial College coronavirus model, which projected 510,000 deaths in the UK and 2.2m in the US and has profoundly influenced public policy.

In order to track China’s slowdown and recovery, which has ramifications for the global economy, the FT has  constructed a China Economic Activity Index. Follow our  live coverage here. (FT, Reuters)

In the news

Market fallout
Fears that coronavirus will lead to widespread unemployment and a spike in consumer defaults have wiped more than two-thirds from the value of US credit card lenders, with executives contemplating cutting credit limits. Popular  hedge fund bets have been hammered, including by Millennium and Schonfeld. Two US senators, meanwhile, offloaded millions of dollars in stocks shortly before US markets crashed. (FT)

The search for a vaccine
Global pharma groups, including Roche, Sanofi and Johnson & Johnson, have promised to work together to try to find treatments and a vaccine. Swiss drugmaker Roche announced it was launching an FDA-approved trial for a potential new Covid-19 drug. Clinical trials in China of an anti-flu drug called Avigan suggest it appears to be an effective treatment for coronavirus. A US drugmaker with a potential coronavirus treatment touted by Donald Trump almost doubled its price in January as the virus caused havoc across China.

Ford borrows $15.4bn to manage plant shutdown
Ford suspended its dividend and drew down $15.4bn, the largest corporate withdrawal yet. JaguarLand Rover will close its UK plants until at least the week of April 20, leaving Volvo’s Swedish operations as the only significant car plant still operating in Europe. Tesla will “temporarily suspend” production at its main US facility, despite Elon Musk’s resistance.

British Airways pilots hit with 50% salary cut
British Airways pilots are to be hit with a 50 per cent pay cut to their salary for April and May. Lufthansa, the world’s second-largest airline, warned that it was likely to emerge as a smaller business. Airlines want to defer payments to Europe’s air traffic controllers, worth about €500m a month, as they battle a deepening cash crisis. What can Boeing buy with $60bn? The aerospace manufacturer has asked the US government for assistance after its shares fell 70 per cent in a month. (FT)

Oil price enjoys biggest-ever one-day gain
Crude had its  biggest-ever one-day gain on Thursday after Donald Trump hinted at intervening in the Saudi-Russian stand-off. US energy producers are  restructuring billions in debt. The surging US dollar and plunging oil prices are piling stress on emerging economies, where non-resident investors have withdrawn $78bn in two months. (Bloomberg, FT) 

Slack and Microsoft fight for millions of remote workers
The coronavirus crisis has reignited one of the software industry’s fiercest rivalries, between Slack and Microsoft, over their respective workplace messaging apps. Amazon warehouse workers in the US, France and Italy have protested against normal shifts despite positive cases. Big Tech has the cash to expand after the crisis, Richard Waters writes— and regulatory threats are likely to recede. (FT)

Huge text message campaigns spread coronavirus fake news
An uptick in text-based misinformation, capitalising on coronavirus panic with misleading medical advice, is spreading largely via private, encrypted messages, making it difficult to curb. US officials believe the campaign bears hallmarks of China or Russia. (FT)

Former Uber engineer pleads guilty to stealing Google secrets
Anthony Levandowski, the former head of Uber’s self-driving project, pleaded guilty to one count of stealing trade secrets from Google, his former employer. Thirty-two other charges will be dropped as part of a plea deal reached with federal prosecutors. (FT)

India executions
India executed four men for the gang rape and murder of a young woman on board a Delhi bus in 2012, a crime that prompted a massive outpouring of public anger at pervasive violence against women. India ended an unofficial moratorium on the death penalty in 2012, when it executed Ajmal Kasab for the 2008 Mumbai terror attacks. (FT)

Which country was the first to suspend trading on its financial markets due to the coronavirus crisis: the Philippines, Italy or Iran? Take our quiz.

The day ahead

Tiffany earnings 
The luxury company is due to report on Friday, but investors will be more interested in an update on the LVMH takeover. Here’s a look inside LVMH’s factory in Orleans, which normally churns out bottles of perfume but in 72 hours was transformed to produce hand sanitiser destined for medical workers on the front line. (FT)

Olympic flame arrives
The Olympic flame arrived in Japan on Friday, as concerns grow over whether the Tokyo 2020 Games will go ahead as planned.   Sebastian Coe, who led London’s 2012 Olympics, admitted that a delay remained “possible”. (Reuters, Guardian)

Keep up with the important business, economic and political stories in the coming days with the FT’s  Week Ahead. Click to subscribe    here. And don’t miss our  FT News Briefing podcast — a short daily rundown of the top global stories.

What else we’re reading

Yuval Noah Harari: the world after coronavirus
Humankind is facing a global crisis, perhaps the biggest of our generation. We now face two important choices, and the decisions made in the next few weeks will shape the world for years to come. Don’t miss Charlie Bibby’s photo essay of a deserted London. (FT)

Germany: Europe’s South Korea?
Coronavirus has hit Germany with full force, but the country has proven remarkably resilient in one crucial way: the number of deaths has been minuscule, bucking trends elsewhere. In Ischgl, Austria, a ski resort is one of the 10 highest-risk areas globally, alongside Wuhan, northern Italy and Iran. (FT)

What scientists can learn from economists 
Britain’s government desperately needs the advice of economists,  writes Chris Giles. Ministers and officials must stop claiming they are in precise control and making promises they have no chance of delivering. During times of crisis, nations turn to their myths — but the spirit of the Blitz isn’t back. (FT)

Two sides of the same panicked story 
“Toilet paper” and “Treasury bonds” are not often uttered in the same breath, but right now they should be, writes Gillian Tett, who recounts her last dash before going into her own lockdown in New York. (FT)

Lentils and war games: Nordics under lockdown
Nordic and Baltic nations, ever aware of a threat from nearby Russia, have long involved citizens in contingency planning in the event of a national crisis such as a war, cyber attack or pandemic. (FT)

Calming creativity in troubling times 
“Seriously, mum, Handmade?” snarked Helen Brown’s 10-year-old son. “You want us to watch a man make a chair?” Fifteen minutes later, the cynic was mesmerised. Here are our TV and streaming picks this week. From falafel sellers to motivational speakers, people are finding creative ways to make use of idle resources, Tim Harford writes. Joy Lo Dico recommends gardening. (FT)

In praise of phone calls 
As  messaging has overtaken phone calls, what have we lost? There are few things as nourishing as the human voice, especially during a quarantine. Here’s an   extrovert’s guide to sanity in self-isolation. (New Yorker, Politico) 

Video of the day

Mastering the art of sustainable architecture
In a nation where space is at a premium, the Dutch are leaders in creating environmentally friendly buildings. From repurposed structures to modular, transportable studios and floating neighbourhoods, Helen Barrett explores three approaches to sustainability. (FT)

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has warned Donald Trump that imposing tariffs on additional Chinese goods would inflict damage to the US economy, as the US president faces a decision within days on whether to impose new levies on Beijing.

Speaking at the headquarters of the Business Roundtable, a lobbying group for corporate America in Washington, Mr Dimon said that while the direct impact of tariffs was small, the indirect effect could be substantial.

“It’s what happens to people’s psyche and confidence and businesses,” Mr Dimon said. “[The tariffs] wouldn’t be a positive.”

Mr Dimon’s comments came at the latest critical juncture in the trade war between the US and China. Mr Trump must decide by Sunday whether to move ahead with planned tariffs on $156bn of Chinese imports — including consumer goods like toys and smartphones. (FT) 

In the news

US hits Iranian airline and shipping group with sanctions The US has imposed sanctions on Iran’s biggest shipping company and largest airline for allegedly helping Tehran develop ballistic missiles in contravention of UN sanctions. (FT) 

Saudi Aramco officially world’s most valuable company Shares closed 10 per cent higher on Wednesday after the state oil company’s  first day of trading on Riyadh’s Tadawul stock exchange, giving the group a market capitalisation of nearly $1.9tn. The company is also gauging interest among international investors for a  possible listing in Asia. (FT, Wall Street Journal) 

Polls show UK election narrowing The Conservative party lead narrowed in the UK general election after a  rocky few days for prime minister Boris Johnson. On the final day of campaigning, a new poll by YouGov projected the ruling Conservative party would  secure a majority of 28 seats in the House of Commons, down from 68 in  an earlier model.  Mr Johnson and Labour leader  Jeremy Corbyn  each dashed across the country on Wednesday to secure eleventh-hour support. (FT)

We’ve made our daily UK election live updates free to read so everyone — not only FT subscribers — can keep up with all the news in the countdown to polling day. Simply visit  ft.com/ukelection.

Fed holds rates steady The Federal Reserve left its policy rate  unchanged at 1.5-1.75 per cent and indicated without dissent that it had no plans to make any more changes in 2020. After a two-day meeting, policymaker predictions for the likely future path of the Fed’s policy rate showed a decisive shift toward a more accommodative path over the next three years. (FT) 

India passes controversial citizenship law The country passed a  law offering fast-track citizenship to non-Muslims from neighbouring Muslim-majority countries — a turning point in Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s drive to redefine the country as a Hindu homeland. Our editorial board says the bill puts the country’s  secularism at risk. Find more on the history of the bill  here. (FT, BBC) 

EU unveils plan to be carbon neutral by 2050 In its  Green Deal for Europe, the EU unveiled a sweeping set of environmental initiatives aimed at creating the world’s first  carbon-neutral continent. Youth activist Greta Thunberg (below) addressed the  UN climate summit  in Madrid on Wednesday, the same day she was named    Time’s person of the year. Also at the summit,    China said it would lead a group of developing economies in calling for wealthier nations to contribute more funding to deal with the climate crisis. (FT, Time, South China Morning Post)

US regulator knew about 737 Max safety issues The US aviation regulator failed to ground Boeing’s fleet of 737 Max aircraft even after its own analysis showed it was far more accident-prone than most aircraft. At Wednesday’s congressional hearing, a Boeing employee also told lawmakers that he was rebuffed by the company after repeatedly warning about safety problems with its aircraft before two 737 Max jets crashed within months of each other, killing 346 people. (FT)

Aung San Suu Kyi defends Myanmar Aung San Suu Kyi launched a  vigorous defence of Myanmar against genocide allegations, insisting that accusers were painting an “incomplete and misleading” picture of a military crackdown that triggered an exodus of Rohingya Muslims. Her journey from the Nobel Peace Prize podium to the  defence lectern at the UN’s top court symbolises her  alienation from international admirers . (FT) 

Wretched state of North Korea’s female healthcare The country’s maternal mortality rate is 1,200 deaths per 100,000 births, 15 times higher than what had been reported in UN data and nearly five times above the global average, according to  new evidence from hundreds of defectors. (FT) 

The day ahead

UK election day Voters will decide whether Boris Johnson’s mantra to “get Brexit done” or the Labour party’s most leftwing manifesto in a generation has won them over. Will sterling hold its gains through the UK general election? We broke down a few  different scenarios. See the latest in public opinion with our  poll tracker. (FT)

European Council summit EU leaders will gather in Brussels for a two-day summit on Thursday, where they are likely to discuss deeper  eurozone integration and what next for Brexit. Also on Thursday in Europe, the ECB delivers its interest rate decision — policy is expected to remain unchanged. Instead the focus will be on  Christine Lagarde’s first meeting and press conference. (FT) 

Algerian elections Voters go to the polls on Thursday in presidential elections. The vote will be the first since protesters  toppled the ailing president Abdelaziz Bouteflika in April after 20 years in power, but many voters plan to stay away. (FT) 

Despite Tuesday’s USMCA deal, investors and business should  not get too comfortable with the idea that a lasting peace has finally descended over trade in North America, the FT’s James Politi writes. More in  Trade Secrets, our must-read daily briefing for the latest on international trade and globalisation.    Sign up here.

What else we’re reading

The role of AI in China’s crackdown on Uighurs In associating China’s repression in Xinjiang with sophisticated, AI-driven policing models, we may be  assuming too much, writes the FT’s China tech correspondent Yuan Yang. The technology used in China’s  surveillance state in Xinjiang is at root driven by political objectives that are blunt and indiscriminate. (FT)

The weird world of the election battlebus Candidates in the UK general election stepped off their  battlebuses for the last time on Wednesday evening, consigning the political vehicles that have provided a colourful backdrop (and a mobile home for politicians and journalists) for the past five weeks to the paint shop. Following the main party leaders as they tour the country, the surreal becomes normal. (FT)

Volcker criticises Trump in last essay “By the late summer of 2018, it was already clear that the US and the world order it had helped establish during my lifetime were facing deep-seated political, economic, and cultural challenges,” former Federal Reserve chairman Paul Volcker wrote three months before his death in the afterword to the forthcoming paperback edition of his autobiography and  published exclusively here.  (FT)

Grannies as the antidote to loneliness In the wider UK, despite being more digitally connected than ever before,  loneliness has become endemic and single-person households are on the rise. With the mounting costs of housing, education and care for children and the elderly, perhaps the west should look at other cultures’ multigenerational  housing models as a solution to such problems. (FT)

What racism sounds like in banking When former American football player Jimmy Kennedy, who earned $13m during his career, tried to become a “private client” at JPMorgan Chase, he was essentially told he was too black. Phone conversations that Mr Kennedy and a JPMorgan financial adviser had with bank employees, and secretly recorded, reveal the extent of  racial bias at a cluster of the bank’s branches in Arizona. In the tech industry, which also struggles with diversity, Intel offered a detailed look at its    pay disparities. It wasn’t flattering. (New York Times, Bloomberg) 

German payments group funds London spy operation A former Libyan intelligence chief, who told associates he is a shareholder in German payments group Wirecard, funded  a surveillance operation in London that targeted a string of investors including hedge fund manager Crispin Odey. Rami El Obeidi, head of foreign intelligence in Libya’s National Transition Council, was hunting for evidence that market speculators were attempting to manipulate Wirecard shares, according to two people familiar with the operation. (FT)

BlackRock strives for moral high ground The dismissals of two senior executives from BlackRock challenge external perceptions of the  corporate culture  Larry Fink, chief executive of the world’s largest asset manager, has helped build since founding the firm in 1988 and which he commonly promotes as a selling point. (FT) 

Chinese 5G sparks gold rush for Japanese materials China has much to gain from Japan, as it rushes to out-gun the US in the 5G market. In turn,  Japanese suppliers are seizing an unexpected opportunity in the superpowers' interminable trade and technology war. Blacklisted by the Trump administration, Huawei has steadily shifted procurement elsewhere. Japan has already benefited. (Nikkei Asian Review)

FT wins press awards

The Financial Times took home three prizes at the 2019 Press Gazette British Journalism Awards in London on Wednesday, including a second consecutive news provider of the year award.

Mehul Srivastava was recognised for his investigation into Israeli hacking firm NSO Group, whose spyware has infiltrated  WhatsApp and  Big Tech cloud providers. It was used to  track journalists and dissidents.

The team of Jim Pickard, Robert Shrimsley, Jonathan Ford, Chris Giles, Delphine Strauss and Sebastian Payne won the political journalism award for  The Corbyn Revolution, an FT Series on Labour’s agenda to transform Britain’s economy. Playwright Clare Dwyer Hogg was highly commended for her  commentary on Northern Ireland. Watch her short film “ Hard Border”, performed by Stephen Rea.

Podcast of the day

Tensions at the heart of Europe  Gideon Rachman talks to Franziska Brantner, a rising star of Germany’s Green party, about the tense relationship between France and Germany as discussions on Russia, China and deregulation take centre stage. (FT)

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz to find... FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email. How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz to find out. Global...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz to find...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz to find out.

Global equities are heading for their worst week since the depths of the financial crisis in 2008, as investors pile into asset classes that are seen as shelters during economic storms.

European and Asian equities faced a fresh bout of selling on the final trading day of the week. MSCI’s Asia Pacific index dropped 2.5 per cent, while the Stoxx Europe 600 fell 4 per cent and the FTSE 100 dropped by 3.6 per cent. S&P 500 futures suggested Wall Street’s benchmark index would decline 2 per cent.

The renewed selling comes after the S&P 500 ended down 4.4 per cent on Thursday, its worst one-day performance since 2011, taking its decline since a peak last week to 12 per cent, into correction territory. Goldman Sachs predicted on Thursday that US companies would “generate no earnings growth in 2020”.

But as investors increase bets that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates in response to the health crisis, questions were being asked about whether monetary policy can help. Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, warned on Friday the coronavirus would hit the UK economy in the months ahead. The euro and gold are benefiting from the panic.

In Asia, China has issued a record number of force majeure certificates to exempt local exporters from fulfilling contracts, while start-ups are struggling to maintain funding. Shenzhen’s tech-focused index is now the world’s best performing this year even as risky assets have been hammered. Saudi Arabia is pushing for a substantial oil production cut as demand sinks.

In other developments:

Germany has become the latest country to introduce mass quarantine measures as the number of cases in the country rises. The western state of North Rhine-Westphalia, which includes the cities of Cologne, Bonn and Düsseldorf, has quarantined some 1,000 people.

London-listed IAG — the owner of British Airways — and easyJet announced measures ranging from hiring freezes to aircraft redeployment as they seek to cushion the blow from the virus.

The Geneva Motor Show, which was due to start on Monday, was cancelled following a ban from the Swiss authorities on events attended by more than 1,000 people.

The largest US military base abroad is under lockdown as South Korea’s number of confirmed cases breached 2,000. Authorities are racing to identify members of a sect at the heart of the country’s outbreak.

Follow our live coverage  here, and don’t miss the FT News Briefing, where Gillian Tett unpacks the outbreak’s economic impact. (FT, WaPo) 

Further reading

The FT View: The global struggle to contain coronavirus

Italy under lockdown: ‘My town is shocked and scared’

Coronavirus shakes Big Tech but investors fear worse is to come

Why the WHO won’t call coronavirus a pandemic (Bloomberg)

Most coronavirus cases are mild. That’s good and bad news (NYT)

How Disease X erupted in China (SCMP) 

I was on the coronavirus cruise ship (Atlantic)

In the news

Turkey-Syria tensions rise
Ankara has vowed to launch retaliatory attacks after an air attack by Syrian forces in Idlib killed 33 Turkish soldiers. The attack is the single deadliest incident suffered by Turkey, a Nato member, since the start of the Syrian civil war on its border nine years ago and marks a major escalation in the conflict between Turkey and the Russian-backed Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad. What’s at stake for Turkey in Idlib? This explainer has the answers. (FT)

Three former Barclays bankers cleared of fraud charges
The UK Serious Fraud Office has lost its high-profile seven-year case against three Barclays bankers over deals they made with Qatar during the financial crisis. Two emergency cash calls in 2008 helped the bank avoid a bailout by the UK government, raising £11.2bn. The three defendants — Roger Jenkins, Tom Kalaris and Richard Boath — were acquitted after a five-month retrial at London’s Old Bailey. (FT)

SoftBank-backed DoorDash files for IPO
The lossmaking US food delivery start-up has filed for an initial public offering. The filing will test investor appetite for fast-growing but unprofitable consumer businesses in the wake of stuttering IPOs from Uber, Lyft, Peloton and Pinterest last year. The company behind the seven-piece South Korean boy band BTS is pushing ahead with plans for an initial public offering despite growing coronavirus fears. (FT)

Invesco’s outflows near $10bn
Invesco’s flagship leveraged loan fund has shed more than half its assets over the past year while ranking as the worst performing of its peers in the US, partly on an outsized bet on a coal company. Investors pulled $6.8bn from junk bond funds over the past week, including $4bn from BlackRock’s high-yield ETF alone. (FT)

Europe’s biggest ever buyout deal
Thyssenkrupp has agreed to sell its elevator division to private equity groups Advent and Cinven for €17.2bn, in what could be one of Europe’s largest ever buyout deals. Our Due Diligence team reports from Berlin where despite coronavirus fears the great and the good of the private equity industry gathered for their annual bash, including Carlyle Group’s David Rubenstein. (FT)

Upsurge of violence in Indiaputs spotlight on police
At least 42 people were killed and 300 others seriously injured in New Delhi this week in India’s worst outbreak of sectarian violence since 2002 riots in Gujarat. The carnage follows a stoking of animosity between India’s Hindu majority and Muslim minority by Narendra Modi’s ruling BJP — with some questioning whether police failed to intervene. (FT, NYT) 

Netanyahu battles for votes
Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s four-time premier, is pulling out all the stops to ensure his political survival in the country’s third poll in a year on Monday. Ex-military chief Benny Gantz, his rival, has ruled out a unity government. (FT) 

New dean in town
Erika James has been named dean of the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton Business School, making her the first woman and first person of colour to lead the programme that the FT has ranked as the  top global MBA for research. (Philadelphia Inquirer, FT) 

How many charges was former Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein convicted of this week: two, five or 22? Take our  quiz.

The days ahead

South Carolina primary 
Joe Biden’s future presidential ambitions rest on the African-American voters of South Carolina, who make up 60 per cent of Democratic voters in Saturday’s make-or-break primary. The former vice-president will be looking for a boost before Super Tuesday when hundreds of delegate votes will be up for grabs and former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg enters the ballot for the first time. (FT) 

Taliban peace deal possibility
The US and the Taliban are expected to sign a deal on Saturday setting out a timeline for US troop withdrawal in what could be a step towards lasting peace in Afghanistan. The   Taliban are winning; why would they cede anything, asks a former CIA officer. (FT, Economist, NYT)

Slovakia votes 
The country’s ruling Smer party, which has dominated Slovak politics for more than a decade, is expected to lose its parliamentary majority on Saturday in the first election since the murder of an investigative journalist. (FT) 

Harry and Meghan farewell tour 
The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have returned to the UK for a farewell tour as they prepare to step down as senior royals and begin life in North America. But in Canada, the pair will have to   pay for their own security. (CNN, Reuters) 

President Donald Trump and Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders are from different planets on most issues. But on trade, they’re  not really so different. More in  Trade Secrets, our daily briefing on the changing face of international trade and globalisation.    Sign up here. 

What else we’re reading

Lunch with Peter Piot
Peter Piot is the Mick Jagger of microbes. He helped discover Ebola when he was just 27 and led the fight against HIV-Aids and is a global health legend. Now director of the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine he is also great company, a wine lover and a foodie. He scans the menu with the intensity of a doctor examining a medical chart as he sits down for lunch with our Africa Editor David Pilling. “All we have is medieval ways of containment: isolation, quarantine, contact tracing,” he says on fighting the current coronavirus outbreak. (FT)

Disentangling the ‘Bernie Bros’ from the Russian bots
After victories in New Hampshire and Nevada, Bernie Sanders is the clear frontrunner to be the Democratic presidential nominee. But the online behaviour of his supporters — derisively referred to as “Bernie Bros” — and the prospect of Russian involvement has become one of the main issues threatening to thwart an otherwise unrelenting rise to the top for the Vermont senator. America may be about to get its most memorable lesson to date on how money cannot buy elections, writes Edward Luce in the latest Swamp Notes. (Sign-up for the newsletter here) (FT)

Opening the skies to drones and flying cars
Three challenges stand in the way of filling the sky with drones and flying cars. The first two — money and technology — are being tackled with zeal. The third challenge is harder: how should countries regulate their airspace so that vast fleets of drones and flying vehicles can operate safely? To solve this problem the Federal Aviation Administration is working with private companies to develop a new traffic management system for unmanned flights. (FT)

Life in Italy under lockdown
Italy is reeling from the political and economic ramifications of trying to contain one of the largest coronavirus outbreaks outside Asia. About 50,000 residents in 11 towns in the industrialised and wealthy north cannot leave a cordoned area until March 6 — or they risk fines and up to three months’ imprisonment. (FT)

Barclay court drama
Painful rifts within Britain’s Barclay family were once a private affair. But the bitter quarrel burst dramatically into the public this week with intra-family espionage, high court intrigue and alleged corporate chicanery. “Fit for Shakespeare,” said one longtime associate. (FT)

Accelerating or breaking on climate change
We often try to alter behaviour, especially that of others, by pushing on the accelerator rather than releasing the brake — finding what prevents them from acting differently. A vehicular metaphor seems apt as Tim Harford ponders replacing his disintegrating diesel car. (FT)

Your brain is not a computer — but your boss may be
Scientists have accumulated vast amounts of data on brains from the tiniest to our own. But what was for decades the dominant metaphor in neuroscience could have been leading us astray. A feared automation crisis imagines workers replaced by intelligent machines but   robots are already managing warehouses, call centres and software development. (Guardian, the Verge)

Solo dining in London
Eating alone can be a liberating act of self-care: you are alone with your thoughts, able to eat exactly what you wish at whatever speed you prefer. Food writer Tim Hayward pulls up to the counter at select single-friendly spots in the British capital. (FT)

Video of the day

Why buy negative yielding bonds?
About a fifth of the global bond market trades at negative yields. FT statistics journalist Federica Cocco explains why, and what the attraction is for investors. (FT)

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.The siege of a Hong Kong university entered a second day on Monday, fol... FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.The siege of a Hong Kong university entered a second day on Monday, fol...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

The siege of a Hong Kong university entered a second day on Monday, following a night of fire and ferocious clashes between riot police and protesters holed up on the campus.

Officers from the special tactical contingent, known as the “raptors”, attempted to storm the university in the early hours of Monday morning but were beaten back by volleys of petrol bombs that set the main entrance to Hong Kong Polytechnic University ablaze.

On Sunday evening, protesters defending a bridge near the campus set an armoured police vehicle on fire and repelled repeated police assaults with the help of petrol bombs fired off the roof of the university using large homemade catapults. Earlier in the day, a police officer was shot in the leg with an arrow fired from a demonstrator’s bow.

The siege of PolyU comes after the most violent week in the city’s months-long political crisis. At least one person was shot by police, another was set on fire, a 70-year-old man died after he was hit in the head by a flying brick and the police warned the city was on “the brink of total collapse”.

The situation in Hong Kong is a nightmare for China’s president Xi Jinping, writes Gideon Rachman. Meanwhile, one of the largest property owners in central Hong Kong that dates back its fortune to the opium trade with China’s Qing dynasty two centuries ago is now one of the territory’s most exposed conglomerates. (FT)

In the news

Saudi Aramco scales back IPO
Saudi Arabia on Monday called off plans to formally market the shares of Saudi Aramco outside the Kingdom and other Gulf countries ahead of its long-awaited initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter. The latest setback follows an announcement on Sunday that Saudi Arabia had significantly pared back its ambitious listing plans for the state-owned oil company. The Kingdom will now sell just 1.5 per cent of the group’s total shares to investors, raising between $24bn-$25.6bn, a fraction of the $100bn it had hoped for. (FT, Bloomberg) 

Impeachment inquiry
US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she would “ make sure” Donald Trump does not “intimidate” the whistleblower who sparked an impeachment inquiry as public hearings enter a second week. Gordon Sondland, the US ambassador to the EU, is scheduled to appear on Wednesday. Here’s our guide to the inquiry. (FT, WSJ)

Boris Johnson reverses tax cut promise
Britain’s prime minister has reversed a promise to cut corporation tax. Speaking to Britain’s business bosses, Boris Johnson said the £6bn saved by the U-turn would be spent on the NHS and other public services. Later, Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the opposition Labour party, will outline plans to help tackle climate change at a Confederation of British Industry conference. The leaders were speaking to business as polls show the Conservative party’s lead widening with less than a month to go until the general election. (FT)

Yahoo Japan and Line to merge
SoftBank-backed Yahoo Japan and messaging app Line have agreed to merge to create a south-east Asian powerhouse in data and artificial intelligence worth ¥3.3tn ($30bn). SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son has long pitched the merger as a way to compete against bigger groups in China and Silicon Valley, according to people familiar with the discussions. Elsewhere, ByteDance is in talks with the world’s largest record companies for global licensing deals as the Chinese company behind TikTok prepares to challenge Spotify and Apple with its own music streaming service. (FT)

HP spurns Xerox
The board of consumer printer company HP unanimously rejected a $22-a-share bid from smaller rival Xerox over the weekend, while leaving the door open to “a potential combination” of the two companies. Carl Icahn, the activist investor who owns stakes in both companies, described the potential deal “a no-brainer”. (FT)

Prince Andrew’s PR disaster
The Queen’s second son attempted to clear his name over abuse allegations in a BBC interview over the weekend. But the TV appearance turned into a PR disaster, engulfing him in a royal sex-and-propriety scandal unmatched since the 1990s. It was packed with bizarre alibis and unleashed a wave of excoriating coverage and amplified accusations over his connections to disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein. (FT, BBC)

Former Goldman Sachs partner diesat 81
Roy Smith ran Goldman Sachs’ international operations in the 1980s and was based in London, when Margaret Thatcher was British prime minister and the City of London was undergoing the biggest transformation in decades following the “big bang”. But Mr Smith, who studied at Harvard Business School with Michael Bloomberg, would have more of an impact on the public as an academic at New York University, where he became one of the investment industry’s foremost academic chroniclers. (FT)

The day ahead

Sri Lanka government
Sri Lanka’s former defence chief Gotabaya Rajapaksa will be sworn in after winning Saturday’s presidential election by capitalising on public fury over the deadly Easter bomb attacks. Known as “The Terminator”, Mr Rajapaksa’s ruthless streak helped propel his family’s dramatic political comeback. Mr Rajapaksa must work to bring reconciliation to Sri Lanka after decades of warfare, says an FT editorial. (FT, Guardian)

For more on what lies ahead this week for the global economy sign up to our Week Ahead email, which will land in your inbox every Sunday. Also watch The Week Ahead video, which previews some of the big stories the FT is watching. And remember, every Monday to Friday, our News Briefing podcast gives you a run down of the most important global business stories you need to start your day.

What else we’re reading

Facebook’s fake numbers problem
Mark Zuckerberg has always said Facebook is a platform for authenticity. But the proliferation of phoney identities has reached a record high. That’s a big problem for a company that trumpets user growth — a barometer of health to investors — and is often criticised for failing to police false information. Rana Foroohar writes that our personal data needs protecting from Big Tech. (FT)

‘Latin America is up in arms’
From Chile to Bolivia, revolts against leaders from left and right have root causes in stagnant growth and weak investment leaving Latin America facing a second “lost decade”. “Latin America is up in arms, all the way from the southern cone to Mexico,” one economist tells our Latin America editor Michael Stott, as he surveys a continent in turmoil. (FT)

Developers bend rules to lure NY buyers
The hard-and-fast rule for those hoping to own a New York City apartment was that they must come up with 20 per cent of the purchase price in cash in order to secure a property. Yet in an attempt to prod buyers in what has been a moribund market, several developers have begun to show more flexibility by either accepting smaller down payments or staggering them. One developer in the city described the luxury market right now as “scary”. (FT)

FT Executive MBA Ranking 2019
French school HEC Paris tops this year’s list of universities offering executive MBAs, up from sixth a year ago. The EMBA is a part-time programme often taken by people more established in their careers compared with those on full-time courses. Applications for traditional two-year, full-time MBA programmes in the US have declined overall for five straight years, according to the Graduate Management Admission Council, while EMBA applications have grown steadily. This is the list of best performing schools. (FT)

A trend to watch
Three banks in America have collapsed over the past month, bringing the total number of failures this year to four. In a country with some 4,700 federally insured lenders, that is a small number. But given that the total last year was zero, the trend is worth watching, writes our US banking editor Robert Armstrong.

Dealing with mistakes at work
Good god, I thought. That could have been me, writes Pilita Clark after watching Official Secrets, a film based on the true story of an explosive US intelligence memo that was leaked to Britain’s Observer newspaper on the eve of the 2003 Iraq war. The memo was inadvertently changed from American English into British English by an unsuspecting assistant who thought she was being helpful but it led to suspicions the memo was a fake. In her column, Pilita asks how should we deal with mistakes at work? (FT)

Britain’s silver screen queen
Olivia Colman takes to the throne as Elizabeth II in the third series of Netflix’s The Crown, released on Sunday. Following last year’s Oscar for her portrayal of 18th-century Queen Anne in The Favourite, the role cements Ms Colman as acting royalty. Jo Ellison got a sneak peek at the show’s fabulously Technicolor Windsor wardrobe. The real-life Queen Elizabeth has an unexpected second career: executive mentor. (FT, WSJ)

Video of the day

Will regulators approve Google’s bid for Fitbit?
Officials in Washington are likely to investigate Google’s bid to enter the wearable technology business, says our Washington correspondent Kiran Stacey, who also answers readers’ questions on technology and regulation. (FT)

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our  quiz to find out.

Top investment banks’ revenues fell to their lowest level since the financial crisis last year, according to new research, spurring record job cuts even as global equity markets boomed.

The world’s 12 largest investment banks posted combined revenues of $147.5bn across their trading and investment banking businesses last year, down 4 per cent year on year to the lowest level since 2008. Equities trading was the weakest business last year, said industry monitor Coalition, leading to the sharpest rate of lay-offs since it began collecting that data in 2012.

The investment banking performance contrasts with the record profitability at many of the banks’ parent companies, such as JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley, whose earnings were powered by strong trends in other parts of their businesses including consumer banking and investment management.

The world’s biggest banks have spent much of the past decade since the financial crisis trying to pivot their businesses away from trading and investment banking businesses, which are more volatile than other divisions and attract high capital charges.

Analysts are not predicting any immediate improvement. “Investment bank revenues seem to have stabilised in the last two years and we expect them to remain at these [lower] levels in the short term,” said Coalition research head Amrit Shahani.

In the news

Coronavirus outbreak latest
Chinese health authorities revised up Thursday’s number of coronavirus cases while an airline industry body warned that the outbreak could cost carriers $29.3bn. Protesters in Ukraine attacked a bus carrying evacuees from China, Apple supplier Foxconn warned that full-year revenue would suffer, Facebook pulled out of a San Francisco gaming conference and a gathering of China’s business and political elites   was postponed. Follow our live coverage here. (FT, BBC, SCMP)

Further reading:

Gillian Tett: Share prices look sky high amid coronavirus fears

Coronavirus wreaks havoc on luxury and fashion groups

Fourteen days in solitude: a quarantine diary (NYT)

Roger Stone sentenced
The veteran Republican political operative was sentenced to 40 months in prison following a controversy over the US justice department’s intrusion. Roger Stone was convicted last year of lying to Congress, obstruction and witness tampering. Intelligence officials warned US lawmakers that Russia was interfering in the 2020 campaign to support Donald Trump’s re-election. (FT, NYT)

EU budget talks deadlocked
Talks over the EU’s 2021-27 spending plans have exposed rifts within the union created by Brexit. The €60bn-€75bn funding gap in the budget would help finance ambitious policies to fight climate change, aid poorer regions and subsidise farmers. But a rebellion led by Germany over plans to slash rebates on budget contributions overshadowed discussions, which are set to continue in Brussels today. (FT)

HSBC’s executive search
HSBC has identified Jean Pierre Mustier, boss of Italian lender UniCredit, as the leading external contender to become its next chief executive. Noel Quinn, the interim chief appointed after John Flint was ousted last August, is the other candidate. Ralph Hamers of ING is moving into one of the most powerful and challenging positions in global finance at the helm of UBS. (FT)

Oil trader suffers big hedge fund loss
Pierre Andurand, one of the world’s best-known oil traders, experienced a loss of about 8 per cent in his main $1bn fund in January, a turbulent month for energy markets. Socially-responsible US investment funds, meanwhile, saw record inflows in 2018. But banks risk being caught off guard by the climate crisis, warns a recent analysis. (FT)

T-Mobile and Sprint close to deal terms
Sprint and T-Mobile are close to fresh takeover terms that would give Deutsche Telekom, the parent of T-Mobile US, about 43 per cent of the yet-to-be combined US wireless carrier. ViacomCBS shares plunged after the newly recombined television and film company’s first earnings report revealed losses. (FT)

Fears over the coronavirus have prompted goods shortages in Hong Kong that led thieves to hold up a supermarket this week to steal what: face masks, pork or toilet paper? Take our  quiz.

The days ahead

Nevada caucus
The US state holds the third Democratic presidential primary contest on Saturday, with Bernie Sanders leading in state polls. The main target of this week’s debate, Michael Bloomberg, will not be on the ballot, but may be   plotting to block a Sanders nomination. The billionaire is a pragmatic centrist, argues The FT View, but could pose a dilemma for US democracy. Edward Luce asks how could New York’s three-time mayor have been so unprepared for Wednesday’s mauling?

US lawmakers, meanwhile, have been warned by intelligence officials that Russia is interfering in the 2020 campaign to try to get President Trump re-elected. (WaPo, Politico, FT, NYT)

After this week’s debate, who would you vote for? Have your say in our latest  poll. 

Buffett’s shareholder letter
Warren Buffett will post his annual shareholder letter on Saturday as Berkshire Hathaway reports fourth-quarter results. Mr Buffett’s lesson for companies:  keep candid. (FT)

Iran parliamentary election 
Hardliners hope to use Iran’s election on Friday to forge a radical new parliament. More than 90 sitting MPs, including conservatives and hundreds of reformists, have been told they cannot contest the polls. (FT) 

G20 finance conference 
Global leaders and central bank chiefs will gather in Saudi Arabia over the weekend for the Institute of International Finance’s conference in Riyadh. New UK chancellor   Rishi Sunak will not be attending in order to focus on the forthcoming Budget. (IIF, Bloomberg) 

The  brutal realisation— that no one, anywhere, actually knows where every single one of the 3,000 parts that go into the average car comes from — should be heeded by politicians eyeing a rash of trade deals. More in  Trade Secrets, our daily briefing on the changing face of international trade and globalisation.    Sign up here. 

What else we’re reading

Wall Street now going after Main Street
Morgan Stanley’s $13bn purchase of online brokerage ETrade is the biggest bank deal since the financial crisis and suggests a wave of banking takeovers is on the way. Wall Street is now going after Main Street, says our Due Diligence, rather than the rich and powerful it once courted. But the deal is an expensive gamble by Morgan Stanley’s chief executive Jamie Gorman, says Lex. (FT)

EU v Silicon ValleyNew data-sharing principles laid out by the EU this week seek to crack open the data silos that have helped to reinforce the power of the dominant tech companies. But past experience suggests that, when it comes to limiting the power of Big Tech, it might be best not to expect too much, writes Richard Waters. (FT)

Lunch with Lloyd Blankfein
The retired Goldman Sachs chief executive and life-long Democrat discusses the populist backlash since the financial crisis, Donald Trump’s chances of being re-elected and American nostalgia. “When I went to school you couldn’t go to the bathroom because you were afraid of getting knifed.” (FT)

Modern slavery in Kensington
In theory, the maids, housekeepers, nurses, cooks and other domestic staff of visiting overseas families enjoy the same legal protections as any other employee in Britain. In reality, that protection seldom reaches behind the doors of town houses, five-star hotel rooms and country estates, where workers fall victim to abuse. (FT)

How a cruise ship holiday turned into a coronavirus nightmare
When retiree Linda Ip booked a 10-day voyage on board the Diamond Princess with her husband and a group of friends she never imagined that she would spend almost two weeks confined to a windowless cabin, before testing positive for the coronavirus — after which the holiday took an even darker turn. (FT)

Can the art world clean up its act?
“Panic. Absolute bloody panic,” a senior gallerist said of the Society of London Art Dealers’ reaction to new regulations to combat money laundering in the art market, a longstanding concern. Now, at last, we are seeing a concerted attempt to get to grips with it, writes arts editor Jan Dalley. (FT)

OK boomer 
For the first time, five generations of employees — traditionalists, baby boomers, Generation Xers, millennials and Generation Zers — coexist in the workplace. Generational consultants are helping bridge the divides. A new survey found teenagers have    unrealistic expectations about their future careers. (NYT, Economist) 

The horror of your hobby going viral
There ought to be an English word for the peculiar and specific feeling of resentment when something that we love — in Isabel Berwick’s case, swimming in the Hampstead Ladies’ Pond in north London — suddenly turns mainstream. She settles on Smug Early Adopter Resentment— or “smear”. (FT)

With insider tips from our global network of correspondents and subscribers,  FT Globetrotter makes the most of work travel. Start with FT chief executive  John Ridding’s tips for Paris and solo dining in Tokyo before diving into our city guides, free to read this week.

Podcast of the day

Finance on Instagram
The “ Instagram generation” is more famous for sharing consumption-driven images than financial savvy — but the social media platform is increasingly providing the “inspo” for young people looking to save money, start investing or get out of debt. Claer Barrett talks to FT Money writer Katharine Gemmell and columnist Jason Butler. (FT)

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

China is considering delaying its annual meeting of parliament, currently set to begin on March 5, as the country’s leadership struggles to bring the coronavirus outbreak under control.

It emerged over the weekend that Chinese president Xi Jinping issued orders to contain the deadly coronavirus outbreak almost two weeks earlier than previously thought, an account that appears to contradict the narrative that local officials were to blame for allowing the epidemic to spiral.

The official Communist party magazine Qiushi reported that Mr Xi met the party’s politburo standing committee, China’s most powerful decision-making body, and gave instructions on the virus response on January 7, 13 days before the public was warned about the outbreak’s severity. Previous state media accounts appeared to date Mr Xi’s earliest direct involvement to a January 20 statement.

China’s central bank on Monday cut a key medium-term lending rate in an attempt to prop up the economy. The reduction is expected to filter through to the loan prime rate, a benchmark for the broader financial system. Chinese equities rallied on expectations the stimulus measures will be part of a programme aimed at dulling the negative economic and financial effects of the coronavirus outbreak. The intervention by the People’s Bank of China put the renminbi on track for its first rise in four days.

Reported new cases of the Covid-19 virus rose to 2,048 on Sunday evening, taking the total to 70,548. The death toll increased by 105 to 1,770. For the latest on the number of reported cases of the outbreak, check our dynamic map.

In other developments:

Japan has confirmed another 99 cases of coronavirus on board the stricken Diamond Princess cruise ship, currently under quarantine in Yokohama, taking the total number of cases on the vessel to 454. On Sunday night, the US evacuated more than 300 of its citizens on board the ship.

Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong’s de facto flag carrier, has warned that its “financial results for the first half of 2020 will be significantly down on the same period last year”. Inbound traffic to Hong Kong, the airline’s main hub, was down 40 per cent in January compared with a year earlier.

Samsung has begun flying electronic components for its latest Galaxy phones from China to its factories in Vietnam, where it produces nearly two-thirds of its phones. The coronavirus crisis has left Vietnam’s manufacturers, both local and foreign-owned, vulnerable in areas from electronics to textiles and footwear because many have supply chains that rely on China. (FT)

Further reading:

Hong Kong toilet roll heist underscores coronavirus panic-buying

Coronavirus fears force China into mass chicken cull

Cries of despair from coronavirus Ground Zero

New York Chinatown business suffers from coronavirus fears

In the news

SoftBank investment chief pushes hedge fund
Rajeev Misra, the head of SoftBank’s $100bn Vision Fund, has lined up billions of dollars of outside investment for a new hedge fund-style investment vehicle. The plan has found support from Abu Dhabi’s state fund Mubadala and the government of Kazakhstan but would mark a sharp deviation from the vision of SoftBank’s founder Masayoshi Son, who created the telecoms company’s investment arm to take stakes in private, technology-focused start-ups and profit from scaling them up. (FT)

Japanese economic data worse than expected
Japan’s economy shrunk at an annual rate of 6.3 per cent in the fourth quarter after last autumn’s rise in the country’s consumption tax. The contraction was far worse than expected and puts pressure on Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and the Bank of Japan to mount a policy response. The dismal figures suggest that stimulus measures to cushion the effects of the tax rise were ineffective. (FT)

Pelosi issues 5G warning to Europe
Nancy Pelosi warned European countries they will “choose autocracy over democracy” if they let Huawei take part in rolling out 5G technology. Her remarks echoed those of Mark Esper, US defence secretary, and Mike Pompeo, secretary of state, at the annual Munich security conference over the weekend. The stark rhetoric was contested by Wang Yi, China’s foreign minister. The risk being discussed on the sidelines of the Munich conference was that the Europeans may end up crushed between Washington and Beijing, writes our Brussels Briefing (sign up here). Here are the highlights from the conference. Meanwhile, the US is turning to Qualcomm for its 5G buildout, as Rana Foroohar reports in her latest Swamp Notes. (FT)

Ex-justice officials call for US attorney-general to resign
More than 1,100 former justice department officials have called on US attorney-general William Barr to resign, accusing him of doing Donald Trump’s “bidding” by intervening to reduce the proposed sentence of the president’s longtime friend Roger Stone. Over the weekend Donald Trump ignored his attorney-general’s plea to stop tweeting and asserted it was his “legal right” to direct criminal cases as he wished. (FT)

Brexit warnings
France’s foreign minister has warned that the UK and EU face bitter negotiations over their future relationship. The warning from Jean-Yves Le Drian comes ahead of a speech on Monday by the UK’s chief Brexit negotiator, David Frost, where he is expected to say that the chances of a deal are being undermined by Brussels’ insistence that Britain sticks to EU rules. (FT)

GM to exit Australia and New Zealand
General Motors is pulling out of Australia and New Zealand, retiring its 160-year-old Holden brand and selling its factory in Thailand in the latest phase of its global restructuring. GM said China’s Great Wall Motors had agreed to buy its Thai manufacturing plant and that the moves would incur cash and non-cash charges of $1.1bn. The news comes as Geely sets its sights on becoming China’s first global carmaker. (FT)

Dubai port operator delists
DP World, which operates ports in 50 countries around the world, is to delist and be taken private by Dubai. It said going private would allow it to take a longer term view on the ports and logistics business. As part of the deal, majority owner Port and Free Zones World has offered to buy DP World shares listed on Nasdaq Dubai and pay $5.15bn to its parent Dubai World. (FT)

The world of luxury has changed completely in recent years.  How to Spend It, the FT’s luxury magazine, is following suit, relaunching under editor Jo Ellison to start a new dialogue about how we define “spend”.   Read more.

The day ahead

Zuckerberg meets EU commissioners
Fresh from the Munich security conference, Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg will meet EU commissioners Margrethe Vestager and Thierry Breton on Monday. “I believe good regulation may hurt Facebook’s business in the near term but it will be better for everyone, including us, over the long term,” he writes ahead of the meeting. (FT)

Libya talks
EU foreign ministers’ talks on the Libyan crisis on Monday could cover Mediterranean naval patrols to enforce an arms embargo after Stephanie Williams, the UN deputy envoy, warned that the ceasefire was “ holding by a thread”. Fayez al-Sarraj, the leader of Libya’s recognised government, warned that an oil blockade risked creating a  financial crisis. (FT, AJ)

US markets are closed on Monday for President’s Day.

Keep up with the important business, economic and political stories in the coming days with the FT’s  Week Ahead. Click to subscribe    here. And don’t miss our  FT News Briefing podcast — a short daily rundown of the top global stories.

What else we’re reading

Calls for Big Tech break-up gain traction in Democratic race
In 2016 Elizabeth Warren laid out her thinking on tech antitrust in a speech that became famous in legal and technology circles. Her ideas, fuelled by a small group of leftwing academics, are now gaining a wide hearing in the 2020 presidential race and causing trepidation in Silicon Valley. Meanwhile, Joe Biden’s biggest backers are responding to calls for donations but in private several donors expressed concern about his prospects. (FT)

For more from Rana,  sign up for our   Swamp Notes newsletter, where she and Edward Luce discuss money and power in Trump’s America.

Cambridge caught in crossfire of US-China tech war
The battle for technological supremacy between China and the US could damage Cambridge’s reputation as a centre for innovation as universities come under increased scrutiny. But decentralised technology can support individuals and liberal democracies, Rana Foroohar writes, finding one such example in Taiwan. (FT)

Inside Syria’s final battle 
There are some  3m civilians trapped in north-west Syria near the Turkish border, facing an intense bombing campaign by forces loyal to Bashar al-Assad. Streets are jammed with loaded cars, as families desperate to escape have little option of where to go. (FT) 

Is Modi’s BJP introducing Big Brother?
India’s ruling BJP has used what critics say are authoritarian tactics to contain unrest over a controversial new citizenship law. The surveillance build-up comes as the government embarks on its first personal data protection bill, which activists and some of the bill’s original champions fear will adopt a model closer to China than Europe. (FT)

Where to power dine in New York
Looking to combine discreet discussion with fantastic food in NYC? FT readers shared their top tips, from sushi on the Upper East Side to modernist Milanese on Park Avenue. Our US finance editor’s picked his favourite New York eateries in this guide. (FT)

Corporate schmoozing will survive coronavirus
The cancellation of the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona has pushed coronavirus to the top of any trade body or corporate board’s agenda. But it’s unlikely to derail our desire to meet in person, Andrew Hill writes. For chief executives, social media can be risky, but we should hear more from bosses on Instagram, not less, Pilita Clark argues. (FT)

A City life on film
Sulphur and White, which opens next month, tells the story of David Tait, a senior City executive — and the impact of childhood sexual abuse that nearly cost him his life. Emma Jacobs writes that it’s a difficult watch that demonstrates how the conversation around mental health has changed. Another film not to miss: the Battle for Hong Kong. (FT)

Lunch with the FT: Olga Tokarczuk
The fame that came with winning the Nobel Prize for Literature has been a bit jarring for the Polish writer: even on a recent trip to a hardware store, she was mobbed. Over  Lunch with the FT, Olga Tokarczuk sounded off on confronting history, battles with the nationalist right and why populist nostalgia will pass. (FT) 

FT academy

Want to know how FT editors produce award-winning long reads? Join FT Magazine editor Alice Fishburn and analysis editor Geoff Dyer for an in-depth masterclass on February 28. And pick up tips on how to   handle a big interview with chief features writer Henry Mance on February 21.

Video of the day

Will Brexit split the UK?
The FT’s chief UK commentator Robert Shrimsley and deputy opinion editor Miranda Green discuss whether the UK could break-up following the 2016 EU referendum. Opposition parties in Northern Ireland and Scotland are pushing for referendums on independence from London. (FT)

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.Michael Bloomberg came under sustained attack from his Democratic rival...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

Michael Bloomberg came under sustained attack from his Democratic rivals on Wednesday night for covering up alleged sexual harassment and gender discrimination and for his “stop and frisk” policy when he was Republican mayor of New York.

The billionaire was the clear loser in his first appearance in the televised Democratic debates. Elizabeth Warren, the senator for Massachusetts who has fallen back in polls since lacklustre results in Iowa and New Hampshire, emerged as Mr Bloomberg’s most pointed critic. She drew attention to allegations that have resurfaced in recent days that the former bond trader used vulgar and misogynistic language towards women he worked with in the 1990s at the eponymous financial information company he founded.

“I’d like to talk about who we are running against: a billionaire who calls women fat broads and horse-faced lesbians,” said Ms Warren. “And no I am not talking about Donald Trump. I am talking about Mayor Bloomberg.”

Amy Klobuchar, the US senator from Minnesota, went on the attack over Mr Bloomberg’s failure to release his tax records. The billionaire said he would release his financial statement in coming weeks.

But he was not the only candidate under fire as the presidential candidates used Wednesday night’s debate in Las Vegas to stake their claims ahead of Saturday’s Nevada caucuses.

Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Indiana and Ms Klobuchar, who are competing over many of the same moderate voters, locked horns repeatedly. Frontrunner Bernie Sanders was criticised for saying that he would not release more medical records.

The Democratic party nomination is a slow-motion train wreck, writes Edward Luce that is likely to end in a Bloomberg-Sanders showdown.

In the news

Coronavirus rate cuts
Chinese lenders cut their benchmark lending rate on Thursday by 0.1 percentage points as Beijing grapples with the economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic. Chinese bond yields fell to four-year lows and Goldman Sachs warned that the risk of a markets correction was “high”, but smartphone users in China made a record 222m apps downloads as the lockdown provided a gaming industry boost. Follow our live coverage here. (FT) 

Further reading:

Opinion: People’s Bank of China will help the country recover

Cruise industry caught in the eye of the coronavirus storm

How the coronavirus can kill people (WaPo)

UBS names new chief 
The world’s largest wealth manager has named the boss of Dutch bank ING  Ralph Hamers as its next chief executive, replacing Sergio Ermotti, who spent nearly nine years turning round the Swiss lender after its bailout during the financial crisis. (FT) 

EU demands Big Tech’s data
Technology companies will have to  open up troves of data to smaller rivals, akin to sectors such as financial services, under European Commission proposals aimed at breaking down digital monopolies. The FT View is that Facebook’s content regulation proposals are too weak. (FT)

German ambassador named head of US intelligence
President Donald Trump has appointed Richard Grenell, the American ambassador to Germany, to lead the US intelligence community. Democrats castigated the move to name Mr Grenell due to his lack of experience in the intelligence field, particularly given that the position oversees the 17 security agencies.

Separately, the White House has denied an allegation heard in a London court on Wednesday that Donald Trump offered to pardon Julian Assange if the WikiLeaks founder absolved Russia of hacking Democratic emails during the 2016 campaign. (FT)

US junk bond parade
Macy’s downgrade to junk status has taken the total number of US “fallen angels” to six this year, compared with 13 in 2019, stoking concerns of a sell-off that could ricochet through markets. But the Federal Reserve said the US economic outlook was “somewhat more favourable”. Could millennials extinguish the Fed’s firepower by retiring early? (FT, NYT)

‘Atmospheric rivers’ blamed for flooding
A little-understood weather phenomenon called “ atmospheric rivers” — water carried across the Atlantic by strong winds as long streams of vapour — could be central to understanding the severe recent flooding in Britain.

And after years focusing on oil, gas and mining companies, campaigners concerned about global warming are turning their attention to the world of finance. (FT)

Boeing asks for tax break to be dropped
The aircraft maker has asked for a $100m a year tax break from Washington state to be suspended in a bid to stop the EU from imposing billions of dollars in retaliatory tariffs this summer, when it is hoping to bring its troubled 737 Max back into service. (FT)

Suspected far-right extremist kills 10 in Germany
The killing spree took place in the German city of Hanau, in the state Hessen, in the latest evidence far-right violence is on the rise in the country. A letter written by the suspected killer claimed responsibility for the shooting and called for the “extermination of certain peoples who could no longer be expelled from Germany”. (FT)

AI discovers antibiotics to treat drug-resistant diseases
Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have discovered a powerful new antibiotic using a deep-learning algorithm that analysed the structure of 2,500 molecules. Meanwhile, the UN is to start using technology to try to understand what people living in war zones want from peace agreements. (FT)

The day ahead

Roger Stone sentencing 
The longtime Donald Trump ally and friend is set to be sentenced in Washington on Thursday on  seven counts of obstruction, making false statements and witness tampering. The president has publicly attacked the prosecutors as well as Judge Jackson and a juror in Mr Stone’s trial, leading to a remarkable furore with William Barr, Mr Trump’s attorney-general. Catch up on the case that has roiled the justice department. (FT, WSJ)

EU budget summit
European Council president Charles Michel convenes a high-stakes EU leaders meeting on Thursday with the goal of hammering out the bloc’s seven-year budget, which must be settled before the year’s end. Poland’s prime minister Mateusz Morawiecki argues that budget arithmetic masks the benefits of economic integration. (FT) 

Donald Trump is making the first visit of his presidency to  Delhi next Monday. White House and state department aides will no doubt be hoping that he keeps any boasting of his dealmaking prowess strictly in the realm of the trade (mini) deal. More in  Trade Secrets, our daily briefing on the changing face of international trade and globalisation.

Tech Scroll Asia

Amid the coronavirus outbreak, Apple is expected to  miss its production schedule for mass producing a more affordable iPhone, while inventories for existing models could remain low until April or longer, according to this Nikkei Asian Review  exclusive. More in our    Tech Scroll Asia newsletter, your guide to the billions made and lost in Asia tech.    Sign up here. 

PS: we’re offering a  free 30-day trial to Tech Scroll Asia, which includes access to FT.com. Spread the word to friends and colleagues. 

What else we’re reading

How WeWork lost its billions
WeWork’s pitch went beyond short leases to start-ups in need of flexibility: with pinball tables, meditation rooms and beer on tap, it offered a physical social network for millennials. Adam Neumann’s vision capitalised on a unique economic moment, after the financial crisis left swaths of prime office space empty. Here’s how it went wrong. (FT)

Smokers left in the cold
Excluding smokers from the workforce is spreading, to the delight of anti-smoking activists. But civil liberties advocates are alarmed by employers’ creeping control over workers’ lives — even when they are off the clock. The US and UK are at odds over ecigarettes: are they saving smokers or creating new addicts? (FT, Guardian)

Merkel and Macron: Europe’s missed chance
Europe’s differences with the White House are routinely played out in public, but the relationship that has really soured is that between Paris and Berlin, Philip Stephens writes. Martin Sandbu writes that corruption must be fought across all of Europe or not at all. (FT)

Just flagging . . . 
“Circle back.” “Pivot”. “Disruption”.  Corporate buzzwords are tedious, but they mark the boundary between work and leisure and save time. Why they’re annoying comes down to who’s using them, and when. Robert Armstrong bemoans the professional man’s prison uniform: the conformist suit. (Atlantic, FT)

Sweden’s negative rate experiment
It was the biggest monetary policy experiment of modern times, dividing economists, central bankers and politicians. Now that Sweden has called time on its five-year trial with negative interest rates, a serious question remains: did it work? (FT)

Playing to save her life
Dagmar Turner, from the Isle of Wight, played the violin while surgeons removed a tumour from her right frontal lobe, near the area that controls fine movement of the left hand. On her playlist: Gustav Mahler, George Gershwin and Spanish songwriter and singer Julio Iglesias. (Reuters)

With insider tips from our global network of correspondents and subscribers, FT Globetrotter can help you make the most of your work travel. Start with FT chief executive John Ridding’s tips for Paris before diving into our city guides, free to read with week.

Podcast of the day

How to record the sound of sex
In the latest episode of Culture Call, Kaitlin Prest chats with Lilah Raptopoulos about sex, power and the grey areas around consent. Plus: trend forecaster Emily Segal, known for coining “normcore”, shares five alternate fashion-month takeaways. (FT)
