urn:contentItem:5X2D-8TT1-JB77-K018-00000-00FirstFT: Today’s top stories2019-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisFirstFT: Today’s top stories Eli Meixler, Eileen Rodriguez and Neil Maxwell

Oil prices rose as much as 20 per cent to above $71.00 a barrel — the biggest percentage spike in almost three decades — as markets reopened... Oil prices rose as much as 20 per cent to above $71.00 a barrel — the biggest percentage spike in almost three decades — as markets reopened after an  attack...

Oil prices rose as much as 20 per cent to above $71.00 a barrel — the biggest percentage spike in almost three decades — as markets reopened... Oil prices rose as much as 20 per cent to above $71.00 a barrel — the biggest percentage spike in almost three decades — as markets reopened after an  attack...

Oil prices rose as much as 20 per cent to above $71.00 a barrel — the biggest percentage spike in almost three decades — as markets reopened...

Oil prices rose as much as 20 per cent to above $71.00 a barrel — the biggest percentage spike in almost three decades — as markets reopened after an  attack on Saudi Arabia’s oil infrastructure at the weekend cut more than half the country’s production.

The rally, which followed news that Saudi Arabia’s oil production is expected to be well below maximum capacity for weeks, set oil on course for one of its biggest one-day gains as traders worried over the extent of the outage.

Brent crude oil, the international benchmark, gained almost $12 to trade as high as $71.95 a barrel, before easing back to $65.21 in the European morning, still up 8.5 per cent. The US benchmark, West Texas Intermediate, was up as much as 16 per cent to $63.64 a barrel before paring back these gains to $59.25, or 8 per cent up.

The attack on Saturday, which the  US blamed on Iran, sharply increased risks in global energy markets. It also  dented Saudi Arabia’s reputation as the most reliable supplier of last resort.

Saudi Arabia was  ill-equipped to deal with the disruption amid new leadership at Saudi Aramco and the energy ministry and a looming IPO, Nick Butler writes. Read our  Live blog .

In the news

Fed wrestles with trade war and Saudi oil attackA potential oil shock will add to problems policymakers already face assessing  economic risks. (FT)

Brexit talks Boris Johnson will hold his first face-to-face talks with Jean-Claude Juncker, European Commission president, on Monday, with the British prime minister claiming he “passionately” believes a Brexit deal is possible. Wolfgang Munchau contends that an  Italian-style coalition could stop Brexit. The changes in Rome hold lessons for Remainers — and for Mr Johnson. (FT)

Purdue claims bankruptcyPurdue Pharma, the opioid maker owned by members of the Sackler family, has  filed for bankruptcy, as it hopes to force holdout states to accept its offer to settle litigation that accuses it of helping cause the US opioid epidemic. (FT)

China’s slowdownGrowth in industrial output from Chinese factories  fell to a fresh low in August, another signal that the trade war and slowing economic activity are weighing on the world’s second-biggest economy. Chinese companies have also become  net sellers of global assets this year for the first time in a decade. (FT)

Havoc in Hong KongPro-democracy protesters  left a trail of destruction across Hong Kong on Sunday, marching in defiance of a police ban and vandalising government buildings and subway stations. The anti-government demonstrations have now  lasted more than 100 days — and have a    new anthem. (FT, Bloomberg)

Frankfurt Motor Show stallsThe future of the  world’s biggest motor show is in doubt after a weekend of environmental protests brought parts of Frankfurt, which has hosted the motor show since 1951, to a standstill. Meanwhile,  BMW will not renew the i3, its primary electric vehicle. (FT)

HKEX charm offensiveHong Kong’s bourse will step up efforts this week to buy the London Stock Exchange Group by  appealing directly to shareholders, following the rejection on Friday of its £32bn offer. Our  Big Read delves into the unsolicited bid, which is testing the LSE’s post-Brexit loyalties amid tensions with China. (FT)

Blackstone has  clinched an all-cash takeover for Canadian real estate investment trust Dream Global, valuing the owner of western European office and warehouse spaces at C$6.2bn ($4.7bn). The acquisition adds to Blackstone’s expanding portfolio of logistics properties — the group’s property arm closed a record $20.5bn in commitments last week.

French hotel group returns to SyriaLouvre Hotel Group will manage two luxury hotels opening next year in Damascus, the first western company to return to Syria’s tourist industry since civil war broke out in 2011. (FT)

Days ahead

Coin questionsFacebook is set to be  quizzed today on its proposed Libra coin project by global regulators after a weekend in which EU finance ministers meeting in Helsinki expressed concern about the financial stability implications of the project. Benoît Coeuré of the European Central Bank, who will chair the meeting, warned in Finland that “the bar for regulatory approval will be very high” for Libra to operate in the EU. (FT)

Apple and IrelandJudges in Luxembourg will on Tuesday and Wednesday hear  arguments in the court battle over the European Commission’s finding that Apple and Ireland created an “artificial” profit arrangement enabling the iPhone maker to pay a tax rate of less than 1 per cent. (FT)

What else we’re reading

Israel’s election kingmakerAs Israel goes to the polls on Tuesday for the second time in a year, former defence minister Avigdor Lieberman is wooing secular security hawks in a bid to  fracture the rightwing vote— giving him power over the fate of Israel’s prime minister since 2009, Benjamin Netanyahu, who also faces a  united Arab opposition. (FT)

US scepticism on climate changeAhead of a UN climate summit next week, a YouGov poll shows the US is a clear outlier in terms of scepticism about climate change, with considerably more people expressing doubts than in Europe. Some 15 per cent of Americans believe either that the climate is not changing at all, or that it is not changing due to human causes, almost three times the global average. ( FT)

Takedown is on the moneyRana Foroohar is not a big fan of shareholder “activists” like Paul Singer, but she thinks the letter his investment firm Elliott Management sent last week to AT&T’s board of directors  couldn’t be truer. The telecoms group is an underperforming, mismanaged dodo bird of a company — big enough to have racked up $190bn in debt yet not large enough to fend off the Big Tech apex predators ready to eat its lunch, she writes. (FT)

Lunch with the FTPierre Lagrange, the 57-year-old Belgian maverick “hedgie” is a financial nerd: an engineer who made a fortune leading up to the financial crash and then in its aftermath. But his back-story is rather edgier: innovator, fashionista, iconoclast, Harley rider and more. And secretive his HQ certainly is. (FT)

Can Jamie Dimon’s magic touch weather the bad times ahead?If the world’s big banks are riding for a fall, you wouldn’t know it to look at the biggest of them all, writes Patrick Jenkins.  JPMorgan’s share price hit an all-time high of nearly $119 late last week, cementing its dominance of the world ranking by market capitalisation. The financial crisis was supposed to have killed off all the “masters of the universe” — Mr Dimon may be the last true example of the species. (FT)

Hidden M&A victims: staffMany  M&A deals take no account of the extreme human cost in disruption and anxiety, writes Andrew Hill (FT)

Notre-Dame’s toxic falloutWhen flames engulfed the Notre-Dame in April,  460 tons of lead in the roof and spire were incinerated, scattering toxic dust on to the streets, schools and parks of Paris. Five months later, French authorities have not disclosed contamination testing results. Here are    precautions to consider before visiting with children. (NYT)

Africa’s urbanisation illsUrbanisation often conjures images of young professionals crammed into megacities, living in pods in ever-taller skyscrapers. But some 10m people are projected to  flood into Lagos, Nigeria between 2020 and 2025, roughly 10 times the number of people who will become Londoners. Read more about the city’s response in our Special Report:  How will we live in 2050? (FT)

The grandmaster dietTraining for top chess players now includes strict dietary and fitness regimens to avoid severe weight loss during tournaments, when their  stress responses mirror other elite athletes: last year, 21-year-old Russian grandmaster Mikhail Antipov was estimated to have burnt 560 calories in two hours of competition — roughly the same as Roger Federer in an hour of tennis. (ESPN)

Sexist jokes are sadly not outliersAn unfortunate missive from CLSA’s Damian Kestel reinforced tedious, sexist clichés, but it was a reminder that while sensitivity to corporate sexism is improving,  we still have a long way to go, Pilita Clark writes. (FT)

Richard Haas predicts that John Bolton’s successor  will struggle to satisfy Donald Trump. The president of the Council on Foreign Relations argues from his own experience as National Security Council staff member that the next US national security adviser would be wise to focus on details. (FT)

Video of the day

Why sterling is on the reboundThe FT’s capital markets editor Katie Martin sees fading no-deal Brexit fears  driving the pound’s recovery this week. (FT)

Saudi Aramco has become the most valuable company in the world after its shares began trading on Riyadh’s Tadawul stock exchange....

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.Saudi Aramco has become the most valuable company in the world after its...

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

Saudi Aramco has become the most valuable company in the world after its shares began trading on Riyadh’s Tadawul stock exchange.

The stock market debut marks the culmination of a near four-year process to list the state-owned oil company beset by problems.

When trading began on Wednesday the shares rallied 10 per cent, giving the group a market value of nearly $1.9tn — comfortably ahead of both Apple and Microsoft. It is also a bigger market capitalisation than the combined value of the next five biggest international oil companies.

The company raised $25.6bn in the IPO, surpassing the $25bn raised by China’s Alibaba when it debuted on Wall Street in 2014 and making it the world’s largest ever IPO. However, state investment funds and wealthy families were encouraged to buy Saudi Aramco shares in a last-ditch attempt to give Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman his long-coveted $2tn valuation.

Saudi Arabia pared back its hopes for the public offering after international investors balked at the valuation, forcing the kingdom to abandon an international roadshow weeks before the listing. Just 1.5 per cent of the company was sold to investors in the end, down from an initial target of 5 per cent or $100bn of new financing.

In the news

Impeachment charges announced
House Democrats outlined two articles of impeachment against Donald Trump on Tuesday, accusing him of abusing power by pressuring Ukraine to investigate his political rivals and of obstructing Congress’s inquiry (read the annotated articles, and an   explanation of the charges). Mr Trump will probably be formally impeached by a House vote next week, leading to a trial in the Senate, which can remove him from office by a two-thirds vote. (FT, WaPo, Reuters)

USMCA trade pact signed
But Democrats also gave Donald Trump a breakthrough on Tuesday, agreeing to ratify the USMCA trade pact with Canada and Mexico. Here are the deal’s crucial provisions, including free flow of data. Edward Luce writes that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi made a political bet pursuing impeachment and the trade deal simultaneously. (FT, WSJ)

Polls show UK election narrowing
The Conservative party lead has narrowed in the UK general election after a rocky few days for prime minister Boris Johnson. On the final day of campaigning, a new poll by YouGov projected the ruling Conservative party would secure a majority of 28 seats in the House of Commons, down from 68 in an earlier model. Meanwhile, tens of thousands of political ads vanished from Facebook’s public archive less than 48 hours before the poll, raising fresh transparency concerns.

We’ve made our daily UK election live updates free to read so everyone — not only FT subscribers — can keep up with all the news in the countdown to polling day. Simply visit ft.com/ukelection.

ExxonMobil wins, Chevron writedown
ExxonMobil has won a court fight with New York state over its vulnerability to climate change disclosures, in a ruling that could affect similar challenges. The fraud claims centred on Exxon’s use of a proxy carbon cost to incorporate future emissions curbs in planning. Oil major rival Chevron has put US shale gasfields up for sale as it plans to write down more than $10bn on low natural gas prices. (FT)

US-China tariff delay expected
China expects the US will delay a threatened tariff increase on Sunday to continue negotiations on a “phase-one” trade deal, which could include reducing rather than removing levies already in effect. US stocks closed slightly lower on Wednesday, but Wall Street is predicting the record-setting rally will continue in 2020. (Bloomberg, FT)

Big bank earnings set to rebound
The biggest banks in the US have buoyed hopes of a big rebound in fourth-quarter earnings after a brutal final quarter in 2018. Senior executives from Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs all described strong trends in the last few months at an industry conference in New York. Separately, HSBC’s private bank will pay $192m in penalties and admit to helping US customers hide more than $1bn from tax authorities. (FT)

Ex-Mexican minister accused of taking cartel bribes
The Mexican minister in charge of security during the country’s ill-fated war on drugs has been arrested in the US, accused of conspiring to smuggle cocaine and accepting multimillion dollar bribes to protect jailed drug kingpin Joaquín “El Chapo” Guzmán’s Sinaloa cartel. Genaro García Luna, who held the security post from 2006 until 2012, was arrested in Dallas on Monday. Meanwhile, our correspondent in Mexico describes how the offer of asylum for former Bolivia president Evo Morales has polarised the country. (FT)

The days ahead

Central banks meet
The US Federal Reserve is expected to hold rates on Wednesday, ending this year’s easing. Brazil’s central bank is expected to reduce the Selic rate by 50 basis points for a fourth consecutive meeting to 4.5 per cent, a new low. The European Central Bank holds its first monetary policy meeting under Christine Lagarde on Thursday. (FT)

India’s citizenship bill
A contentious bill, which offers a pathway to citizenship to South Asian migrants fleeing religious persecution, apart from Muslims, will go before India’s upper house of parliament on Wednesday. The bill sailed through the lower chamber on Monday. (FT, BBC)

Sign up for Trade Secrets

Last week, Wang Yi, China’s foreign minister, made his first trip to South Korea in five years. The senior statesman’s meetings with his South Korean counterpart, Kang Kyung-wha, and South Korea’s president Moon Jae-in put the spotlight on China’s use of trade to bolster or batter the economies of its closest neighbours. More in Trade Secrets, our must-read daily briefing for the latest on international trade and globalisation.   Sign up here.

What else we’re reading

Paul Volcker’s legacy
“By the late summer of 2018, it was already clear that the US and the world order it had helped establish during my lifetime were facing deep-seated political, economic, and cultural challenges.” The words of former Federal Reserve chairman Paul Volcker, written three months before his death as the afterword to the forthcoming paperback edition of his autobiography and published exclusively here. Meanwhile, Martin Wolf writes a personal appreciation of Volcker. (FT)

German payments group funds London spy operation
A former Libyan intelligence chief, who told associates he is a shareholder in German payments group Wirecard, funded a surveillance operation in London that targeted a string of investors including hedge fund manager Crispin Odey. Rami El Obeidi, head of foreign intelligence in Libya’s National Transition Council, was hunting for evidence that market speculators were attempting to manipulate Wirecard shares, according to two people familiar with the operation. (FT)

Peloton’s bigger problem
The US fitness equipment maker’s advert provoked a cascade of criticism, evoking postwar era advertising that portrayed wives as submissive rather than independent. The reassuring news for Peloton is that errors tend to fade — the bad news is that its marketing mistake drew attention to a product weakness, John Gapper writes. (FT)

EU green policy stumbles
For Europe, halting global warming has been elevated to a moral imperative. Yet for some developing countries such as Brazil, Indonesia and Malaysia, translating those ideals into trade policy, to be outlined in the “Green New Deal” on Wednesday, evokes protectionism and has been described as “colonialism”. Read more in the FT Series: Europe First. (FT)

Russia’s banking shakedown
At a time when regulators are shutting down lenders over allegations of fraud or money laundering, Moscow’s security apparatus has used the banking sector as a gold mine. Don’t miss these images of the   first Chechen war, which 25 years ago humbled post-Soviet Russia and tilted power towards Vladimir Putin. (Bloomberg, NYT)

New Zealand’s eruption
When cool water meets boiling magma, the result can be explosive. This is what is thought to have happened on the volcano Whakaari, which killed six people this week and left another eight missing. Predicting eruptions should be possible — but the challenge is to transform data into real-world judgments, Anjana Ahuja writes. (CNN, FT)

BlackRock’s ethics, Glencore’s ‘billionaire boys club’
Mark Wiseman’s firing last week, the second recent departure from BlackRock’s global executive committee, speaks to the corporate culture chief executive Larry Fink has built since 1988. A fraud investigation over “suspicions of bribery” puts pressure on Glencore for rare change at the top. (FT)

FT wins press awards

The Financial Times took home three prizes at the 2019 Press Gazette British Journalism Awards in London on Wednesday, including a second consecutive news provider of the year award.

Mehul Srivastava was recognised for his investigation into Israeli hacking firm NSO Group, whose spyware has infiltrated WhatsApp and Big Tech cloud providers. It was used to track journalists and dissidents.

The team of Jim Pickard, Robert Shrimsley, Jonathan Ford, Chris Giles, Delphine Strauss and Sebastian Payne won the political journalism award for The Corbyn Revolution, an FT Series on Labour’s agenda to transform Britain’s economy. Playwright Clare Dwyer Hogg was highly commended for her commentary on Northern Ireland. Watch her short film “ Hard Border”, performed by Stephen Rea.

Podcast of the day

Tensions at the heart of Europe
Gideon Rachman talks to Franziska Brantner, a rising star of Germany’s Green party, about the tense relationship between France and Germany as discussions on Russia, China and deregulation take centre stage. (FT)

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our  quiz to find out.

FirstFT on Monday will be a special year-end edition, with a 2020 preview on January 2. We will return on January 6. Wishing all our readers a very happy holiday and new year. 

The timing of Donald Trump’s impeachment trial was thrown into doubt on Thursday after Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic House speaker, refused to reveal when she would send the articles of impeachment to the Senate.

The move by Ms Pelosi was seen as an attempt to pressure Republicans into accepting Democratic demands that White House officials, who had refused to testify before the impeachment inquiry, be called as witnesses at trial. But her comments drew condemnation from Republican lawmakers and the president.

“So after the Democrats gave me no Due Process in the House, no lawyers, no witnesses, no nothing, they now want to tell the Senate how to run their trial,” Mr Trump tweeted. “Actually, they have zero proof of anything, they will never even show up. They want out. I want an immediate trial!”

Mitch McConnell, the Republican Senate majority leader, stepped up the high-stakes game of chicken over the impeachment trial.

“Speaker Pelosi suggested that House Democrats may be too afraid . . . to even transmit their shoddy work product to the Senate,” Mr McConnell said. “The prosecutors are getting cold feet in front of the entire country.”

The stand-off between Ms Pelosi and Mr McConnell — two of the shrewdest lawmakers in the US Congress — creates doubt over whether the Senate trial will proceed as planned in early January.

The House broke up on Thursday for a two-week holiday recess without taking the votes to appoint impeachment managers, which is required to start the process in the Senate. Meanwhile, the White House is preparing   for the departure of acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney once the Senate wraps up the impeachment trial. (FT, NYT, WSJ, Politico)

In the news

Warren and Buttigieg clash in Democratic debate
Elizabeth Warren, the US senator from Massachusetts, and Pete Buttigieg, the mayor of South Bend, Indiana, engaged in a fiery exchange over campaign finance and “big dollar donors” in the final televised Democratic leadership debate before voting in the primaries begins early next year. All the candidates broadly welcomed the House vote to impeach Donald Trump, with only entrepreneur Andrew Yang dissenting that the party should stop being “obsessed” with impeachment. (FT)

Bank of England chooses new governor
The Bank of England has chosen its 121st governor — the successor to Mark Carney, who steps down at the end of next month. Andrew Bailey is head of the UK’s financial services regulator and has overseen a series of headline-grabbing financial scandals this year. The UK should have left the EU by the time Mr Bailey takes up his new post but other challenges lie ahead for the new governor. Here are the five most pressing issues in his in-tray. (FT)

Kalanick on course to sell out of Uber 
Travis Kalanick has sold more than 90 per cent of his stake in Uber, liquidating more than  $2.5bn worth of stock in less than two months. The proceeds provide Uber’s former chief with a war chest to finance his new venture, City Storage Systems, better known as CloudKitchens. Uber also agreed to  pay $4.4m to settle claims of gender discrimination. (FT)

Paris bears brunt of strikes 
As strikes against Emmanuel Macron’s pension reform plan enter their third week,  daily disruption of the French capital’s transport networks is taking its toll, with foreign tourists staying away and commuters struggling to reach the city centre. Business has begun to sound the alarm. (FT)

Russian shooting 
Police killed a  gunman who attacked the Moscow headquarters of the country’s security services, killing one and severely wounding five during Thursday evening’s rush hour. Meanwhile, Vladimir Putin has said he is open to  altering Russia’s constitution, including increasing the power of parliament and restricting presidential terms. Mr Putin, who has governed Russia since 2000, must step down as president in 2024 under the constitution. (FT)

Goldman approaches 1MDB settlement 
Goldman Sachs is in talks with the US government to pay a  nearly $2bn fine, admit guilt from its Asia subsidiary and submit to continuing oversight to resolve a criminal investigation into its role in the multibillion-dollar    1MDB corruption scandal. Here’s  our timeline of the 1MDB affair. (WSJ, FT)

What percentage of Macau’s government revenues come from the gaming industry: 35 per cent, 60 per cent or 80 per cent? Take our  quiz.

The days ahead

Boris Johnson’s Brexit bill 
Boris Johnson outlined his  government’s agenda on Thursday, which he hailed as the most radical in a generation. Here’s  our guide to the packed programme, which begins on Friday with a vote on a new Brexit bill that  limits parliament’s role and strips out protections on workers’ rights. Sterling, meanwhile, is on track for its worst week of the year as Brexit uncertainty returns. (FT, Guardian)

US GDP report 
Friday brings the year’s final gross domestic product reading, which is expected to show the US economy  grew 2.1 per cent in the third quarter. Economists are  optimistic about US economic growth in 2020, but it will probably be slower than in 2019. (FT, WSJ) 

Croatia’s election 
President Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic is locked in a  three-way battle for Sunday’s vote after a gaffe-prone campaign eroded the former Nato assistant secretary-general’s lead, stoking political uncertainty as Croatia prepares to hold the EU presidency for the first time. (FT)

Boeing said this week it would  suspend production of its 737 Max in January, triggering concerns of a ripple effect across the US manufacturing industry. Could this affect phase one of the US-China trade deal, which requires China to increase its imports from the US? More in  Trade Secrets, our daily briefing on the changing face of international trade and globalisation.    Sign up here. 

What else we’re reading

The year capitalism went cuddly 
Milton Friedman has had a tough year. Chief executives lined up to disavow the Chicago economist’s doctrine that a company’s sole responsibility is to shareholders,  putting “purpose” at the heart of business models and tackling social issues as diverse as immigration, gun violence and climate change.  Gillian Tett writes that ESG investors are taking on Big Tech, while FT Money offers tips on  where to invest in 2020. (FT)

Moral Money is our new weekly newsletter covering sustainable business, finance and investing.  Sign up here.

Irish isles hope for gin tonic 
In Ireland’s remote offshore islands, poteen, an illicit homemade whiskey, was a staple of rural life for generations. Now, as Dublin steps up efforts to support the small and scattered western communities, Cape Clear island has produced its  first run of gin. (FT)

Five decades, 25 films 
From Raging Bull to Spirited Away, the FT’s outgoing film critic Nigel Andrews  picks his favourite films. Read his  reflection on stepping out of the semi-darkness of the cinema after 50 years. What are your top five films from the past 50 years? Tell us in the comments. (FT)

The end of privacy 
Dozens of companies are  tracking mobile phones, and in effect, their owners. A data trove includes 50bn phone location pings from more than 12m Americans, and it was eerily simple to determine the identity of any one of them. Meanwhile,  an FT analysis found evidence of violence, hate speech, bullying and sexually explicit content on TikTok, where current and former employees said inexperienced teams were ill-equipped to deal with content moderation. (NYT, FT)

Commercialising Christmas 
Santa was not dreamt up by the marketing men — but Rudolph the red-nosed reindeer was, in 1939, so that Montgomery Ward stores could give away millions of copies of his heart-warming story,  Tim Harford writes. Builders, cleaners, postal workers — how much should you  tip at Christmas? From reusable wrapping paper to a vegan dinner, here’s how some are celebrating a  sustainable Christmas. Need a break from the holidays? Here’s the FT Globetrotter guide to  London’s best martini. (FT) 

Pets replace progeny 
Today, as millennials delay or avoid having children, many are choosing to  raise dogs, cats or even pigs instead. Pets may cost less than babies to raise to maturity — not to mention the lower college tuition costs — but they are far from cheap: one recent survey shows 42 per cent of US millennials have gone into debt for their pets. (FT) 

Podcast of the day

Our 2019 cultural round-up 
From Lizzo and Fleabag to Greta Thunberg and the Impossible Burger,  Culture Call hosts Lilah and Gris look back at the biggest themes, people and moments of the year, plus listener recommendations for your holiday gift list. (FT)

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.Executives at Nissan have accelerated secret contingency planning for a...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

Executives at Nissan have accelerated secret contingency planning for a potential split from Renault as Carlos Ghosn’s downfall continues to reverberate.

The plans, the latest sign of tension in the 20-year-old automotive alliance, include war-gaming a total divide in engineering and manufacturing as well as changes to Nissan’s board, according to several sources, and have taken on added urgency since Mr Ghosn’s dramatic escape from Japan in December.

A full split would probably force both carmakers to seek new partners as the industry grapples with falling sales and rising costs from the shift to electric vehicles. Rivals are also bulking up, with FiatChrysler and PSA merging and Volkswagen and Ford forming an alliance.

Here’s a look at the colourful cast of operatives allegedly involved in secreting Mr Ghosn, who said last week that he felt like a “hostage” in Japan, from Tokyo to Beirut.

Spin doctors offer advice on turning round the damaged Ghosn brand. But Andrew Hill writes that may be mission impossible — the former auto executive’s choices leave his reputation beyond repair. (FT, Bloomberg)

In the news

Google on brink of joining the $1tn club
The stock market value of Google parent Alphabet is close to hitting $1tn for the first time, making it the fourth of the Big Tech to reach the milestone. The internet search company came within 1 per cent of the $1tn threshold on Friday, after a 7 per cent rally since the start of the year on hopes that it will report another record surge in advertising when it announces earnings on February 3. (FT)

Iran roiled over downed plane
Iran’s Revolutionary Guard commander was summoned to parliament on Sunday as public sentiment turned dramatically against the regime over the downing of a passenger aircraft that killed 176 people. Mark Esper, the US defence secretary, said he “didn’t see” evidence Tehran was preparing to attack US embassies, contradicting Donald Trump’s justification for the US assassination of Iranian general Qassem Soleimani. Here’s a look at how close the US and Iran came to war. (FT, NYT)

Pelosi prepares to file articles of impeachment
Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic Speaker of the House of Representatives, on Sunday said she had no regrets for holding back the articles of impeachment after the House voted in December to charge the president with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. She is expected to send the articles of impeachment to the Senate this week but Mr Trump on Sunday urged senators to   dismiss the charges outright rather than dignify them with a full trial. (FT, CNN, NYT)

Pound extends 2020 losses
Sterling fell 0.7 per cent on Monday morning after new data showed the UK economy contracted by an unexpectedly large amount in November. Over the weekend an external member of the committee that sets interest rates in the UK said he was willing to vote for a cut in interest rates. (FT)

Anger at Boeing CEO’s exit package
Families of people killed in crashes of Boeing’s 737 Max reacted with anger on Sunday at the revelation that the company’s ousted chief executive, Dennis Muilenburg, walked away with stock, benefits and share options potentially worth $80m. Dave Calhoun, a longtime Boeing board member, takes over the struggling aerospace group from Monday. (FT)

Boris Johnson in Northern Ireland
Devolved government returned to Northern Ireland over the weekend after a three-year absence. Arlene Foster of the Democratic Unionists was appointed Northern Ireland’s first minister of the Stormont assembly. Boris Johnson, UK prime minister, and Leo Varadkar, Ireland’s leader, will meet in Belfast on Monday. (FT)

Taiwan’s pro-US president wins second term
Voters in Taiwan resoundingly re-elected Tsai Ing-wen on Saturday with the highest vote count ever seen in the country’s presidential elections, a result that could bolster buoyant markets and harden Chinese president Xi Jinping’s uncompromising approach. FT Asia editor Jamil Anderlini writes that the poll makes the region a bit more dangerous. The FT View is that democracies should deter Beijing’s efforts to isolate the island. (FT, Bloomberg)

Fragile ceasefire begins in Libya
Khalifa Haftar, the military strongman fighting since April to seize the capital Tripoli, has accepted a joint appeal by the presidents of Russia and Turkey to halt fighting. Gen Haftar had initially rejected the call for a pause in the violence issued last week during a meeting in Istanbul between Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, and Recep Tayyip Erdogan, his Turkish counterpart. Russia is backing Gen Haftar, while Turkey has sent troops to support the internationally recognised government in Tripoli. The leaders of the two warring sides will meet in Moscow for talks today. (FT, Al Jazeera)

Philippine volcano erupts
A volcano has erupted in the Philippines, disrupting hundreds of flights and forcing schools and the stock exchange to shut. Taal Volcano, located 100km south of the capital Manila, first erupted on Sunday, sending a column of ash and steam up to 15km into the atmosphere. Philippine authorities evacuated more than 13,000 people from the area and warned that a big eruption could follow. (FT)

Brazil delays 5G auction
Brazil’s auction of coveted 5G spectrum has been delayed, in a setback to the country’s technological ambitions that could cost the state billions in lost tax revenues and investments. The auction was scheduled for March but a dispute at Anatel, the nation’s telecoms regulator, over the rules for the auction have held back the sale. (FT)

The day ahead

US-China trade truce
Chinese vice-premier Liu He begins a four-day trip to Washington on Monday to sign the “phase one” trade deal agreed in December. The US is also planning to announce a new forum for dialogue with China in a throwback to the engagement strategy pursued by previous administrations. (SCMP, FT)

Royal summit
The Queen has summoned Prince Charles and his sons Prince William and Prince Harry for an emergency summit on Monday at the Sandringham estate, after the Duke and Duchess of Sussex abruptly announced last week their intention to step back from royal duties. The Duchess of Sussex is expected to join the summit by telephone from Canada. “Megxit” has set off a frenzy in Canada, where some hope to host the departing royals. Black Britons are wondering   what took them so long. (FT, NYT)

Oscar announcement
Nominees for the 2020 Academy Awards will be announced this afternoon from Los Angeles. Watch it here, but first, here are   predictions for all 24 categories, including a likely all-male directing group despite strong offerings from female directors. (LA Times)

Fourth-quarter earnings season looms
A trio of big banks kick off the fourth-quarter earnings season in the US on Tuesday. Analysts and investors are hopeful that corporate America will report its first quarter of earnings growth since the end of 2018. Here is what to expect. (FT)

Keep up with the important business, economic and political stories in the coming days with the FT’s Week Ahead. Click to subscribe   here. And don’t miss our FT News Briefing podcast — a short daily rundown of the top global stories.

What else we’re reading

Is Vanguard too big?
The dramatic growth of the fund manager — last year it took in more money than rivals BlackRock and Fidelity combined — has raised questions about its influence on corporate America. Once an upstart investment company shunned — even mocked — by rivals, it has disrupted the investment management world. (FT)

Biden and Sanders reprise Iraq war fight in 2020 race
Joe Biden has sought to position himself as the Democratic candidate with the most foreign policy experience ahead of the latest televised debate. A television ad released on Friday featured recent news clips from Iran alongside older photos of the former vice-president in the White House Situation Room and speaking at the UN. His rival Bernie Sanders, who voted against the Iraq war, has blasted his opponent for supporting the 2002 US invasion. (FT)

Salvini’s comeback bid
Italy’s nationalist League is hoping to capitalise on a stunning mayoral victory in staunchly leftwing Emilia-Romagna to make gains in legislative assembly polls in the heart of Italian socialism. Victory could trigger a crisis in the ruling coalition — and catapult Matteo Salvini to the premiership. (FT)

Coaching v commanding
Andrew Hill recounts how industrial group Linde won over sceptical staff in 2017 with a safety drive based on “active listening”. No boss loses by cutting short a holiday to tackle problems, Pilita Clark writes, with the Iran crisis and the Australian bushfires offering lessons in what not to do. For those returning from a holiday mindset, Janan Ganesh has advice on avoiding hangovers in 2020. (FT)

Record London property sale
Property magnate Cheung Chung-kiu, whose company owns the “Cheesegrater” skyscraper, will buy a Knightsbridge mansion for more than £200m, a house price record. Here’s a helpful guide for new and longtime Londoners: the city’s best bike routes from FT Globetrotter, which also looks into healthy living in Tokyo. (FT) 

The hassles of EU train travel
We all want to fly less, Michael Skapinker writes, and train journeys are more comfortable, easier to work on and far greener. It’s a shame then that the“short-haul” rail market is so flawed. (FT)

Michael Skapinker will be chairing a discussion on “The Future of Flying: electric planes, green offsets or staying at home” at the FT’s London offices on January 20. Tickets here.

Video of the day

How map makers will win the 2020 US election
The FT’s head of visual and data journalism Alan Smith investigates gerrymandering, using tiddlywinks and a salamander. (FT)

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.US senators have clashed over the need for key witnesses to testify at D...

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

US senators have clashed over the need for key witnesses to testify at Donald Trump’s impeachment trial, ahead of Tuesday’s start to the main proceedings to decide whether the president should be removed from office. 

Democrats have been demanding that the Republican majority allow key officials, such as John Bolton, the former national security adviser, and Mick Mulvaney, the White House chief of staff, to appear at the trial.

Mitch McConnell, the Senate leader, and the White House, are opposed, but some centrist Republicans are sympathetic to the idea, putting pressure on Mr Trump’s party to give in.

On Saturday, the impeachment managers — a group of Democratic lawmakers from the House of Representatives who will act as the prosecution — filed a 110-page legal brief declaring that Mr Trump’s conduct in the Ukraine scandal was the “worst nightmare” of America’s founding fathers. 

It followed the appointment of Kenneth Starr as part of a heavyweight legal team to defend Mr Trump at the impeachment trial. Mr Starr led the effort to unseat Bill Clinton in the 1990s, which culminated with the impeachment of the former president for lying about his relations with Monica Lewinsky, a White House intern at the time.

Mr Trump also appointed Robert Ray, who succeeded Mr Starr as independent counsel in the Clinton probe, to his legal team as well as Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard law professor who successfully defended Claus von Bulow and OJ Simpson in murder trials that gripped the US.

Here’s a full guide to only the third impeachment trial of a US president since the founding of the republic.

In an editorial, the FT says the conduct of the trial is bound to be as political as the eventual vote. But that by scrutinising as much information as possible a saga so tainted with partisanship can still leave a constructive legacy. (FT)

Davos preview

World leaders, chief executives and celebrities are gathering in the Swiss mountain town of Davos this week for the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting.

The event, which marks its 50th anniversary this year, has a reputation for high-altitude pontificating but opens on Tuesday under a shadow of uncertainty about trade and global economic growth. This year’s themes include the future of healthcare, how business can confront economic inequality and   the climate crisis, which the WEF for the first time listed as all five of its top risks.

Here’s our preview of five issues that will probably occupy delegates’ attention. Some of the FT’s top journalists will be on site to bring you insights from the sidelines — look out for our coverage on FT.com and in FirstFT. In the FT News Briefing podcast, Andrew Edgecliffe-Johnson explains how climate change and Big Tech will drive this year’s agenda. Meanwhile, our global business columnist Rana Foroohar, who will be attending her 20th Davos this week, gives her 5 top tips for anyone attending. (WEF, FT, Bloomberg)

This week,  Moral Money will publish daily at 5.00 GMT from Davos to keep you updated on all the developments related to sustainable and ESG investing. We’re also offering a free 30-day trial — sign up at   ft.com/moralmoney.

In the news

China reports sharp rise in cases of Sars-like virus
China has reported a sharp rise in the number of people infected with a Sars-like virus and confirmed cases outside of the central city of Wuhan for the first time, adding to concerns about the spread of the respiratory disease. Authorities in Wuhan said 136 patients had been infected with the virus, bringing the number of confirmed cases in the city to more than 190. In total, three people have been killed and nine remain in critical condition since the virus was identified earlier this month. (FT)

US boosts anti-Tehran tech funding
US-backed technology companies have recorded a recent increase in the use of circumvention software in Iran after elevating efforts to help Iranian anti-regime protesters thwart internet censorship. A US state department official told the FT that after protests broke out in Iran in 2018, Washington accelerated efforts to help Iranians communicate with each other and the outside world. (FT)

Brussels alarmed by Brexit plans
The UK’s pledge to diverge from EU rules after Brexit has provoked alarm in Brussels, with officials warning to “prepare for the worst” following chancellor Sajid Javid’s interview with the FT on Friday. Britain’s auto and aerospace industries also warned that a split from EU rules would cost “billions” of pounds. (FT)

BofA plans to ‘double’ US retail
Bank of America can double its consumer market share despite fears about the power of the country’s largest institutions, Brian Moynihan, chief executive, told the FT. BofA is already the largest US consumer bank, with $730bn of retail deposits that is by far its most profitable unit. Read our interview here. (FT)

Airbus plans tickets derivatives
Airbus is setting up a trading venue for derivatives designed to hedge the air travel industry’s exposure to highly volatile ticket prices. The European aircraft manufacturer is due to announce the project, named Skytra, on Monday after more than two years of preparation. (FT)

SpaceX successfully aborts test
The Elon Musk-led private space exploration company successfully completed an emergency escape simulation in Florida that could allow it to launch Nasa astronauts as soon as March. The demonstration, broadcast live on Sunday, involved engineering a deliberate malfunction to test how astronauts would be saved in the event of an engine shutdown. (FT)

Royals withdraw
Prince Harry and Meghan Markle will no longer use “Royal Highness” titles and agreed to repay £2.4m spent refurbishing their residence in Windsor, Buckingham Palace announced on Saturday. The Duke of Sussex said he had “ no other option” in his first public remarks on the decision to step back as senior royals, but Camilla Cavendish says the couple is swapping one gilded cage for another. (FT, Guardian) 

Guaidó leaves Venezuela to meet US secretary of state
Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaidó has defied a travel ban imposed by the government of Nicolás Maduro and left the country for the first time in nearly a year, crossing into Colombia where he will meet US secretary of state Mike Pompeo. Mr Guaidó is then expected to travel to the US and Europe. (FT)

The day ahead

Market close for MLK day
US stock and bond markets will be closed today to commemorate the birthday of civil rights leader Martin Luther King. Banks and the US postal service will also be closed for the federal holiday, which was signed into law in 1983. Here’s a   full list of what is and is not open today. (YahooFinance, NJ.com)

UK-Africa summit
The inaugural UK-Africa Investment Summit, conceived as a coming-out party for “Global Britain”, will open on Monday in London, where some 15 African heads of state will hear Britain’s post-Brexit pitch. The FT View is that Britain is right to refocus on the business opportunities Africa presents. (FT, BBC)

Huawei trial opens
The battle begins over Huawei chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou’s extradition to the US with a hearing in Vancouver on Monday. The US alleges that Ms Meng, the daughter of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei, misled banks and violated sanctions against Iran. (FT, WaPo)

The FT is sharpening its coverage of the City of London. The daily Lombard column relaunches on Monday with a new editor, Kate Burgess.

What else we’re reading

Why we need to regulate AI
Companies cannot just build technology and let market forces decide how it will be used, Alphabet and Google chief executive Sundar Pichai writes. They must also make sure that artificial intelligence is harnessed for good. Don’t miss Joseph Stiglitz arguing that the internet’s unregulated “marketplace for ideas” doesn’t work. (FT)

Use the eco-excuse at your peril
There is no doubt that carbon emissions need to be cut, fast. But policies that make everyday life more expensive are not going to be uniformly popular, Pilita Clark writes. Don’t expect the earth from fund managers on climate change, Jonathan Ford writes— decarbonisation is the responsibility of governments. (FT)

China’s birth rate time-bomb
Chinese women gave birth to 14.7m babies last year, the fewest in six decades, according to statistics released on Friday. Demographic decline and labour shortages represent a serious threat to a Chinese economy already growing at its slowest pace in 29 years. Read more of the FT’s coverage of ageing populations. (FT)

Populism and the smouldering rage of American poverty
A trio of new books counters the view of populist voters as racists. In a weekend books essay Edward Luce reviews Dignity: Seeking Respect in Back Row America by Chris Arnade, who travelled across the US to interview the poor. In The New Class War, Michael Lind, a scholar at the University of Texas in Austin, offers a bracing, and at times brilliant, polemic against what he calls the epistemic closure of the “managerial elites”. While Cas Mudde has produced an indispensable guide to extreme rightwing parties in The Far Right Today. Catch up on our five best weekend reads here. (FT)

The end of the executive assistant
Executive assistants once ran the office. Increasingly, the office runs without them. More than 1.6m secretarial and administrative-assistant jobs have quietly vanished in the US since 2000, a decline that in magnitude mirrors factory losses as new technologies took over duties such as filing and phone calls. (WSJ)

Sign up to Tech Scroll Asia

The woes of Indian hotel group Oyo, one of the crown jewels in SoftBank’s Asia portfolio, features prominently in last week’s Tech Scroll Asia, which also investigates Alibaba’s predatory practices in China’s ecommerce sector and explores the rise of unmanned convenience stores in South Korea.

We’re offering a free 30-day trial to Tech Scroll Asia, which includes complimentary access to the Financial Times. Sign up here.

Video of the day

The Week Ahead
James Sandy previews the big stories we’re watching this week, including the World Economic Forum gathering in Davos, Meng Wanzhou’s extradition hearing, US earnings results from Netflix and a monetary policy decision from the ECB. (FT)

urn:contentItem:5WNB-9WP1-DXP9-94ST-00000-00FirstFT: Today’s top stories2019-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:04ZLexisNexisFirstFT: Today’s top stories Gordon Smith, Eli Meixler and Priyanka Vora

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our  quiz. SoftB... FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email. How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our  quiz .  SoftBank is to launch a...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our  quiz. SoftB...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our  quiz. 

SoftBank is to launch a second investment fund totalling $108bn with investors including Microsoft, Standard Chartered and the sovereign wealth fund of Kazakhstan.

The Vision Fund II follows a splurge of investments in Uber, WeWork and other technology companies in a span of two years through its first $97bn Vision fund, which was mainly backed by the governments of Saudi Arabia and Abu Dhabi. 

The new fund will target “market-leading, tech-enabled growth companies” to facilitate “the continued acceleration of the AI revolution”, SoftBank said. Rajeev Misra, a former senior Deutsche Bank executive who runs the first Vision Fund, is likely to run the second one. (FT)

In the news

Tech earnings round-up
Google’s advertising business rebounded in the second quarter, prompting a share price rally for parent Alphabet, and the move to one-day shipping reinvigorated revenue growth at Amazon. Australia’s government, meanwhile, said on Friday that it planned to tighten regulation of Facebook and Google to address the harm that it said large digital platforms were causing to businesses, consumers and the media. Big Tech must brace for a bleaker future as new regulations would prove expensive. (FT)

FedEx accused of breaking Chinese law
An investigation by the Chinese government into FedEx showed the US parcel delivery service broke the law by not delivering packages to the country’s leading telecoms equipment maker Huawei, state media alleged on Friday. (FT)

US judge slashes $2bn damages award in Bayer case
Bayer, the German chemicals and pharmaceuticals group, scored a partial victory in its long-running legal battle over allegations that its Roundup pesticide causes cancer, after a California judge slashed the damages awarded in the most costly case so far from $2bn to $87m. (FT)

ECB signals fresh stimulus
Mario Draghi on Thursday paved the way for fresh monetary stimulus before he departs in October, signalling to investors that rate cuts and a new round of asset purchases are likely at the European Central Bank’s next meeting in September. But other eurozone officials may not share Mr Draghi’s “whatever it takes” ambitions. (FT)

Buffett lunch winner apologises
The Chinese cryptocurrency entrepreneur who paid a record $4.6m to have lunch with Warren Buffett has apologised for self-promotion and “immature” behaviour amid questions over why he postponed the meal. (FT) 

Farage teams up with Trump supporters
Nigel Farage has joined forces with Donald Trump-supporting Americans to raise money for the UK’s fight to leave the European Union. The new initiative, called World4Brexit, is expected to draw advice from members of Mr Trump’s circle, such as Steve Bannon, but will not fund candidates, according to fundraising documents. (FT)

Maduro’s stepsons sanctioned
The US has imposed sanctions on the three stepsons of Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro for their alleged role in a vast international corruption network that profited from a government scheme to import food. (FT)

Did you keep up with the news this week? Take our  quiz. Who will serve as home secretary in Boris Johnson’s newly announced cabinet? Priti Patel, Michael Gove or Andrea Leadsom? 

Sign up for Moral Money 

This week’s  newsletter asks the head of one of the world’s largest mining companies how he is addressing climate change. It looks at the growing backlash against tax avoidance and has more from the SEC and its plans to rein in proxy advisers.  Sign-up here.

The days ahead

Economic data
The second-quarter US GDP release on Friday is expected to show growth slowed to 1.6 per cent, from more than 3 per cent in the first quarter. Friday’s print may shed light on whether the trade spat has  taken a similar toll as it has on China after the White House announced a second, $16bn round of federal aid to farmers. (FT)

Twitter earnings
Twitter has a chance to detail its plans to increase users and advertising revenues when it releases its second-quarter earnings on Friday. The social media network has been under fire for allowing politicians, including President Donald Trump, to break its rules. It has also had to remove thousands of accounts linked to governments in Iran and Russia. Here are five things to look out for. (Reuters)

Hong Kong braces for more protests
Organisers are planning to push ahead with demonstrations on Saturday in Yuen Long, an outlying district of Hong Kong that was the scene of mob violence last week, despite the police banning the gathering and Beijing warning that the People’s Liberation Army can legally intervene. Watch the FT’s deputy Asia editor Ravi Mattu explain why Hong Kong’s political crisis is entering a worrying new phase. (SCMP, FT)

Iran meeting in Vienna
Representatives from Britain, France, Germany, Russia, China and Iran will convene on July 28 in hopes of saving the 2015 nuclear deal, as a European naval alliance in the Strait of Hormuz struggles to gain traction. US sanctions on Iran have halved trade between the Islamic republic and the United Arab Emirates. (Reuters, FT)

What else we’re reading

‘I want to understand who ordered the killing’
Ten months after the execution of Jamal Khashoggi his body parts have not been found, and his fiancée Hatice Cengiz is still demanding answers as to why the Saudi journalist was murdered. She sits down for an emotional lunch with the FT’s deputy editor Roula Khalaf. (FT)

China’s state of business
Much of modern China’s epic growth was driven by private enterprise — but under Xi Jinping, the Communist party has returned to being the ultimate authority in business as well as politics. (Guardian)

Learning to love meetings
Resentment of office meetings is almost universal. But there are situations where there is simply no substitute: everyone arrives with a brisk update and leaves with a crisp to-do list. After all, the value of a meeting is less what happens there than what comes after, Tim Harford writes. (FT)

Meet the evolutionary relatives
Recent fossil finds and technological breakthroughs have challenged conventional wisdom about Homo sapiens history. Chris Stringer, a researcher at the Natural History Museum, London, offers a revised tour of our 500,000-year-old genetic neighbourhood in the third instalment of the FT Magazine’s Masters of Science series. (FT)

Get a shot of inspiration each Saturday with the best in life, arts and culture — sign up here to FT Weekend.

How Turkey purged its intellectuals
For more than a century, Ankara University’s storied school of political science dominated the education of Turkey’s governing class — until the Erdogan regime began dismantling it. (NYT)

The case against Bretton Woods
Seventy-five years after the Bretton Woods conference, the multilateral system it established has become too bureaucratic for purpose. Gillian Tett outlines the argument for a rethink. In case you missed it, Martin Wolf examined the health of the Bretton Woods system amid rising nationalism. (FT)

Bollywood stars target India’s start-ups
Deepika Padukone, Bollywood’s highest-paid female star in 2017, is relishing her latest role: start-up investor. “The way I invest is exactly the way I would choose any of my film scripts: follow your gut,” she says. Watch the interview here. (FT)

Searching for the Knights Templar
Under the cobblestoned streets of Paris’s Marais lie the ancient remnants of the Knights Templar’s European stronghold, which boasted towers, a drawbridge and a gothic church. There are still traces of the once powerful “state-within-a-state” — if you know where to look. (BBC)

My perfect summer
Martha Stewart’s taking the helicopter, Terence Conran is in trouble on the beach, and Marlon James (pictured) is wishing he was on the Orient Express. Our assembled cast from the worlds of politics, art, literature and business share their thoughts on what makes the perfect getaway. (FT)

Video of the day

Boris Johnson’s election cabinet
Boris Johnson, Britain’s new prime minister, has appointed several hard Brexiters to his cabinet. FT editor Lionel Barber and deputy opinion editor Miranda Green discuss whether he is simply preparing for an early general election. (FT)

FT subscribers can click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

Nearly two-thirds of Americans say this year’s record-setting Wall Street rally has had little or no impact on their personal finances, according to new poll commissioned by the Financial Times and the Peter G Peterson Foundation.

Just 40 per cent of respondents correctly said the stock market had increased in value in 2019, whereas in reality all the major US stock market indices have reached record highs in the last month.

The findings call into question whether one of the strongest bull markets in a decade will boost Donald Trump’s re-election chances. The president has staked his bid on a strong US economy, and frequently touts stock market performance as evidence of his economic leadership.

Last Friday, Mr Trump wrote on Twitter: “New Stock Market Record today, AGAIN. Congratulations USA!” Earlier in the week, he tweeted: “Another new Stock Market Record. Enjoy!”

The survey findings are part of the monthly FT-Peterson US Economic Monitor, which tracks voter sentiment towards the US economy in the run-up to next year’s presidential election. The most recent poll was conducted just before the Thanksgiving holiday. It reflects the opinions of 1,010 likely voters nationwide, and has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. (FT)

In the news

Huawei files new lawsuit in US
The Chinese telecoms equipment maker has filed a lawsuit in a federal court in New Orleans against the Federal Communications Commission. Huawei is alleging the FCC acted illegally when it banned the company’s customers from receiving federal broadband subsidies. Boris Johnson, meanwhile, has proposed excluding Huawei from Britain’s 5G networks after lobbying by Donald Trump at the Nato summit and in China the company is facing criticism over its treatment of a former employee. Robert Zoellick, former World Bank president, rebuked President Trump for his policy towards China. (FT)

Legal scholars say Trump’s actions were impeachable
Three leading constitutional scholars told Congress that Donald Trump had committed impeachable offences, as the House of Representatives judiciary committee launched a new phase of the impeachment inquiry. The professors were invited by Democrats to testify on the first day of hearings before the committee, chaired by New York congressman Jerrold Nadler. An academic invited by the Republicans said there was “a paucity of evidence” to impeach the president. (FT)

Shinzo Abe launches $121bn stimulus package
Japan’s prime minister has launched his first fiscal stimulus since 2016 with a larger-than-expected ¥13.2tn ($121bn) package to repair typhoon damage, upgrade infrastructure and invest in new technologies. The spending package is one of the largest since the 2008-09 financial crisis and marks a return to the free-spending early days of “Abenomics”, when Shinzo Abe was elected for a second term in 2012. (FT)

Labour rules out coalition
With just a week to go until Britons go to the polls the leader of the opposition Labour party has ruled out negotiating with smaller parties in the event of a hung parliament. Labour are lagging far behind the ruling Conservative party in the polls and many believe the party’s only viable path to power is by cobbling together a coalition. “We will implement our manifesto . . . no negotiation, no deal, no coalitions,” said John McDonnell, would-be finance minister, in an interview with the Financial Times. Currency traders, meanwhile, are betting on a win for Boris Johnson’s party. Catch-up with the latest polls in the FT’s poll of polls. (FT)

New owner for the New York Mets?
Billionaire financier Steven Cohen is in talks to buy a majority stake in the New York baseball team. Sterling Partners, the investment vehicle for current Mets owner Fred Wilpon, is negotiating a deal with the hedge fund manager that would value the franchise at $2.6bn. It is not the first time the controversial money manager has tried to buy a baseball team: in 2012 he tried but failed to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers. (FT)

Nato summit ends in acrimony
A summit to celebrate 70 years of the Nato military alliance ended in acrimony, with Donald Trump branding Justin Trudeau “ two-faced” after video footage appeared to capture Canada’s prime minister mocking the US president to other Nato leaders. After the video emerged the US leader abruptly cancelled a press conference to mark the conclusion of the summit in Watford, near London. Mr Trump’s latest intervention exacerbated tensions as Nato leaders battled to curb disagreements over Syria and funding of the cold war-era alliance. (FT)

Do you think the 70-year-old alliance is still important? Have your say in our latest poll.

French pension protests
Hundreds of thousands of French workers will participate on Thursday in the first day of an indefinite public sector walkout, expected to be the biggest in 25 years, over proposed sweeping pension reforms that would eventually push back the retirement age. Here’s how to prepare for widespread transit disruption. (FT)

Fed weighs in on repo turmoil
Stress tests designed to make banks more stable might have led lenders to hoard cash, exacerbating a spike in short-term borrowing costs that forced the Federal Reserve to step in earlier this year, according to Randal Quarles, the lead US banking regulator. (FT)

Corporate round-up
Slack recovered lost ground late on Wednesday after the app reported stronger revenue growth, but shares remain down more than 40 per cent from listing. Twitter is planning its first foray into the junk bond market on Thursday, hoping to raise $600m following lacklustre third-quarter earnings. Meanwhile, a new lawsuit alleges Lyft failed to protect female passengers from sexual assault. (FT)

ICE executive exchanges business for politics
Kelly Loeffler was the smooth investor-relations chief who pitched Intercontinental Exchange to Wall Street. Now she is promoting President Donald Trump’s border wall. On Wednesday, the executive from the Atlanta-based exchange group was named a Republican senator for the southern US state of Georgia. (FT)

Russia accused of assassination
Germany has expelled two Russian diplomats over Moscow’s failure to help investigate a Chechen rebel’s murder in Berlin in August, which federal prosecutors found had “sufficient indications” to attribute to Russia. In the Czech Republic, the top prosecutor reopened a fraud probe into billionaire prime minister Andrej Babis. (FT)

Thousands of top chip engineers have been lost to China, as Beijing lures workers with generous benefits to bolster its semiconductor industry in the tech war with the US. Read more about Taiwan’s brain drain in this week’s Tech Scroll Asia newsletter and   sign up here.

FT Seasonal Appeal

Asim is a Sumatran tiger at London Zoo. He is also part of a research project to help us understand more about his wild cousins in Indonesia. Research — like that featuring Asim — carried out by the Zoological Society of London, the FT’s Season Appeal partner, is underpinning efforts to conserve species that are critically endangered in the wild.

Learn more about this year’s seasonal appeal here and donate   here. This podcast explores new ways to finance conservation.

The days ahead

Saudi Aramco IPO and Opec meeting
The Saudi state oil company is set to price its IPO on Thursday, with Riyadh seeking to raise $25bn after higher ambitions were thwarted. Saudi Arabia is also pushing Opec to back a deeper cut to oil production at a two-day meeting in Vienna that begins on Thursday. Here’s what to watch for, including foot-dragging from Russia. (Reuters, FT)

Tiffany earnings
The jewellery company is expected to post a rise in same-store sales, helped by new marketing and product lines, when it reports third-quarter results on Thursday about a week after agreeing to be bought by French luxury group LVMH for $16.6bn. (FT)

Trudeau to unveil programme for government
Returning from the fractious Nato summit, Justin Trudeau will formally unveil the agenda of his weakened minority government on Thursday as parliament convenes for the first time since the election. (Reuters)

Sign up to Trade Secrets

Donald Trump is treading a politically delicate path as he tries to help Big Tech improve its access to foreign markets at a time when the sector is increasingly becoming a punchbag in Washington. More in Trade Secrets, the FT’s daily briefing on the changing face of international trade and globalisation.   Sign up here.

What else we’re reading

Women of the Year 2019
Every December, the Financial Times dedicates a special FT Weekend Magazine to profiling the most influential women across the world. This year’s list includes Nobel Prize-winner Esther Duflo, justice Brenda Hale, actress Emma Thompson and more. We also asked for your help — and received more than 100 nominations. Here is a selection of the standouts. (FT)

Buttigieg and Biden show the political centre still holds
Take your pick as to the shock of the year: Pete Buttigieg’s surge towards the Democratic presidential nomination, or the staying power of Joe Biden. The presence of two moderates at the front of the field, or thereabouts, challenges an assumption that prevailed at the start of the year: the left’s takeover of the Democratic party, writes Janan Ganesh. Meanwhile, Edward Luce, observes the brewing storm around Rudy Giuliani and asks: How did he get here? (FT)

The EU takes on the dollar
As Europe warily watches growing industrial competition from China and increasingly erratic leadership in Washington, the role of the euro is at the centre of a profound reassessment of how the bloc defends its financial interests. Don’t miss the first entry in our FT Series: Europe First. (FT)

Fighting for the Amazon’s future
Deforestation and fires in the Amazon rainforest, coupled with Jair Bolsonaro’s support for development could have catastrophic consequences on the environment and economies worldwide. But a web of shell companies protect investors who support the damage. Read more in our Special Report: Amazon conservation. (FT)

Britain’s secret war with Russia
The poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal in March 2018 sparked a fierce intelligence and PR battle between London and Moscow, the details of which are only now emerging, revealing how Russia projects disproportionate power thanks to divisions and distractions in the west. (Atlantic)

Power dining in New York
If you worship money and status, New York is a city of churches. From a classic grand grill to red-sauce Italian in Harlem, here are five places fit for big shots, as well as our picks in Tokyo, Paris and Mayfair, London. Nominate your top power dining spots choices here. (FT)

India’s missing wills
Indians are great at handling many rites of passage, such as weddings, but dismal at preparing for death, writes Shruti Advani. A 2018 report said 97 per cent of Indian families with significant businesses had no succession plan in place. (FT)

Podcast of the day

Why astrology is thriving in 2019
You may have noticed the revival of astrology in recent years: Americans are spending more and more on ‘mystical services’ (currently a $2.2bn market). Lilah and Gris explore what the growing trend says about our culture with help from Culture Call listeners. (FT)

Saudi Aramco launched its long-awaited initial public offering on Sunday, kicking off the centrepiece of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s ambitious plan to overhaul...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.Saudi Aramco launched its long-awaited initial public offering on Sunda...

FT subscribers can  click here to receive FirstFT every day by email.

Saudi Aramco launched its long-awaited initial public offering on Sunday, kicking off the centrepiece of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s ambitious plan to overhaul the kingdom’s oil-addicted economy.

The listing on the domestic Tadawul exchange has faced a series of delays, triggering doubts over a $2tn-target valuation. Riyadh is hoping to raise as much as $60bn with a sale of up to 3 per cent of the company, but bankers believe a $1.2tn-$1.5tn valuation is more realistic.

The company said it would issue the IPO prospectus on November 9, with the final offer price, listing size and valuation to be determined at the end of the bookbuilding period. Saudi Aramco has also sweetened terms to win over investors, but two people briefed said the listing could still be pulled depending on the response.

The FT View is that MBS’s shallow reform effort underscores the lack of accountability for the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Don’t miss this photo essay, which offers a rare glimpse at how Saudi Arabia gets its oil. (FT, Bloomberg)

In the news

Are you better off since Trump came to power?
Nearly two-thirds of Americans say they are not financially better off than they were when Donald Trump was elected, according to the first in a series of new polls conducted by the Financial Times and the not-for-profit Peter G Peterson Foundation. A total of 31 per cent of Americans say they are now worse off financially than they were at the start of Mr Trump’s presidency, while another 33 per cent say there has been no change in their financial position since Mr Trump’s inauguration in January 2017. Thirty five per cent of the more than 1,000 people questioned for the nationwide poll said they are better off. (FT)

‘It is time for me to move on’
McDonald’s sacked Steve Easterbrook, its chief executive, after he engaged in a consensual relationship with a colleague that “violated” company policy. In an email to staff, the 52-year-old Briton, who has been credited with turning around the fast-food chain’s fortunes, admitted making a mistake and agreed it was time to move on. Chris Kempczinski, president of McDonald’s US business, will become the new chief executive. (FT)

Trade outlook
The US is pushing Taiwan to restrict its biggest chipmaker from producing semiconductors for Huawei and tighten technology exports to China. Toshimitsu Motegi, Japan’s foreign minister, said a new trade deal could lead to the elimination of US car tariffs in an interview with the FT, while US commerce secretary Wilbur Ross said he was “optimistic” that sticking points with China would be resolved. This single Chinese company dominates the electric vehicle battery market. (FT, WSJ)

JPMorgan’s bond boost
JPMorgan Chase has pushed more than $130bn of excess cash into long-dated bonds and cut the amount of loans it holds, marking a big shift in response to capital rules that treat loans as riskier than bonds. Berkshire Hathaway increased its cash pile to a record $128bn in the third quarter as it struggled to find large acquisitions. (FT)

Trump impeachment inquiry
The anonymous whistleblower who sparked the impeachment inquiry into Donald Trump has agreed to answer questions by House Republicans, while a top aide to Mike Mulvaney, the president’s acting chief of staff, has been instructed not to appear before a hearing on Monday. The FT View says an open impeachment inquiry offers welcome opportunities for public scrutiny. (FT) 

UK general election watch
Nigel Farage will not stand in the forthcoming election, but will campaign for a “clean break” Brexit, which the FT View calls a delusion. Our Big Read examines whether Boris Johnson’s gamble on a poll could be scuppered by voter volatility, while both Tory and Labour spending pledges will result in higher taxes. Stay up to date with our poll tracker. (FT)

China pension fund among world’s largest
China Life Pension has doubled its assets under management in the past year to more than Rmb1tn ($142bn) and is expected to join the ranks of the world’s largest pension funds over the next two years. China is also on pace to be the world’s best-performing stock market in 2019, with the benchmark CSI 300 index outpacing the FTSE 100, Japan’s Topix and the S&P 500. (FT)

KPMG partner cull
KPMG will axe a tenth of its UK partners by Christmas following individual performance reviews — the Big Four firm’s latest effort to scale back costs dramatically. The one-off cull of partners comes as it tries to recover from a reputational crisis and prepares for regulatory changes to the accounting sector. (FT)

Taiwan plays (cyber) war games
A multinational security exercise co-hosted by the US has begun in Taiwan, as the two allies seek to bolster Taipei’s defences against potentially crippling cyber attacks from China. Teams from Japan, Malaysia, the Czech Republic and the US will play alongside Taiwanese government and military officials to simulate attacks on Taiwan’s financial sector. (FT)

Sign up to Trade Secrets — our daily briefing

Trade Secrets is the FT’s must-read daily briefing on the changing face of international trade and globalisation. At a time when the global trading system is under threat, the US and China are battling each other on trade, and the UK is struggling to detach from the EU, FT Trade Secrets reports, explains and analyses one of the world’s most important stories.   Sign up now.

The day ahead

Uber earnings
The ride-hailing company reports third-quarter earnings after markets close on Monday, following disappointing second-quarter results. Rival Lyft posted rosier results last week. Under Armour, which is facing a federal accounting probe, and Pacific Gas and Electric, whose shares fell to a record low recently amid fears of liabilities linked to the fires in California, also report on Monday. (FT, WSJ)

Who will replace John Bercow? 
British lawmakers vote on the next House of Commons Speaker on Monday. John Bercow, who has been in the post for a decade, will make way for one of eight candidates. Here’s the line-up to replace the controversial Mr Bercow. (FT, Telegraph) 

US embassy in Tehran revisited
Forty years ago on Monday a group of Iranian college students stormed the US embassy in Tehran, triggering the start of a hostage crisis that lasted 444 days. Najmeh Bozorgmehr, the FT’s Tehran correspondent, visits the former US embassy that is now a ‘den of espionage’ museum run by the country’s Revolutionary Guard.

Keep up with the important business, economic and political stories in the coming days with the FT’s  Week Ahead. Click to subscribe    here. And don’t miss our  FT News Briefing podcast — a short daily rundown of the top global stories.

What else we’re reading

‘Few fund managers can match Fidelity’s totality’
To call the Johnsons Boston royalty would only be inaccurate insofar as Fidelity’s founding family is wealthier than the Windsors, and even more private. Forbes estimates that Abigail Johnson, the third-generation of Johnson to lead Fidelity, is worth more than $14bn, making her the 34th richest individual in the US. As investors’ money continues to gush from actively managed funds she talks to the FT about the challenges facing the mutual fund industry — from cryptocurrencies to quantum computing. (FT)

SoftBank’s blind spots
The near-collapse of SoftBank’s gamble on WeWork and the plummeting valuation of other holdings have shaken faith in Masayoshi Son’s investment genius and his bets on disruptive technology. Here’s a look into how WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann found a kindred spirit in Mr Son — and is walking away enriched. Is the worst over for SoftBank? Asks   this piece. (FT, NYT, NAR)

Rowena Chiu speaks out
For nearly 20 years Rowena Chiu did not discuss her experience working for Harvey Weinstein — in fact, she was silenced by a punitive non-disclosure agreement after she accused the Hollywood producer of sexual assault in 1998. “It took time to kind of unravel the story and for me to be ready,” she says. She also recorded a podcast. (FT)

Big Tech is selling dystopia
Silicon Valley’s leaders have grown from scrappy innovators to surveillance capitalists with the power to swing elections. The result is that, after four decades of private sector ascendancy, the public realm is closing in, Rana Foroohar writes. (FT) 

What’s left of Condé Nast?
Two years after Si Newhouse died (and Graydon Carter left), Anna Wintour and new chief executive Roger Lynch map out the future of the publishing company that is home to some of America’s most iconic magazines including Vogue, Vanity Fair and The New Yorker. (Intelligencer)

Milking the EU
The EU spends $65bn a year on farm subsidies intended to sustain rural communities. But across central and eastern Europe, the bulk of that money — the largest item in the bloc’s central budget — enriches anti-democratic politicians. Hungary’s central bank governor argues that the euro was a mistake. (NYT, FT)

Video of the day

The Week Ahead
Josh de la Mare on some of the top stories the FT will be watching this week, including the Bank of England decision on interest rates, half-year results from Toyota, an election in Spain and the 30th anniversary of the Berlin Wall’s fall. (FT)
